Dr. M. Montserrat Feu López (Sam Houston State University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

Sociedades Hispanas Confederadas, a transnational relief organization headquartered in Brooklyn, aided Spanish Civil War refugees and the underground resistance in Spain during the Francisco Franco dictatorship. The Confederadas newspaper, España Libre (1939-1977), revitalized anarchist and antifascist culture with the publication of short stories, poetry, essays, satirical chronicles, caricatures, and the reviews of popular theater. The presentation focuses on one of the most esteemed editors of the newspaper, Jesús González Malo, who had been a Spanish Civil War militiaman. During his tenure, he politically and financially supported the anarcho-syndicalist clandestine resistance in Spain and relocated refugees and exiles. His closest anarcho-syndicalist contributors published anarchist literature and antifascist humor with a clear awareness of master narratives, playful literary approaches, and affective engagement with readers. The presentation briefly analyzes selected texts for their re-articulation of anarchism in exile: (1) José Castilla Moraless plays, (2) Félix Martí Ibáñezs short stories, (3) Adolfo Camíns poems, (4) Ramón J. Senders essays and short stories, and (5) Josep Bartolís cartoons.
column2: Spanish Anarcho-Syndicalists In New York: Exile And Anti-Francoism, 1936-1977

column1:
Dr. Gretchen J Lemke-Santangelo (Saint Mary's College of California)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

Oral historians often encounter silence in relationship to womens sexual experiences, particularly if such experiences have involved trauma and violence. Understanding the cultural, social, and political factors that inhibit disclosure is key to both identifying and interpreting silences, and to establishing a foundation for greater trust and candor. Of equal importance is knowing when to let silence prevail. Memory is the stuff of identity, and when it threatens ones sense of self, or relationships between self and others, it may be suppressed, censored, or reshaped—all for good reasons. Breaking the silence can be therapeutic, but historians arent trained therapists. Drawing upon interviews from my books Abiding Courage and Daughters of Aquarius, this paper will discuss how to interrogate, and in some cases, delicately push through the silences in womens stories. It will also use case studies to examine the fine line between asking for too much and too little.
column2: Telling Secrets: Interpreting And Pushing Through Womens Silences Around Sexuality And Sexual Trauma

column1:
Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

This paper analyzes narratives of town creation and town promotion in DeLand, Florida and Thomasville, Georgia. These two communities faced similar challenges in the Gilded Age and Progressive Era as they marketed themselves to potential Northern investors and residents. Promoters for both strove to counter negative perceptions of the region based on climate, geography, and regional history. Both continue, in the present day, to craft compelling historical narratives to brand themselves to tourists, businesses, and residents, and both are part of the national Main Street Center, which makes historic preservation a key element of development and revitalization. Contemporary efforts to market these spaces incorporate historical forms that shape downtown landscapes: murals, plaques, streetscapes, museums. The narratives they present resonate—and reproduce—those created by the earliest boosters. Both the contemporary stories and the historic templates they reference rely on a series of elisions and perspectives that mythologize elements of the past and elide complex or controversial histories related to race and class. In DeLand, contemporary historical narratives emphasize white pioneer stories, with only passing reference to the African Americans who labored in the areas turpentine and citrus industries. In Thomasville, Georgia, the revived Main Street and nearby neighborhoods restore the Victorian charm that, along with nearby plantations, is the towns tourism draw. In both communities, alternate histories exist slightly off the beaten track, metaphorizing the historic relationships between black and white, privileged and working-class residents.
column2: The Best Place On Earth: Narratives Of Southern Town Promotion And Identity

column1:
Dr. Robert Michael Zecker (SAint Francis Xavier University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

At the end of World War II, the International Workers Order, a progressive consortium of ethnic lodges, championed a vision of continued U.S.-Soviet cooperation, independence for colonized peoples, and social democracy at home as the fulfillment of Roosevelts Four Freedoms. As the U.S. girded for a Cold War against the erstwhile Soviet allies, the IWO also opposed a permanent military-industrial wartime footing that it argued diverted resources from more productive and egalitarian economic activity. Local IWO lodges wanted to know why the U.S. had the capacity to bring Nazi scientists to America to work on weapons programs, but could not find the means to enact universal health care or defend unions from Taft-Hartley assaults. IWO papers denounced the governments leniency toward DPs with authoritarian pasts recast as useful brain workers in the fight against Communism. The doors of America are flung wide open to some of the worst fascist scum of Europe, one paper thundered. As the Cold War escalated, support for health care and unions, anti-militarism, cooperation with the Soviets and anti-colonialism were all deemed stigmata of the IWOs subversive nature. Prosecution of the Order as a Communist front, deportation of members and dismemberment of its assets by court order taught these unrepentant advocates of social democracy the limits of dissent in Cold War America.
column2: The Doors Of America Are Flung Open To Some Of The Worst Fascist Scum: The Fight For Social Democracy At Home And Abroad In The Early Cold War

column1:
Dr. Theresa Ventura (Concordia University, Montreal)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

As American naval ships sailed into Manila Bay in the spring of 1898, Ramon Reyes Lala, a Philippine expatriate living in New York City, secured a deal to publish his history of the archipelago. Lalas The Philippine Islands (1898) cast Philippine nature as rich but untapped due to the effete rule of Spain. He hoped the American intervention would bring three figures of modern enterprise – the scientist, engineer, and practical economist – to the former colony to discover what the Philippines have to add to the useful productions of the world (156). Like many wealthy and well-educated Filipinos collectively known as ilustrados, Lala was a liberal internationalist who wielded depictions of tropical nature to criticize Spain and promote foreign trade and investment. What was a nationalist and cosmopolitan strategy developed during long sojourns and exiles in Europe became, in an American context, an invitation to empire. This paper uses Lala and his travel writings as a lens into the tense politics of colonial collaboration in the US occupation of the Philippines and in the former Spanish empire more broadly. While Lillian Guerra and Francisco Scarano have called figures like Lala in the Caribbean pro-imperialist nationalists, this paper instead asks why the specter of American intervention seemed promising to liberal elites. How did their expectations contribute to American ideas about development and enterprise in the Pacific and Caribbean? What does this brief moment tell us about the multidirectional flow of images, expectations, and ideas in the shaping of the global south in the American imaginary?
column2: The Whole Country Is A Virgin Mine: Philippine Depictions Of Nature And Nation Before And After 1898

column1:
Mr. Max Forrester (Washington University in St. Louis)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

This paper looks at religion and diplomacy in the experience of immigrant and sedentary Indian groups in the Texas borderlands in the two decades before the U.S.-Mexican War, and argues that issues of faith and perceptions of fate profoundly influenced the political choices of Native peoples trapped between allegiances. The alliances that these Indian groups founded were frequently comprised of incredibly diverse peoples (Western Cherokees, Kickapoos, Delawares, and Shawnees among many others); this paper explores the role that mutually intelligible understandings of fate could play in facilitating a language of diplomacy, overcoming cultural differences and resource shortages, and choosing sides when violent conflict became inevitable. Through its identification of fate (understood as destiny, prophesy, or simple inevitability) as a potentially unifying and motivating factor, this investigation aims to expand our understanding of political decision-making and alliance-building among Native groups beyond the enemy of my enemy is my friend trope. Building on current historiographical discussions regarding local diplomacy and indigenous power on the Southern Plains, this paper employs both historical and ethnohistorical approaches to connect Native religiosity to the political imperatives of the region.
column2: They Begin By Mentioning The Great Being: Faith, Fate And Political Decision-Making In The Antebellum Texas Borderlands

column1:
Ms. Andrea R. Gray (Thomas Jefferson Foundation, Inc.)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

When Thomas Jefferson retired from the presidency at the age of sixty-five in 1809 he happily left political life in Washington and returned to his beloved Monticello. Writing to inhabitants of his own Albemarle County on 3 Apr. 1809 he confided that the pomp, the turmoil, the bustle & splendour of office, have drawn but deeper sighs for the tranquil & irresponsible occupations of private life, and I gladly lay down the distressing burthen of power. Jefferson never again held a public office, never traveled outside Virginia, and avoided entering public debates. Jefferson did, however, continue to toil during the last decade of his life as he spearheaded the founding of the University of Virginia. Believing education to be imperative for the good of society and of wise government, he conceived of and drafted the legislation that would establish the state school, designed its buildings, recruited its faculty, and served as rector until his death. In this paper I will look at Jeffersons retirement years and how he balanced his desire for the tranquil & irresponsible occupations of private life with the labor-intensive public act of promoting state-sponsored education. At times he worked to keep his role as quiet as possible in order to protect his privacy and to minimize possible negativity toward the infant school stemming from his role as a polarizing figure. Yet Jefferson gladly ranked this work among his highest achievements when he instructed that Father of the University of Virginia be inscribed on his epitaph.
column2: Thomas Jefferson And The University Of Virginia: The Final Public Act Of A Private Man

column1:
Mr. Phimmasone Michael Rattanasengchanh (Ohio University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

In my presentation, I will argue that the U.S.-Thai public diplomacy programs from 1957 to 1968 helped mobilize Thai support for Washington and Bangkoks anti-communist agendas. I will illustrate both the United States Information Services (USIS) and the Thai military-monarchical governments roles in promoting anti-communism and the benefits of having America as an ally. In the first stage, I am looking at the formation of a new U.S.-Thai relationship during the years of 1957 to 1963. I argue that the perceived threat of communism helped make the two countries into stronger allies than in previous years. By 1964 and 1965, the Vietnam conflict had drawn the United States, militarily, into the region. Washington turned to Thailand as a base for U.S. air operations. My main argument for this period focuses on the USIS and Thai governments efforts to convince the people of the dangers of communism and its potentiality of growing in Thailand. U.S.-Thai public diplomacy officials portrayed Thai support for American military intervention in Vietnam as a national security necessity. Eventually in 1966, the United States requested the Thai government send a military contingency to Vietnam as part of Lyndon B. Johnsons rally around the flag campaign. The USIS and Thai military-monarchical government created public campaigns to develop support for Thailands involvement in the war. They focused on communisms incompatibility with the Thailands cultural history and its desire for economic progress. I will conclude with discussing some of the results and consequences from the anti-communist policies.
column2: U.S.-Thai Public Diplomacy In Thailand: The United States Information Services And Thai Military-Monarchical Governments Anti-Communist And Pro-Vietnam War Activities, 1957-1968

column1:
Professor Victoria W Wolcott (University at Buffalo)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

In our current historical moment comparisons to our volatile past are everywhere. But looking backward can also generate powerful models of progress and peace. In the mid-twentieth century black and white socialists seeking radical economic and social change drew from nineteenth-century utopian communities to model a new world in the present. These communities were, in a sense, a way to represent both the American past and its potential future. Pacifist communities created cooperative farms in the Deep South, urban Ashrams in the Northeast, and interracial churches on the West Coast. They promoted communal living, cooperative economics and a new form of radical pacifism that became an essential tool in the civil rights movement.Father Divine, for example, was particularly enamored with Mother Ann Lee and the Shakers. In 1936 he founded a series of rural interracial cooperatives, which he named the Promised Land, in a region of rural New York where the Shakers had begun their utopian experiment. Ashrams in Newark and Harlem in the 1940s modeled themselves after Gandhian communities, but also after early nineteenth century utopian societies such as Ephrata. And the Delta Cooperative farm in Mississippi was explicitly modeled after nineteenth-century Owenite cooperatives such as New Harmony. In these spaces activists lived communally and honed their skills in nonviolent direct action. And they provided models for a new generation of utopian thinkers who emerged decades later in the New Left.
column2: Visions Of Utopia: Modeling Social Change In Mid-Twentieth Century Pacifist Communities

column1:
Mr. Gregg Michael French (Saint Mary's University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

Partially spawned by the adult education movement, middle- and upper-class American women began forming literary travel clubs and reading circles throughout the American Northeast and the American Midwest during the last quarter of the nineteenth century. With the assistance of a variety of different sources, including The Bay View Magazine, John Lawson Stoddards lecture series, and Burton Holmess travelogue collection, these clubwomen took part in imaginary journeys, which allowed them to glide from land to land without having to leave the comfort of their own communities. Following the conclusion of the Spanish-American War of 1898 and the creation of Americas overseas empire, they began taking imaginary journeys throughout Latin America, and in turn, quickly became active participants in the U.S. colonial experience. During their journeys, American clubwomen came into contact with the regions customs, peoples, pasts, culinary traditions, major cities, as well as its industrial capabilities. Using these imaginary journeys throughout Latin America as a lens to increase our understanding of how Gilded Age and Progressive Era women perceived Americas role in global affairs during the first quarter of the twentieth century, this paper will ask how American clubwomen perceived Latin Americans? What racial and cultural similarities did they draw and what differences did they find? Perhaps most importantly, how did their evaluations of the region affect how they engaged with American empire building throughout the time period under discussion?
column2: Wards Of Uncle Sam: American Clubwomen And Their Imaginary Tours Through Latin America, 1902–1916

column1:
Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

Medical vitalism—which visiting scholars learned about at the Edinburgh Medical School beginning in the 1760s—introduced American physicians to an understanding of life that potentially challenged Christian conceptions of God. Vitalists held that a self-activating life force animated the tiniest particles of matter, causing these to produce all the bio-chemical processes of life. Some vitalists also believed that the smallest particles are made of fundamentally the same stuff, and that they eventually cycle through all the life forms in the universe. One conclusion from this cosmology of eternal matter was heretical: that no transcendent Creator-God existed. Other heresies followed: Jesus was not divine; heaven and hell were inventions. Dr. Phineas Hedges in New York State combined medical vitalism with such religious heresy. His overt disregard for Christian beliefs provoked fear and loathing in his orthodox neighbors. After Hedges and some friends engaged in a mockery of communion by offering a wafer to a dog, reports flew that the miscreants soon suffered the wrath of God. When Hedges died unexpectedly in 1799, his opponents clucked and nodded in relief. But in other ways Hedges was harder to dismiss. His vitalism also supported his conception of the American Republic as an organic whole in which all people were kin. Vitalist insights spurred generosity, Hedges maintained, and a virtuous Republic required such a radically increased benevolence. Dr. Hedges was part of a small but headstrong community of people who braided together the concepts of vitalism, virtue, and irreligion in the early Republic.
column2: Benevolence Shall Gush In Limpid Streams From The Heart: Vitalist Science, Republican Virtue, And Religious Infidelity In The 1790s.

column1:
Professor Ryan Patrick Semmes (Mississippi State University Libraries)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

In 1877, Edwards Pierrepont, American minister to Great Britain, met with Lord Derby, British minister of foreign affairs, to discuss Ulysses S. Grants upcoming visit to London. Pierrepont asked how Grant was to be received by the British elite and insisted that Grant receive the same consideration as the Ex-Chief Ruler of an Empire. Derby, noting that an ex-president had no diplomatic precedence in America, much less in Britain, observed that Once an Emperor always an Emperor. Pierrepont replied then, once a President always a President. For the first time a former American president was treated, not only as a statesman, but as a former head-of-state. This episode highlights the uniqueness of Ulysses S. Grants post-presidential career. While former presidents had traveled abroad prior to Grants trip, none sought or received the reception afforded to Grant. As his engagements with diplomatic elites grew in number, Grant found that his opinion on world matters carried weight. By the end of his trip he believed that his experiences around the world had afforded him an opportunity to help expand the United States economic reach into the burgeoning Asian markets. Grant immersed himself in the economic and political issues of the world, believing that his newfound knowledge would help him achieve a third term in the Executive Mansion. This paper will argue that Grants world tour helped to lay the groundwork for United States imperialism in Asia, strengthened his claim for a third term, and buoyed the reputation of the American presidency worldwide.
column2: More For Our Country Than For Me: The Diplomatic Mission Of Ulysses S. Grants World Tour

column1:
Dr. Vanessa May (Seton Hall University)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

In 1951, Dr. Martha May Eliot became Chief of the Childrens Bureau at sixty years old. Like all previous Bureau Chiefs, Eliot was highly educated, unmarried and, like many of her Bureau colleagues, she maintained an intimate relationship with another woman. As Chief, she worked closely with womens reform organizations. Many of those groups had been in the forefront of Progressive and New Deal reform and their members vigorously defended Childrens Bureau interests. Eliot, however, was the last chief to fit this model. Although previous chiefs handpicked their successors, when Eliot resigned in 1957, she was replaced with Katharine Oettinger, who was recruited over the objections of Eliot and voluntary womens organizations. During Oettingers tenure, the Childrens Bureau lost status and was dismantled in 1969.These setbacks, for Eliot, the Childrens Bureau, and aging women reformers, demonstrate how age, gender, and sexuality shaped the shift from Progressive and New Deal reform to Cold War liberalism. Newspapers emphasized Eliots grandmotherliness, her unattractiveness, and her childlessness, perceptions that reflected assumptions about sexuality and age. Other government welfare officials disparaged her as too aggressive in defending nostalgic ideas about public welfare. In replacing her, the Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare made motherhood a job requirement and favored Oettinger because she promised to be a team player with liberal men in government. Overall, Eliot was portrayed by colleagues and in public forums as a relic of an earlier era, an old woman with old ideas, blocking the path to modern, liberal reform.
column2: The Last Of The Dedicated Old Maids: Aging Maternalist Progressives In A Liberal Era

column1:
Mr. Jonathan Lande (Brown University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper

Following the Civil War, Frederick Douglass honored black mens military sacrifice, establishing a triumphalist narrative. In The Long List of Glory, I argue that while faithful to the historical record Douglasss trope lionized soldiers sacrifice to combat white supremacy and achieve liberation. African American intellectuals from Reconstruction through the Great War employed Douglasss framework in their histories to communicate particular political platforms; each intellectuals historical reinterpretation reflected distinct programs for attaining freedom. While accurately describing black service, I contend that by glorifying war and using battlefield sacrifice as the cornerstone of their activism these intellectuals confined the scope of emancipation.
column2: The Long List Of Glory: African American Intellectuals, Civil War History, And The Struggle For Freedom From Reconstruction To The Great War

column1:
Hannah Ayers (Field Studio)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Film Screening

AN OUTRAGE is a documentary film about lynching in the American South. Filmed on-location at lynching sites in six states and bolstered by the memories and perspectives of descendants, community activists, and scholars, this unusual historical documentary seeks to educate even as it serves as a hub for action to remember and reflect upon a long-hidden past.Thousands of African Americans confronted, resisted, endured, and perished during the era of lynching in the American South. Beginning with the end of the Civil War and continuing well into the middle of the twentieth century, this extralegal, socially-sanctioned practice of torture and murder claimed the lives of at least 3,959 African American men, women, and children. This past is little-discussed today, even as its wounds fester.
column2: An Outrage: A Documentary Film About Lynching In The American South

column1:
Dr. Vivek Bald (Massachusetts Institute of Technology)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

Rarely can historys form be disentangled from its intent. Case in point is Asian American history, which began as a project of identity, inclusion, political empowerment, and social justice during the civil unrest of the 1960s. At the time, these shared objectives produced particular forms of history. Scholars penned community studies in order to recover lost experiences, wrote U.S.-centric narratives to combat earlier exclusions, and created public history exhibits to fight for restitution. But the past half-century has witnessed the rapid growth and fracturing of the field. Widespread institutionalization has begun to separate Asian American history from its political roots. At one time the central tenets that inspired Asian American history were clear, but today this is no longer the case. Is Asian American history still driven by the particular politics of the present moment? Or is it inspired by new archives, intellectual frameworks and methodological trends? Does a belief in a shared past still hold the field together? Or does it cohere around hope for a shared future? As the inspiration and intent of Asian American history has shifted, so too has its chosen genres, venues, and audiences. This roundtable will explore the connection between what informs historians work and what forms of history they choose to produce. Panelists will include Naomi A. Paik, author of Rightlessness: Testimony and Redress in U.S. Prison Camps since World War II (2016) and, recently, co-author of a collective statement by Asian American studies scholars regarding Japanese American Internment and a proposed registry of immigrants from Muslim-majority countries. She will discuss how shared politics of liberation among differently racialized groups and intersecting axes of power informs Asian American history and its relation to comparative ethnic studies. Joining the conversation will be Genevieve Clutario, whose work focuses on diasporic Filipina nationalism and U.S. imperialism. She will speak to researching archival fragments and restructuring colonial archives through digital curation. Beth Lew-Williams, whose work focuses on Chinese migrants and anti-Chinese violence in the 19th-century U.S. West, will consider the place of family history in intellectual work. Vivek Bald will discuss his work on the South Asian diaspora as a historian and documentary filmmaker. Celebrated historian and public scholar Erika Lee will serve as chair. Most recently, she is the author of The Making of Asian America (2015), a sweeping retelling of Asian American history. Lee directs the University of Minnesotas Immigration History Research Center has written and spoken widely about the field.
column2: What Informs Asian American History Today?

column1:
Mr. Walter Forsberg (National Museum of African American History and Culture)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable discussion imaginatively engages with the conference theme of "The Forms of History" by addressing the role of sound and film conservancy as a way of preserving and teaching African American history. The panelists, all of whom are working on sound and/or film conservancy projects in African American history, will discuss their research strategies, their preservation projects, and their long-term plans to bring these vital primary sources to the general public. The panelists include: Walter Forsberg, Media Archivist at the National Museum of African American History and Culture (NMAAHC); Carleton Gholz, Founder of the Detroit Sound Conservancy; Sonja D. Williams, Media Producer and Professor of Media, Journalism, and Film at Howard University; Suzanne E. Smith, Professor of History at George Mason University; and the panel will be chaired by Josh Shepperd, Director of the Radio Preservation Task Force at the Library of Congress and Professor of Media Studies at Catholic University.In terms of their specific projects, Walter Forsberg will discuss his work restoring and archiving home movies as a part of the NMAAHC Great Migration project; Carleton Gholtz will present his work as the founder of Detroit Sound Conservancy including Vault Version 1.0, a long-term project to convert Detroits musical heritage into a digital archive; Sonja Williams will discuss her work leading Radio and Civil Rights Caucus for the Radio Preservation Task Force as well as her award-winning work on radio projects such as _Black Radio: Telling It Like It Was_ (Radio Smithsonian/PRI); Suzanne Smith will present her work preserving the radio broadcasts of Elder Lightfoot Solomon Michaux; and Josh Shepperd will discuss the mission of the Radio Preservation Task Force as it relates to African American history.
column2: Stop, Look, And Listen: Sound And Film Conservancy And African American History

column1:
Dr. Catherine Allgor (Massachusetts Historical Society--President)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

America has gone Hamilton crazy. Lin-Manuel Mirandas musical about founding father, Alexander Hamilton, has resonated with its audience and the broader American public in ways unlike any other musical in American history. Since it opened in 2015, Hamilton has become a cultural, political, and historical phenomenon. This panel will bring together historians and cultural studies scholars—all of whom are contributors to the forthcoming volume, Historians on Hamilton—to explore and help explain the Hamilton phenomenon. Hamilton is perhaps the most popular historical representation in decades and it incredible success is very clearly linked to the way in which it tells the story of nations founding with hip-hop and rap music traditions performed by a largely non-white cast. Our panelists will explore a variety of questions. They will ask how Hamilton measures up as a work of history, especially important in light of the ways that the musical is being used to teach about the founding fathers and Americas racial past. To what extent does this musical offer a historically accurate representation of the past and what are the implications of its inaccuracies, its exclusions, and its emphasis on including ethnic players who were actually marginalized and enslaved at the time? What did Lin-Manual Miranda get right, what did he get wrong, and does it matter? Panelists will also engage with Hamilton as historical representation whose popularity not only has the potential to shape the way Americans understand their past, but also has much to tell us about a contemporary political moment. Indeed, Hamilton has found fans among both liberals and conservatives. Both Republicans and Democrats have advocated using Hamilton in American history classes. The panel will explore what about the form of this particular representation has allowed it to transcend the history wars that so commonly divide left and right in the U.S. Finally, the panel will offer a space to reflect on questions about narrative form, popular culture and historical truth. There is no question that Hamilton is profoundly ahistorical. Thomas Jefferson was not a black man who engaged in rap battles with a Puerto Rican Alexander Hamilton about the need for a national bank. And yet, do those rap battles and those multiracial casting point audiences to larger historical truths and possibilities than might a more historically accurate account of the Jefferson/Hamilton debate over economic policy in the early Republic? Can historical truths be revealed through consciously ahistorical forms? To what extent is Hamilton democratizing history, both reminding us—as was written recently on an early American history blog—that history does not belong only to those who study it for a living. If this musical is indeed a peoples history, how might Hamilton affect the ongoing efforts by historians to find ways to reach audiences outside the academy? And can this show offer us lessons as historians about how to teach history and to communicate the past in ways that engage young people and bring history alive for them?
column2: What Did I Miss?: Historians Discuss Hamilton

column1:
Professor Jimmy L Bryan (Jr Lamar University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

The popularity of Western films diminished significantly in the 1970s. The national traumas of the Vietnam War, Watergate, Wounded Knee, and environmental crises, left U.S. audiences feeling disenchanted with the trite narratives and images of American exceptionalism and ethnic chauvinism that traditionally defined the genre. In the last quarter of the 20th century, film makers occasionally revisited the format with critical and popular successes like Dances with Wolves (1990) and The Unforgiven (1992), but the dearth of titles led many observers to question the genres viability. As a genre that once dominated U.S. popular culture, the Western has waned, but since 2000, producers have released a small yet persistent number of movies that exhibit the forms and conventions of that category. Within that limited group, the panelists for this session detect something evocative. When film makers choose to produce a Western in the 21st century, are they declaring their intention for social commentary, or are they simply exploiting some nostalgic impulse? Do they find resonance, or dissonance, between the old Forms of History and audiences living in a post-9/11 world, or facing genuine ecological peril, or searching for meaning in the anxious populism that culminated in the Election of 2016?The panelists will interrogate 21st-century Westerns and hope to instigate discussion about how culture makers use popular history to entertain, inform, or exploit. To what degree do films like The Revenant (2015) or the potboilers of Robert Rodriguez and Quentin Tarantino reflect 21st-century sensitivities toward violence? How well do traditional or modern Westerns like No Country for Old Men (2007) reveal the complex worlds of the Mexico-U.S. border? Do remakes like The Alamo (2004), 3:10 to Yuma (2007), or The Magnificent Seven (2016) refresh or rehash older forms? Although they will primarily focus on films produced since 2000, this group of scholars may venture into other media such as television and literature.Monica Rico, chair, (Lawrence University) will talk on Landscape, Language, Violence. Jon T. Coleman (Notre Dame) will present Dont You Forget about Me: The Twenty-First Century West in YA Film and Fiction, while George T. Díaz (University of Texas-Rio Grande Valley) will consider Badmen and Bandidos: Border Films as Wild Westerns. Jimmy L. Bryan Jr. (Lamar University) will follow with The Unfortunate Persistence of Native American Images in Twenty-first Century Westerns.
column2: 21St-Century Westerns: Old And New Forms Of Imagining History

column1:
Mr. Cornelius Moore (California Newsreel)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 11:30 to 13:00

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

Since its founding in 1968, California Newsreel has been at the forefront in producing and distributing film and video for social change. Its long list of pioneering films include but are not limited to Marlon Riggs Ethnic Notions and Tongues Untied, Raoul Peck"s Lumumba, Karen Thorsens James Baldwin: The Price of the Ticket, David Shulmans Dirt and Deeds in Mississippi, and more recently, Abby Ginzbergs and Frank Dawsons Agents of Change. The co-director of Newsreel, Cornelius Moore, will discuss several of these pioneering films, his long tenure at the company, and the role of film in enriching and complicating our understanding of the past.
column2: 50 Years Of Radical Image Making And Documenting The Past: A Conversation With Cornelius Moore Of California Newsreel

column1:
Dr. Mariona Lloret (Universitat Pompeu Fabra)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Writing in 1948, Peter Viereck, seen today as one of the architects of modern conservative philosophy, declared that conservative principles are self expression through self restraint; preservation through reform...a fruitful nostalgia for the permanent beneath the flux….These principles create freedom…[built] on the bedrock of ethics and law. At the heart of Vierecks philosophy was the firm belief that the government should commit itself to policies that uphold restraint and modesty, and if needed, it should be used to enforce these standards throughout the nation. Over the past twenty years, scholars including Dan Carter, Elizabeth Fones-Wolf, and Daniel Stedman Jones have searched for the beginnings of modern conservatism, as well as the origins of neoliberal ideologies which it produced, only to arrive at disparate conclusions. This panel examines the political philosophies of Huey Long, Theodore Bilbo, and Claude Kirk in order to provide a comprehensive analysis of the rise of conservative politics in America. These three politicians offer a unique lens through which one can more adequately understand recent international conservative referendums such as the Brexit decision and the election of Donald Trump. Examining Long, Bilbo, and Kirk challenges the traditional timeline used in much of the recent scholarship on American conservatism and sheds important light on the connective tissue between neoliberal and conservative philosophies which have come to dominate American and international political discourse over the past 20 years.Huey Long built his political tenure on campaigns grounded in populist appeals to conservative principles of state and individual rights, which Long buttressed with calls for business-minded civic progress. Utilizing racial rhetoric only sparingly, Long set the standard for conservative discourse in the pre-war period and helped define its ideology not in terms of religiosity or racism, but in terms of business-minded civic policy. Theodore Bilbo built on Longs tradition of state and individual rights, but added a violent flare of racism to Longs concept of conservatism. During his campaign for United States Senate in 1946, Bilbo used open threats to white masculinity and white identity to win election. He became the national and international standard bearer for a new conservative ethos bolstered by voters who were willing to overlook his overtly racial politics in favor of his symbolism as a fighter for free speech and individual freedoms. In the wake of the civil rights struggles of the 1960s, overt appeals to racism were no longer palatable weapons in political battles. The man who most accurately embodied the new ideology of conservatism was Florida Governor Claude Kirk. Kirk combined veiled appeals to racism with a business model approach to government, which have become the cornerstones of neoliberal and modern conservative ideology. By fusing together and tempering the ideas of Bilbo and Long, Kirk created a conservative coalition that crossed regional lines. A careful examination of these three figures allows historians to view the direct ties between pre-war conservative thought and post-war neoliberal ideology, offering a gateway through which to view larger trends in American political and social history.
column2: A New Microscope For Modern Conservatism: Huey Long, Theodore Bilbo, And Claude Kirk At The Precipice Of Political Change

column1:
Dr. Michael David Gambone (Kutztown University of Pennsylvania)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

The purpose of this roundtable will be to share experiences, challenges, and practical strategies for organizing new unions and securing strong contracts, and discussing why academic unions matter in an age of political realignment. It will feature organizers across the historical profession: tenured faculty, adjuncts, grad students; some at public universities with longstanding unions, some involved with new organizing efforts at private universities. In this roundtable, each representative will offer a short statement about what they understand the role of academic unions to be, specific recent challenges / successes within their institutions, the particular role (if any) of historians, and offer some practical organizing advice in light of the challenges we all face after the Fall 2016 election. We will open in general discussion to think together about academic union organizing in our current political moment.
column2: Academic Unions And Historians In An Age Of Political Realignment

column1:
Ms. Laurie Coyle (Adios Amor Film Project)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Film Screening

Proposal Abstract: Before Cesar Chavez and Dolores Huerta, there was Maria Moreno. Why havent we ever heard of her?In Adios Amor, the discovery of forgotten photographs prompts a search for an unsung heroine, Maria Moreno, a migrant mother who sacrificed everything but her twelve kids in the struggle for farm worker justice. In the late 1950s at the height of the Cold War, Maria Moreno stepped out of the shadows and spoke up for 3 million farm workers living in poverty while they harvested the food for the most affluent nation in the world. Elected by a group of Okie, Arkie, Black, Filipino and Mexican farm workers to represent their demands for equal rights and fair pay, Maria took her crusade all the way to the halls of power in Washington D.C. Although she was silenced and relegated to the sidelines of farm worker history, Maria Moreno left an inspiring legacy of multi-ethnic unity that is deeply resonant today.Today we would know nothing about Maria—not even her name—were it not for a group of maverick journalists and photographers who captured her story and kept her memory alive. Departing from a traditional cradle-to-grave biographical approach, Adios Amor unfolds as a search whose missing clues and dramatic twists raise provocative questions about whose lives we remember and record. Combining elements of the road movie with photography, long lost audio recordings, home movies, interviews and cinema vérité, Adios Amor restores aforgotten history and pays tribute to an intrepid woman whose fight for a better life has universal resonance.From the filmmaker:The seed for Adios Amor was planted a decade ago when I was lead researcher and associate producer for the Sundance Film Festival premiered documentary, The Fight in the Fields: Cesar Chavez and the Farmworkers Struggle. Looking for photographs of Cesar Chavez, I discovered a stash of hundreds of photographs of an unknown woman activist gesturing passionately, speaking her mind. Who was Maria Moreno, this woman in the world? Migrant farm workers leftfew accounts of their lives and struggles, especially in the late 50s at the close of the McCarthy era. I had uncovered buried treasure, a vivid imprint, a historical record pressed between subterranean layers of poverty, silence, loss. After working on several documentaries about illustrious men, I returned to the elusive photographs to search for Maria Moreno, and that questis the story of Adios Amor.After screening Adios Amor, filmmaker Laurie Coyle and historian advisors Vicki Ruiz and Devra Weber will engage viewers in a conversation about how the film challenges conventional histories of the farm worker movement
column2: Adios Amor—The Search For Maria Moreno

column1:
Frank Dawson (Santa Monica College)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Film Screening

From the well-publicized events at San Francisco State in 1968 to the image of black students with guns emerging from the takeover of the student union at Cornell University in April, 1969, the struggle for a more relevant and meaningful education, including demands for black and ethnic studies programs, became a clarion call across the country in the late 1960"s. Through the stories of these young men and women who were at the forefront of these efforts, Agents of Change examines the untold story of the racial conditions on college campuses and in the country that led to these protests. The films characters were caught at the crossroads of the civil rights, black power, and anti-Vietnam war movements at a pivotal time in Americas history. Today, over 45 years later, many of the same demands are surfacing in campus protests across the country, revealing how much work remains to be done.Agents of Change links the past to the present and the present to the past--making it not just a movie but a movement.
column2: Agents Of Change

column1:
Dr. Nathan Cardon (University of Birmingham)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Americans Abroad: Reconsidering the Foreign and Domestic Across the Long 20th Century brings together three early-career historians to think through the ways the foreign and domestic are not oppositional categories but are constructed through a mutually constitutive dialogue. As American state and non-state actors criss-crossed the globe and traversed national and imperial borders across the long twentieth century they brought with them their own conceptualizations of the United States and returned with new understandings of the world. While the borders themselves were very real requiring visas, passports, and other apparatuses of the nation-state, they were simultaneously conceptually fluid. Within a complex web of transnational and trans-imperial circuits Americans interpreted and constructed new understandings of the United States place in the world. At times this supported an imperial imposition of American power according to the matrices and intersections of race, class, and gender. At other times American state and non-state actors contested these very same definitions and avenues of power. Americans Abroad contributes to a growing dialogue that understands and conceives of the United States in the world through ordinary decisions and everyday material practices: from bridge construction in the Nile Valley to bicycle circumnavigations to late-twentieth century Peace Corps workers. Americans abroad translated and merged the foreign and domestic creating new avenues to understand their nations place in an increasingly connected world.Each of the papers in this session explores a different set of American state or non-state actors to think of the ways the foreign and domestic were constitutive of each other across the twentieth century. Nathan Cardons paper, In Dwarf Land and Cannibal Country: Race, Empire, and Bicycle Circumnavigations, explores the ways imperial ideas travelled with the bicycle and carried interpretative weight as white adventurers encountered colonized peoples at home and abroad. Sarah Miller-Davenports paper, Seeing Culture Everywhere: Peace Corps Service and the Challenge of Diversity at Home, uncovers the foreign policy roots of liberal multiculturalism in the U.S. by exploring the impact of returned Peace Corps volunteers on American schools and workplaces in the late 20th century. Lastly, Stephen Tufnells paper, Engineering the Scramble for Africa: American Engineers and Histories of the United States in the World, focuses on bridge-building projects in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan and in the British East Africa Protectorate to propose a framework of global connectivity defined by inter-imperial interaction as one solution to navigating the tensions between imperial and global history.
column2: Americans Abroad: Reconsidering The Foreign And Domestic Across The Long 20th Century

column1:
Michael Burton (University of Nebraska Lincoln)

Date: 2017-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Doing History Workshop

The Animating History workshop will bring together animation industry experts in various areas of story development and production and American historians to conduct a storyboarding session. Industry participants include directors, producers, writers, animators, art department staff, sound, story board, and effects areas alike. We will consider how and why historians might participate in producing high quality animated histories for wide audiences. First, working in teams as a design studio, we will develop a draft animation based on a selected historical event or person. Participants in the workshop will rapidly develop a storyboard and script introducing historians to the world of animation production. Participants will receive a packet on a specific event and will have some time to develop their ideas before coming to work with our industry professionals. After collaborating on these sketches, we will hold a final discussion on how a story is developed for film, television, and the web, and what design principles historians should consider in producing an animation.
column2: Animating History

column1:
Dr. Heather A Huyck (National Collaborative for Women's History Sites)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

Historians must work with communities to collect evidence of the past from people of all ethnic, socio-economic and gendered groups to ensure its preservation and accessibility. Evident in the conjoining of political and civic activism, historians have a clear responsibility to both present and past. Public historians are uniquely positioned to effect change in todays social confusion. Through public programming, exhibitions, and the collecting and making available the works and words of often marginalized people; we can foster environments of greater understanding-- and societal change. The four panelists have worked in museums, archives, and historic sites demonstrate the versatility of public historians and our ability to reach both within and outside of traditional education models. A multiracial dialogue has resulted from the community processing documents from Black Woman activist, Maggie L. Walker. By offering a physical space for students and visitors to learn of past civic engagements and to process and express frustrations with current injustices, the Schlesinger Library and the National Civil Rights Museum at the Lorraine Motel have prompted activists and traditional teachers to take action. Curators at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum inform the public and educational systems how we have come to define ourselves as we do, and who is important (or not) in the American narrative. This cross-generational, cross-racial panel discusses ways history professionals should construct history with others.
column2: Arming Citizens: Public Historians And Civic Engagement

column1:
Benjamin Balthaser (Indiana University-South Bend)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel explores the transnational intersections and radical solidarities of long Popular Front. It examines how Popular Front articulations of anti-racist, feminist, labor and anti-imperialist struggle emerged from and created axes of solidarity. Taking the long view of the fluorescence of radicalism during the 1930s, the panel reframes temporal and spatial trajectories of radical political and artistic activity in the twentieth and into the twenty-first centuries. Interdisciplinary consideration of the artistic work of Elizabeth Catlett and Mike Gold, along with movements such as the International Workers Order and the American Committee for the Protection of the Foreign Born maps arcs of radical persistence and revision. Resistance migrates across space and time, carrying political valences that took different shapes in new contexts.
column2: Axes Of Solidarity In The Long Popular Front

column1:
Professor Deborah Cohen ()

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel invites historical practitioners—academic and independent researchers, teachers, policy makers, museum professions, and activists—into conversation about ways that scholarship on mid-twentieth century Mexican American belonging and exclusion can inform policy and activism on immigration in the current political climate. The panel examines various discourses in the mid twentieth century —medico-psychological, political, economic, and emotional—that constructed the historical experiences of Mexican Americans to sometimes stretch the terms of national inclusion and other times to position newcomers as outsiders or contingent members of the U.S. polity. In recognition of conference priorities, panelists seek to expand understanding of forms of history, as they explore ways discourses in ethnic communities, the medical and social sciences, and political and activist organizations functioned to construct a past, sometimes a past that never was, sometimes a past that pointed to an emancipatory future.Deborah Cohens paper, Migrant Psychosis, examines one medico-psychological diagnosis, migrant psychosis, applied to newcomers of color, largely temporary agricultural laborers. This formal diagnosis arising in the mid-decades of the 20th century made homesickness a disease in ways that contributed to a continued racialization of migrant labor. Ruben Flores complements Cohens paper by looking at the psychological discomfort that migrants felt as they moved from Mexico to the U.S. and were positioned as outsiders to the U.S. political project, even though they labored in sectors well integrated into the U.S. economy. Migrants experiences speak not just of feelings of discrimination and exclusion, but also to the medicalization of those feelings. Laura Westhoff explores the work of Fred Ross and the Community Service Organization (CSO) to build Mexican American activism and expand the boundaries of the inclusion in the political project of pluralist liberal democracy. Her paper illustrates the ways that common themes in U.S. historical narratives--military sacrifice, producerism, anti-communist patriotism—signaled CSO investment in particular discursive strategies that bolstered the existing liberal political project of the mid-twentieth century, while limiting its leaders from imagining and forging alliances that challenged state structures. Together, the panelists works considers how such discourses served as evidence for further discrimination, as a mode of capitulation to overarching political ideology, or as a model of emancipatory historical practice. Examining such discourses, it thus asks how constructing new forms of history might serve as a form of activism and how activism has been and continues to be a form of historical practice. Exploring discourses about those whose claims to membership in the body politic were a priori questioned, each panelist raises questions about where and how history is constituted in forms and spaces outside of its traditional academic definitions and boundaries. Today, as in the past, history in various configurations serves to foster belonging or contingency. Independent scholar and journalist Miriam Pawel will draw out these concerns, suggest the contemporary possibilities that historys various forms offer current activists and their organizing strategies, and frame conversation with the audience.
column2: Belonging And Structures Of Contingency:  What Scholarship Offers Contemporary Activists

column1:
Ms. Micki Kaufman (CUNY Graduate Center)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

For nearly half a century, Henry Kissinger has been one of the most polarizing figures in American politics. In the recent election campaign, Bernie Sanders denounced him; Hillary Clinton embraced him. In surveys political scientists rate him as the most effective Secretary of State in the 20th century, but when he attends public events he is met with protesters who vilify him as a war criminal. In two prominent recent books about him, Niall Ferguson and Greg Grandin offer radically different views: Ferguson portrays Kissinger as an "idealist" (at least before he took office) and a brilliant thinker; Grandin sees him as a uniquely pernicious influence on U.S. foreign policy. There seems to be no limit to the market for studies of Kissinger, but the vast historiography often seems trapped in a stale debate about whether Kissinger should be judged a great statesman or an evil mastermind.This panel moves beyond the predominant moralistic approach to assessing Kissinger"s diplomacy. Drawing on newly declassified documents and on new approaches to international history, the panelists offer new frameworks for studying Kissinger and suggest ways to move the debate to new terrain. Micki Kaufman will describe Kissinger as revealed through the use of computational methods such as text, data, and network analysis, in a distant reading of the National Security Archives Kissinger Collection. Combining data findings with the aesthetics of data visualization, Kaufman will detail a new, digital interpretation of Kissingers complex relationships and policies, as well as insight into his behavior and personality, as revealed in the provenance and content of his correspondence. Daniel Sargent will discuss Kissingers efforts to engage with novel challenges that the advance of globalization spawned. In the mid-1970s, he will explain, Kissinger worked to reorient foreign policy towards the challenges of an emerging post-Cold War world, even as he struggled to preserve the achievements of superpower détente. Barbara Keys will take a longer view of Kissingers career, discussing, among other issues: why no one has done a full account of Kissingers career out of office, the challenges of getting information about the activities of Kissingers consulting firm, and the conflicts of interest between his post-tenure careers as a media expert on foreign relations and as a consultant for foreign governments. She will examine several episodes from his decades as an advocate for the Peoples Republic of China to suggest how emotional analysis can inform our understanding of Kissingers policy advocacy. Tom Schwartz will chair and moderate.
column2: Beyond Good And Evil: New Ways Of Thinking About Henry Kissinger

column1:
Professor Christy Clark-Pujara (University of Wisconsin-Madison)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This paper session brings together three scholars to discuss three different cases of race and place in the northern United States over time, one in Rhode Island during the early Republic, one in Wisconsin in the mid-nineteenth century, and one in Minnesota during the early twentieth century. Taken together, the cases directly address the 2018 Meetings goal of fostering conversation about how (and why) we represent the past in particular by contributing to ongoing efforts at dismantling northern racial exceptionalism as an historical interpretation and as a modern-day assumption. Likewise, they indicate how much there is still to do to uncover the history of racism in the American North, from the nations beginning to the present time.In order to more fully engage the session audience, each of the presenters also plans to address their particular topic through a guided examination of selected primary sources rather doing a traditional paper reading. This will include a whole range of records, documents, and images, some of which we will distribute before the session begins and some of which we will display on PowerPoint slides. An interactive, source-centered format will also necessarily bring up observations, questions, and comments about how we came to our individual topics, how we are doing our research, what we think it means for understanding race in the past, and how we see it illuminating conversations about race today..
column2: Beyond Northern Exceptionalism

column1:
Professor Miroslava Chávez-García (UC, Santa Barbara)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable brings together five scholars who are committed to presenting cutting edge research within their respective fields to non-academics. As experts in disability history, indigenous history, and Chicana/o history, they hope to deepen and broaden the publics understanding of the American past by offering sweeping interpretative histories that challenge more familiar narratives. In pursuit of this goal, they individually have contributed to museum exhibitions, offered public lectures, and written surveys aimed at the widest possible audience.Most history departments and historians value research-rich monographs that focus on specialized and often narrow topics. So do the panelists. Yet rarely do monographs reach an audience that extends beyond professional peers and students as well as family members. The roundtable thus starts with the proposition that, by remaining largely outside the public domain, historians miss an opportunity at making a significant impact on the ways in which is history is recorded, interpreted, and disseminated as well as how it is consumed, understood, and weighed. We recoup the term interpretative history to describe our collective efforts of culling, sorting, and reinterpreting a broad sweep of history. Others might use the word synthetic or characterize (or disparage) any interpretative history as a textbook. Whatever the term, the challenge for us is how to weave what have been mostly marginalized histories within an overarching national history.The roundtable will address such questions as: How do we, as historians, engage a broader public? And what sectors of that public comprise our most likely audience? Given that we seek to appeal to non-experts, how do we strike a balance between the mainstream and the margin? For example, in their forthcoming book, A Chicana & Chicano History of the United States (Beacon Press), Miroslava Chávez García and Lorena Oropeza argue that Chicana/o history is American history. At the same time, the authors do not wish to convey the impression to a general audience that Chicana/o history matters only because it adds a layer of complexity to already familiar topics from settler colonialism to immigration. For her award-winning book in the same series, An Indigenous Peoples History of the United States, Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz chose to abandon standard periodization so that she could decolonize the past.Roundtable participants will examine the challenges, rewards, pitfalls and opportunities of doing interpretative history by discussing their projects and experiences. Along with Chávez-García, Oropeza, and Dunbar-Ortiz, the roundtable includes Catherine Kudlick and Kim E. Neilsen. Kudlick, a scholar of France and director of Paul K. Longmore Institute on Disability at San Francisco State University, played a critical role in curating the exhibit, Patient No More! The exhibit focuses upon an occupation of a federal building in San Francisco by disabled folks in 1977 and places it within the context of that eras social protest. Neilsen is author of A Disability History of the United States, which in one short volume examines disability history from pre-contact to the present. In 2010, the OAH recognized Neilsens talents as a communicator by appointing her a Distinguished Lecturer.
column2: Beyond The Monograph, Beyond The Margins: The Challenge Of Interpretative And Inclusive Histories

column1:
Dr. Lauren Araiza (Denison University)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

What makes a coalition? What unmakes it? How have activists, organizers, and everyday men and women forged community and imagined commonalities, often in unlikely circumstances? Papers in this session will explore answers to these questions, building on recent historiographical discussions of late twentieth-century activism and politics in the United States. Taking cues from scholarship that has explored black-brown civil rights and seen identity politics and coalitions as mutually reinforcing, such as the 2011 edited collection, The Struggle in Black and Brown, panelists will discuss the careful, pragmatic, and divisive processes of alliance-making. Highlighting alliances made in urban and rural California, panelists will examine common goals, strategies, and ideologies – and the limits of these commonalities. From Third World alliances in the Bay Area, as Aaron Bae discusses, to the common ground of health care, explored in Rebecca Bairds study of the LA Free Clinic, radical ideology and pragmatic goals have paved the way for cross-racial and cross-class coalitions. At the same time, rhetoric and strategy have hindered alliances, dividing farmworker communities in the Coachella Valley, as Christian Paiz argues, and enabling corporate victory over a gay-labor-Latinx alliance of boycotters, the focus of Allyson Brantleys paper. This panel will offer multiple perspectives on alliance-making, opening up a wider conversation on the possibilities and pitfalls of grassroots activism in the past and present. Panelists will also consider the ways in which these histories can be made legible to activists, organizers, and leaders today, whether as inspiration or warning.
column2: Bridging Race, Ideology, And Strategy: Coalitions From The Long 1960s To The Reagan Years

column1:
Jon Amakawa (Studio Amakawa and Fitchburg State University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Doing History Workshop

In 2016, Lincoln Home NHS staff, working with the Organization of American Historians and Jon Amakawa of Studio Amakawa, completed an AR app for the Jameson Jenkins Lot. Utilizing information from historic documents and the archeological excavations, Mr. Amakawa developed programing that helps visitors visualize how the now empty lot historically looked. A variety of time periods and vignettes of Jenkins life are represented to the visitors through the augmented reality app and their mobile devices. The visitor first downloads the free app from the iTunes or Google Play stores and then aims their device at a target sign at the lot. When they have done this, their device screen fills with a visual representation of how the lot appeared. Visitors also experience the sounds of the time period, chickens, horses, etc., and they receive an audio and text narration of what they are looking at. The time periods represented are 1844, when Jenkins arrives; 1854, the time by which the Jenkins related structures were built; 1860, when Lincoln was elected president; 1865, when Lincoln was assassinated; 1884, when the Jenkins family had moved and their home was replaced; and, 1978, the year the National Park Service acquired the lot.
column2: Bringing History Back To Life—Augmented Reality At Historic Sites

column1:
Professor Albert M Camarillo (Stanford University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

In 2014 the California Historical Society (CHS), with support from Stanford University, launched the first-ever bilingual historical exhibition in California focusing on a Latina. Juana Briones y su California – Pionera, Fundadora, Curandera (Juana Briones and her California – Pioneer, Founder, and Folk Healer) brought to the California public the story of the life and times of Juana Briones (1802–1889), a pivotal historical figure whose life was part of the transformation of California under three flags: Spain, Mexico, and the United States. The exhibition was an offshoot of an initiative by Palo Alto area local citizens over several years to help save the historic Briones farm home from destruction to make way for a multi-million house in the Palo Alto foothills. Over time, this initiative morphed into an extensive historical recovery project, a senior honors thesis written by a student in the Public History major at Stanford University, and, finally, a major public exhibition developed by the California Historical Society in partnership with Stanford University. The panel will recount the process of conceptualizing and mounting the Juana Briones exhibition. Albert Camarillo will chair the panel and provide the historical contexts regarding the efforts to save the Briones home; he will describe the early stages of a public history initiative and working in collaboration as guest curator with the CHS staff to develop the exhibition. Maritza Urquiza (BA 2013) will discuss how in her senior honors thesis in the Public History major in the Department of History at Stanford she developed the public history presentation framework for the exhibition that was opened by the CHS in January 2014. Dr. Anthea Hartig will provide the view of the CHS and how an extensive primary research recovery process allowed the CHS to exhibit a rich array of documents, artifacts, and a wall rescued from the Briones home before its demolition. Thousands of Californians viewed the exhibition on site in 2014, later through a traveling exhibition in Sacramento, and by accessing the CHSs website about the exhibition.Using a multi-media presentation, the panelists will show slides from the exhibition of paintings, maps, portraits, legal documents, and artifacts in telling how Juana Briones was a woman adaptable to changing times yet undaunted in her pursuits to carve out a life for herself, her children, and community of which she was a part in nineteenth century California.
column2: Bringing Latina History To The Public: The Juana Briones Exhibition And The California Historical Society

column1:
Dr. Amy Essington (California State University, Fullerton)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Historians of the twentieth century are well aware of the impact individuals can have on broader institutions in large part because of sports and the example of Jackie Robinson and Branch Rickey integrating professional baseball in the 1940s. Yet outside of well-worn flashpoints the connections between individuals and institutions is often obscured in studies of the broader development of American sports. This panel will borrow from recent historiographical developments that place institutional and personal perspectives alongside one another in examining the development of American culture. The relationship between these perspectives is particularly important in athletics, as Americans experienced sports not just in owners shiny new stadiums or in the sports-centered newspaper sections, but also as individuals participating in sports on their own terms. Sports in the early twentieth century had powerful backers who understood the potential of athletics and debated whether they should promote amateurism and idealism of American masculinity or embrace a professionalized industry profiting from a nation bent on mass consumer culture. Individual participants and spectators intervened in these debates both in print and with their consumption choices, using their love of sports to shape American sports culture. Giving institutions such as the Presidency and the Army a prominent role, this panel underscores the reality that sports has always been deeply connected to powerful interests. Bringing the individual athlete and spectator closer to the center of analysis, this panel also hopes to highlight experiences across racial, class, and gender barriers, important perspectives that demonstrate a mass public is made up of many unique Americans who engage with sports because of their own interests. This panel will present material from scholars examining sources on the institutional and personal levels to illustrate how both shaped the development of collegiate and professional sports. By examining and discussing these perspectives jointly, historians can demonstrate the complex give and take between institutional structure and personal agency that built American society over the past century.
column2: Building And Rebuilding Sports:  Institutions, Individuals, And American Athletics In The Early 20th Century

column1:
Dr. Waldo Emerson Martin (Jr. University of California, Berkeley)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 16:45 to 18:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Plenary Session

From the gold rush and the sectional crisis to railroad building, Chinese exclusion, Japanese internment, immigration, the Free Speech Movement, and the rise of the modern Republican Party, California has both served as a beacon for the nation"s highest aspirations and a bellwether for its political, social, cultural, and economic changes. Three eminent historians will grapple with the historical forces that have shaped the relationship between California and the nation. They will examine not only how the state and the nation have responded to one another over time but also how their contested history has in turn shaped the choices we face today.
column2: California And The Nation--Past, Present, And Future

column1:
Professor William John Bauer (University of Nevada, Las Vegas)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This round table panel will explore the historiography and current trends in the field of California Indian history. Scholars will showcase new scholarship, methodologies, and theories that inform this exciting field of Native history. Conversations on this round table by leading historians will explore a host of key topics ranging from the nineteenth to twentieth century. Such topics include gender, race, genocide, war, survivance, labor, and urban history.
column2: California Indian History

column1:
Dr. Cathy Gorn (National History Day)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

Do you have middle or high school students contacting you to ask for interviews for National History Day (NHD) projects? Have you been asked to send a student everything you know about a particular topic in history? Are you curious to learn more about NHD? We invite you to join our panel in a discussion of how to help students understand the historical research process. We want to provide a forum to share your experiences and strategies with NHD students, discuss the appropriate (and inappropriate) use of interviews in the historical process, and strategies on how to deal with students who reach out to you with requests.
column2: Can You Tell Me Everything You Know About My Topic?

column1:
Dr. Matthew Cressler (College of Charleston)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Catholicism has been particularly understudied in mainstream American history. Nonreligious historians have tended to overlook lived religion, and Catholic historians have adopted a parochial habit of writing largely for one another. This panel seeks to highlight and remedy these historiographical blind spots through case studies that intertwine Catholic history with modern American social and political histories during the urban crisis. Scholars cannot fully understand the lived history of this period of significant transformation without reference to Catholics, who stood at the vanguard of efforts to resist desegregation. Additionally, historians also cannot fully explain the impact of the economic and social restructuring of the city without considering how these forces reshaped institutions, and especially – as the largest private institution in Northern cities – the Catholic Church. In illustrating the dual role of Catholicism as (1) a religious practice that interacted with American political culture and (2) an urban institution that mediated social movements, we will explore the ways Catholicism governed and defined the contours of the urban crisis, a period in which Catholicism and the Church were indelibly altered and fractured by the politics of race. The Black Freedom Movement, combined with the liberalizing reforms of the Second Vatican Council, pushed the Church and its parishioners in conflicting directions. As black Catholics and liberal priests used their parishes as spaces to engage in black community building and the politics of Black Power, white working-class Catholics shifted toward the nascent conservative movement. Yet all ostensibly adhered to the same doctrinal beliefs. How can we explain this divergence, and how can it refine our understanding of the politics of the urban crisis?Each presenter in this panel takes up the question of how the religiosity of Catholic parishioners interacted with their lived experiences during the turbulent period of the 1960s and early 1970s, and how, in turn, these factors shaped their political identities and the character of their church. Matthew Cresslers paper examines the urban crisis through the lens of Catholic schools, demonstrating that investment in parochial schools shifted from city to suburb and, in effect, eliminated educational opportunities for black children. Matthew Pehl provides a portrait of working-class white Catholics in a labor history of urban police departments. His paper shows that racially charged fears about rising crime rates in American cities created rifts between traditional parishioners and liberal priests, and explores how Catholic police chaplains attempted to bridge the gap. Cassie Millers paper demonstrates that the Churchs increasing rhetorical and material support of anti-poverty initiatives in black and Puerto Rican neighborhoods frustrated white urban parishioners, and contributed to a more general sense of dispossession that led working-class whites to embrace conservatism. Through this panel, we hope to raise questions about the relationship between religion, race, and politics, and, more broadly, to demonstrate that religious identity and religious institutions are subjects valuable to historical inquiry.
column2: Catholics And The Urban Crisis: Religion, Politics, And Race In Northern Cities

column1:
Dr. Sharla M Fett (Occidental College)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable will focus on how chairs can be academic leaders and we will explore the opportunities inherent in serving as an academic leader. How should chairs approach the role? How might faculty partner with the chair to build collegiality and foster achievements department-wide? Panelists include current and newly appointed department chairs from a wide range of institutional settings--public and private, large research universities and small liberal arts colleges, midsize universities and community colleges. The emphasis will be on practical efforts, including models for how to undertake curricular change, meet enrollment changes strategically, and mentor faculty at all stages of careers. Discussion topics include building resources, communicating with all constituencies, balancing departmental needs, involving alumni, partnering with other units and colleges, and raising the visibility of history inside and outside the university. We welcome all who are interested in academic leadership to join our discussion.
column2: Chairing A History Department

column1:
Dr. Linda Eisenmann (Wheaton College, MA)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30
