Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

In this session historians employ gender analysis to explore womens responses to intraracial sexism in higher education, gender and heterosexual norms in vocational and adult education, and the history of consent in heterosexual relations on university campuses. Linda Perkins will discuss Pauli Murrays concept of Jane Crow, stemming from Murrays experiences at Howard University Law School. JoeAnn Nguyen will examine the agenda for vocational and adult education at the Gila River Internment Camp in Arizona, designed to prepare Japanese American women and men for employment in post-camp life. Kelly Sartorius will argue that questions of consent and their correlations with sexual assault have a much longer history in higher education than commonly noted.
column2: Challenging Patriarchy In Education.

column1:
Dr. Brian Craig Miller (Mission College)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Norwegian artist Ole Peter Hansons painting, Grant and His Generals, offers a contemporary interpretation, indeed a form of history, of the Union high command. General Ulysses S. Grant commands the focus of the painting, surrounded by twenty-six subordinates, including Generals George Gordon Meade and Joseph Hooker. In the years following Appomattox, however, the commanders and soldiers responsible for Union victory slowly moved into the shadows of American culture, as the Lost Cause narrative began to take hold. This narrative, which championed southern soldiers and generals, came to dominate American culture and memory. This panel seeks to shift the historical conversation from the Lost Cause troupe and highlight the place of Union generals in the postwar dialogue. The Organization of American Historians conference theme, The Forms of History, offers a fitting opportunity to examine three Union generals, Ulysses S. Grant, Joseph Hooker, and George Meade, and their role in facilitating the conversation on the Civil War.Brooks Simpson explores the ways in which Grant actively shaped the postwar narrative through his personal and private writings. Simpson argues that Grants contribution to the postwar dialogue came from more than his acclaimed Personal Memoirs. Instead, Simpson reveals a Grant who was actively engaged in postwar correspondence, shaping the ways in which Americans remembered the Union victory, and staunchly defended his wartime record. For many Americans, and certainly for Hanson, Grant stood at the center of Union success, while other generals toiled in his shadows. Although George Gordon Meade commanded the Army of the Potomac longer than any other general, Meade never reached the enduring fame of his contemporaries, namely Grant and William T. Sherman. Jennifer Murray explores the legacy of George Meade and his place in the Civil War canon. While Meade has nearly faded into obscurity in todays Civil War dialogue, Murray contends that among his contemporary and early 20th century Americans, Meade achieved a prominent place in the historical narrative. She explores Meades place in American memory through two forms of history, the written narrative and the commemorative landscape. In doing so, Murray reveals a commemorative tradition that sought to place Meade as an integral figure in Union victory and American history. The final paper explores the Civil War career and postwar narrative of a similarly lesser-known Union general. General Hookers place in the historical narrative often centers on the failed campaign at Chancellorsville (May 1863) and his volatile relations with President Abraham Lincoln, his commander-in-chief. Ethan Rafuse offers an assessment of wartime civil-military relations in his exploration of the dynamic between Lincoln and Hooker. Rafuse examines the ways in which this relationship has been portrayed in history, focusing on how particular characteristics of each of these men have been amplified in the historical dialogue and by subsequent generations of historians. Collectively these three papers offer a lens to reevaluate three of the Civil Wars most influential commanders and underscore the means in which their historical legacies have been a malleable form of history.
column2: Civil War Union Generals In War & Memory

column1:
Dr. Amanda Boczar (University of South Florida)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

An old World War II saying went something like this: if the army wanted you to have a wife, it would have issued you one. The statement, while humorous, reflected the reality that service members faced considerable difficulty in combining family life with military service. Military officials assigned personnel without much regard for family needs, often forcing families to struggle through long deployments, to move to new assignments on short notice, and to adapt to new schools and communities on a regular basis. These circumstances placed much of the burden on wives and children who were expected to bear the burdens of service cheerfully so as not to impede their husbands and fathers career. Service women faced even higher hurdles. Until the Vietnam War era, policies forbid women from having children and discriminated against their husbands. By the turn of the twenty-first century, however, military family policies had undergone a sea change. Military families were no longer uncommon and, indeed, wielded great influence over military culture and policies. In 2014, 55 percent of active duty personnel were married, while 42 percent of active and reserve personnel were parents. This panel examines how and why this transition occurred and argues that military families have played significant—if under-examined—roles in shaping military culture and foreign policy. The panel will begin with Michael Timonins research on military wives efforts to speed the demobilization process at the close of World War II. As his paper will suggest, military wives employed a language of domesticity and maternal care as they lobbied Congress and military officials to return their husbands so they could assume their roles as breadwinners and providers. This gendered language, while conventional in many respects, offered women a new role in shaping military and foreign policy. However troublesome military officials might have considered the wives examined in Timonins work, within a few years they began to rely on military wives to project a positive image of American culture during the tumultuous Cold War. Amanda Boczar will describe the development of a family-friendly culture within the army, while paying close attention to the ways policies varied by race, class, rank, and location. The development of a family-friendly military necessitated a host of policy and cultural changes, as Kara Dixon Vuics research on military welfare programs will demonstrate. Morale and recreation programs ballooned in the late twentieth and early twenty-first centuries to provide a wealth of new programming designed to ease the separation of spouses and of parents and children, especially during wartime deployments. Together, the papers draw connections between military, social, womens, gender, and diplomatic history. Maria Hӧhn, whose seminal work on American military personnel in Germany provided a model for historians study of the social, cultural, and diplomatic functions of military families, will chair and comment. The panelists are committed to facilitating greater audience participation and questions than is normally afforded and will therefore limit their remarks to ten minutes. After brief commentary, the panel will open to audience discussion.
column2: Cod Liver Oil, Model Families, And Sesame Street: Creating Military Families In The Twentieth Century

column1:
Professor Sharon Block (University of CA, Irvine)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This session explores the discourses of captivity and coercion that antebellum northerners elaborated as they grappled with transformations in the organization of gendered labor, new opportunities for female mobility, and womens active pursuit of sexual autonomy. Between 1820 and 1860, growing numbers of women moved across regions and through cities, joined religious sects and reform movements, and treated prostitution as equivalent to other forms of waged labor. Their actions threatened to weaken bedrock American institutions, such as marriage and slavery, which controlled their sexual and reproductive lives while also extracting their labor. Capitalization, urban migration, and religious ferment offered chances to pursue limited forms of independence from these institutions—and hundreds of thousands of women risked very real dangers of violence in taking those chances. Yet, as these three papers will argue, the discourses of captivity that emerged in this period obscured much of the systemic violence women already faced and some even produced new opportunities for exploitation. All three papers show that framing sex (especially for the youthful) as coercion or captivity served to obfuscate the ways that some young women were making sexual choices on their own, albeit constrained, terms. In antebellum America imagining sex as captivity also carried powerful connotations of slavery, slowing gaining traction as the institution against which Northerners sought to define their way of life. Kara Frenchs paper focuses on anti-Shaker and Catholic tracts that depicted celibate women as coerced into their roles, rather than having made choices to eschew sex for religious devotion. French highlights the ways that these narratives of captivity and coercion served as a distraction from the challenge to traditional femininity posed by celibacy. April Haynes, by contrast, looks at efforts to redirect racially diverse working-class girls away from prostitution and toward the ostensibly free labor of domestic service. By representing sex work as a form of slavery, reformers built a coercive regime of waged household labor with long-term consequences for the racialized and gendered sector of care work. Finally, Nicholas Syrett examines accusations of kidnapping and infanticide lodged at Madame Restell, New Yorks notorious abortionist, arguing that focusing on the exploitation and harm of live children served as a proxy for new understandings of abortion as child murder that emerged with the rise of a protected, middle class childhood. They were also a way for anxious citizens to condemn abortionists who eradicated the consequences of young womens sinful pasts, thus intervening between daughters and their rightful protectors and masters: their parents. All three scholars write history in its traditional form, but all are also reading against the grain of sources that envision women and girls as always already sexually exploited. We are fortunate to have historians Janet Farrell Brodie and Sharon Block as chair and commentator, respectively, two historians whose work on sexuality in early America has been foundational to these conversations about coercion, commodification, and captivity.
column2: Coercion, Kidnapping, And Commodification: Discourses Of Sexuality And Exploitation In The Antebellum North

column1:
Dr. Megan Elizabeth Birk (University of Texas Rio Grande Valley)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel will examine the intersection of family, community and authority in the American Midwest in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Each of these papers discusses the many ways in which problems within families and communities complicated the power relationships between those families and communities and the larger state. In many Midwestern communities, poor farms were the last line of defense of indigent women whose families could not, or would not, help them in times of trouble. These institutions were the way in which communities provided a minimal standard of living and a safety net for women without alternatives. This panel will also examine the issue of ethnicity, and the way in which Mexican Americans worked to create their own communities in the midst of the regions dominant European ethnic population. Crisis is at the center of the third paper, and the ways in which the state, this time Iowa, did not adequately deal with the problems of indigent families during the Great Depression. The final paper will tackle the problem of child saving, and the way in which child saving for Native American children was both similar and different for that for European American children. Late nineteenth and early twentieth century America was slow to confront the problems of poverty and family dysfunction, and the American Midwest was no exception.
column2: Community, Family, And Authority In The American Midwest

column1:
Professor Edward L. Ayers ()

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 20:00 to 21:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Plenary Session

What are the roles and responsibilities of historians after Charlottesville? After Charleston? After Ferguson? Recent events tragically underscore the need for a revitalized democratic citizenry to address and redress our nations enduring wounds of racial, social, and political inequity. Professional scholars long have shaped and influenced the language and concepts through which we think about the past and, thus, imagine our individual and collective futures. The violence surrounding the removal of Confederate monuments suggests that we are not merely fighting old battles over the presence and interpretation of a contested past, but also struggling to envision, articulate and realize new accounts of democratic relationships in an environment of unprecedented social heterogeneity. How can and will historians catalyze and join constructive conversations about our past in the midst of deep partisan divides, confirmation bias, and resurgent racism? Join OAH President Ed Ayers and in a town-hall style conversation about how historians participating in the debates over Confederate monuments and other divisive representations of the past can contribute to a firm foundation for trust in our shared future.
column2: Confederate Monuments: What To Do?

column1:
Andreas Fickers (Luxembourg Centre for Contemporary and Digital History)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

The emergence of digital history and its related practices raise fundamental epistemological questions about the sources that underpin historical analysis and interpretation, and how historians know what they know. This NARA-sponsored roundtable discussion asks: What are the consequences of digital technologies for the study of history and the production of historical knowledge? Does the production and distribution of knowledge change under digital conditions? In what ways is the Age of Text Search altering or extending the theoretical approaches that have informed and shaped the writing of history and the training of historians? How are expectations about validity and scope altered by digital technologies? What sorts of conversations, training, and studies will be necessary to spur critical thinking about digital discovery, methods, and prevailing theories of knowledge?
column2: Consequences Of Digital Technologies For History: A Roundtable Discussion On The Digital Future Of The Historians Craft

column1:
Professor Brian DeLay (UC Berkeley)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel explores four strikingly different Antebellum visions for the future of the continental interior. Eschewing East-coast, Anglo-Protestant perspectives, these papers present alternatives to the enduring narrative of Manifest Destiny, and examine the consequences wrought by these competing desires for the West, often from the point of view of those actually living there. Together, we hope to present a place and time marked by contingency, where overlooked institutions and economies, or the actions of an inspired few, could have profound effects on the course of 19th century American history. Max Forrester looks at religion and diplomacy in the experience of immigrant and sedentary Indian groups in the Texas borderlands in the two decades before the U.S.-Mexican War, and argues that issues of faith and perceptions of fate profoundly influenced the political choices of Native peoples trapped between allegiances. The alliances that these Indian groups founded were frequently comprised of incredibly diverse peoples (Western Cherokees, Kickapoos, Delawares, Shawnees, among others); this paper explores the role that mutually intelligible understandings of fate could play in facilitating a language of diplomacy, overcoming cultural differences and resource shortages, and choosing sides when violent conflict became inevitable. Sean Harvey examines Albert Gallatins attempts to organize widespread opposition to the U.S.-Mexican War by tracing the networks of individuals extending far beyond the East coast that informed and facilitated his efforts. Gallatin opposed expansionism, doubting that the union could encompass territories stretching to the Pacific. Yet, what he considered an unjust war also promised a windfall of ethnological knowledge concerning the possibility of indigenous social development. This paper argues that Gallatin"s efforts reveal the complementary roles of learned societies and religious organizations in allowing prominent men to parlay wealth, reputation, and local weight into national influence in a representative democracy through the public sphere. James Nichols examines the arrival of Black Creeks, Seminoles, and Kickapoos to the South Texas borderlands following the U.S.-Mexican War. Invited across the border by Mexico in an attempt to populate and protect the region, these so-called tribus emigradas instead imagined an independent pan-Indian colony outside of the purview of both Mexico and the United States. Through an analysis of cultural identities and visionary politics, this paper demonstrates that even after the making of the modern boundary in 1848, the geographical destiny of the south Texas borderlands was anything but certain.Nakia Parker looks at forced migration patterns and lived experiences of people of African and black Indian descent who came with their Native enslavers from the southeastern United States to resettle in the West. Considering Indian and black forced migrations in tandem, instead of as separate and pivotal traumatic events, can illuminate topics such as Native American involvement in the market economy and how conceptions of blackness and notions of Native sovereignty and futurity formed, collided, and reconciled during the mid-19th century. Ultimately, this paper aims to demonstrate that Native Americans were principal, not peripheral, historical actors in the institution of slavery in the Southwest as well as the domestic slave trade.
column2: Consider The Alternative: The Uncertain Fate Of The Antebellum West

column1:
Dr. Benny J Andrés (University of North Carolina, Charlotte)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

In our current moment, the rising tide of chauvinistic nationalism and the deepening vulnerability of racially marginalized, migrant populations register a degree of anti-immigrant hostility reminiscent of the Great Depression eras mass repatriation campaigns. We contend that the conditions of the present make historical inquiry into this earlier moment of immigrant removal as urgent as ever. Our panel excavates the historical contours, contingencies, and impacts of repatriation between the 1920s and 1940s, focusing especially on the repatriation of ethnic Mexicans and also, to a lesser extent, that of Filipino populations. In sites ranging from formal policy and law to courtrooms, aid agencies, labor and social movements, and the families and communities of repatriates themselves, we consider how struggles to define, implement, and respond to repatriation contributed to broader constructions of citizenship and belonging. Our panel examines the interface between consent and coercion in the implementation of repatriation policies and sheds light on the ways targeted populations maneuvered within prevailing political constraints. This examination offers new insights into the ways the boundaries of citizenship were constructed, enforced, and challenged in an era of deep economic and political crisis. Significantly, it also produces lessons about the pursuit of belonging, rights, and justice, lessons that have particular relevance as we confront forces of racial and national exclusion similar to those of the Great Depression era at present. The papers in this panel highlight varying aspects of repatriation across the longer arc of the Depression and World War II eras. Marla Ramírezs paper examines five identifiable waves of repatriation between 1831 and 1944, sorting through important ambiguities in the sources and slippages in historical narratives, offering important new insights concerning divergences and continuities in ethnic Mexicans experiences of repatriation as a cross-generational phenomenon. Elizabeth Sines paper explores grassroots responses to repatriation during the 1930s, highlighting the variety of social and cultural practices targeted populations engaged in their efforts to endure the removal campaigns and to construct notions of belonging for themselves. Romeo Guzmán brings into focus repatriated ethnic Mexicans efforts to return to the United States, shedding new light on the ways they drew on transnational kinship networks, made claims on the state, and reenvisioned citizenship in the process. Yuki Oda takes up the efforts of returning Mexican American repatriates and their families to evince their U.S. citizenship, revealing the troubles that surrounded efforts to prove their national membership during and after the World War II period. Together, the papers not only illuminate the protracted and contested nature of repatriations history; they provide a generative point of departure for building a collaborative discussion about the form and function of historical inquiry in our present moment of political crisis and anti-immigrant hysteria. It raises critical questions about the interplay between the national and the transnational in the lives of marginalized and migrant populations, and about the meanings and nature of rights, citizenship, and social membership.
column2: Constructions Of Citizenship And Belonging In The Repatriation Era

column1:
Mr. Chris Bunin ()

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

Contested Territory: Dien Bien Phu and the Making of Northwest Vietnam explores a world transformed through radical social change and the tense relations of rule it produced. This project analyzes the construction of territory in a borderlands region where struggle took many forms, particularly for the diverse peoples who lived in and near Dien Bien Phu—an out of the way place but also a pivot point in world history. There, in one of the 20th centurys most important battles, Vietnam defeated France to win the First Indochina War (1946-54) and earn independence. The battle was a fulcrum in a global transformation from European empire to national self-determination, inspiring anti-colonial activists from Jakarta to Algiers. It also shattered Dien Biens local economy, leaving a landscape scarred by trenches and bereft of livestock, cupboards bare of rice and seed. Tracing Vietnams postcolonial transition through a historical and political geography of 1950s Dien Bien Phu, this region poses questions for scholars of agrarian societies, political geography, and Southeast Asia. What did it mean to become a postcolonial subject? How is territory shaped, and shaped by, resource access? Why were peasants, long seen as engines of Vietnams revolution, so upset with its outcome?This same region asks educators in middle, secondary, and post-secondary classrooms to also grapple with the question: Why did the US Government reverse its support for an independent Vietnam? This question is central to understanding Americas complex role in Southeast Asia in the 1960s and 1970s. Specifically, this question takes us back to 1945 and directly to Ba Dinh Square in Hanoi, when the Roosevelt administration backed the Viet Minh and the DRVs declaration of independence, and to 1951 (or so) when the Truman administration threw its weight behind France in Asias emerging Cold War. Moreover, and rather than over-focus on the American angle, the question invites us to investigate Vietnamese history during the First Indochina War (1946-54). Understanding this period of post-WWII decolonization helps explain why partition in 1954 violated the nationalist principle of unity (one Vietnam) but led, unintentionally but inexorably, to a Cold War crisis.This panel represents a research team that investigated the complex and contested territory of the Black River Region from Hanoi to Dien Bien Phu in an effort to better understand the pretext for Americas involvement in Vietnam. This work relied on visualization technologies to support scholarship with interdisciplinary humanities. These technologies included geospatial mapping tools and location-based augmented reality mobile app. Our deliverable is a classroom-ready set of resources that will enable students in middle and secondary grades and in college and university courses to better understand Vietnams diverse society.
column2: Contested Territory: Dien Bien Phu And The Making Of Northwest Vietnam

column1:
Mr. Andrew William Bell (Boston University)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

The academic journal is a cornerstone venue for historical work with time-honored formats and procedures. Should a new journal, just beginning now, be any different? On the occasion of the publication of Cambridge University Presss Modern American History, several of the new peer-reviewed journals founders and board members reflect on the problems and possibilities of launching an academic journal in the 21st century. How can a journal bridge divides and create an inclusive meeting place for scholars from different subspecialities without losing its dedication to expertise? What kinds of innovations might be made to extend its formats beyond the traditional research article and the capsulated book review? How to weigh the enduring relevance of print volumes with exploding online capabilities? Who should be the audience for an academic journal, and what relation does the work done there bear to other forms of history?This panel will follow what might be described as a talk show format. The presenters will not give stand-alone talks but rather facilitate a wide-ranging conversation. In advance of the conference, the participants will brainstorm a set of questions that Professor Phillips will then pose to the panelists during the session, interspersed with questions and comments from the audience.
column2: Conversation: Modern American History: Rethinking The Academic Journal

column1:
Dr. Melody Herr (University of Arkansas)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Workshop

During this session, you"ll learn to:* determine if a book is the right publishing option for you* identify the publishers which can best serve your goals* create a book proposal that highlights your expertise and the unique features of your research* craft a cover letter that captures an editor"s attentionMelody Herr is a seasoned publishing professional with more than 16 years of experience as an acquiring editor for university presses and a reputation for a personal touch. She has coached authors working in fields ranging from political science, law, and international relations to regional history, legal history, and general US history. An author herself, she has published nonfiction and historical fiction for young readers as well as scholarly work. Currently, she serves as Head of the Office of Scholarly Communications at the University of Arkansas where she continues to serve researchers and scholars in diverse fields.
column2: Crafting Your Book Proposal And Attracting A Publisher

column1:
Professor Spencer R. Crew (Geroge Mason University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

Creating the exhibitions at NMAAHC in Washington DC presented a number of challenges. It was a balancing act of insuring the history presented was honest and accurate but also making sure it engaged the public in ways that encouraged learning as well as good places for discussions about the issues raised. Historical staff from NMAHC will talk about this process including working with history advisors and how they created a thought provoking experience for all visitors.
column2: Creating History Exhibitions At National Museum Of African American History And Culture

column1:
Tanya Golash-Boza (University of California, Merced)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable session explores the connections between criminality and mass incarceration, on the one hand, and migration, immigration, and mass detentions and deportations, on the other. It examines these links in broad terms, tying in racial formations, labor systems, resistance, conquest, poverty, and public policy. The conversation pushes beyond the black/white binary of much of carceral studies and the Anglo/Mexican or white/Latinx binaries of much of immigration studies. It asks: What does it look like if we study mass deportations, the flows of and war on drugs, and the rise of mass incarceration simultaneously, and in conversation with one another?
column2: Crimmigration: Exploring The Nexus Of Carceral And Immigration Studies

column1:
Dr. Angela Esco Elder (Converse College)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

In 2006, Roy Rosenzweig published an article in the Journal of American History entitled Can History Be Open Source? Wikipedia and the Future of the Past. By then Wikipedia had already become, he said, perhaps the largest work of online historical writing, the most widely read work of digital history, and the most important free historical resource on the World Wide Web. But Wikipedias anarchic editing process and uneven reliability have long repelled academics. Despite studies—including Rosenzweigs—comparing it favorably to traditional encyclopedias, its still the sour taste of Wikipedia that spoils much discussion of open source history, particularly outside of the digital humanities. But Rosenzweig believed that if historians believe that what is available free on the Web is low quality, then we have a responsibility to make better information sources available online. Historians could endlessly indict Wikipedia for its many shortcomings, or, he said, we could emulate [its] great democratic triumph … its demonstration that people are eager for free and accessible information resources.In 2014, after a year-long collaboration, over 350 historians produced a first edition of The American Yawp (www.americanyawp.com), a free and online, collaboratively built, open-source American history textbook designed for college-level history courses. Launched as a radical experiment in mass collaboration and institution-free pedagogy—a growing and widely successful experiment that 150,000 users already benefit from each semester—the Yawp was only a logical extension of the democratic promise inherent not just in the rise of the Digital Humanities as an identifiable academic field, but in a moment when technological innovation, institutional resources, professional norms, and shifting scholarly attitudes have converged to prove Rosenzweig right: history can be open source. The editors of The American Yawp are joined by contributor and chapter editor Angela Esco Elder and Stanford University Press acquisitions editor Margo Irvin (SUP is partnering with the Yawp to explore new paths for the publication of open texts) to discuss the promise and perils of mass collaboration in democratizing the American history survey. How can scholars collaborate across institutions to build resources for the classroom? How is open-source licensing changing historical pedagogy? And in a connected, digital age, what is the future of the American history textbook? How, for instance, are publishers reacting to new technology? Digital humanities scholar Kathryn Tomasek will therefore guide a discussion that addresses these questions while exploring the nature of the American history survey, the collaborative potential of the digital humanities, and the role of university presses in balancing a democratized history with the maintenance of the highest standards of the discipline.
column2: Democratizing The American History Textbook: Mass Collaboration And The American Yawp

column1:
Dr. Justin Behrend (State University of New York at Geneseo)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Routinely held to unrealistic standards amid a rapidly changing political landscape, the nations first African American mayors faced enormous expectations and challenges. Often, they achieved surprising success, despite enormous obstacles, from rapidly shifting economies to deeply recalcitrant white political structures. These certainly were the circumstances facing African Americans who began winning mayoral elections in the 1960s and 70s, such as Carl Stokes in Cleveland, Tom Bradley in Los Angeles, and Maynard Jackson in Atlanta. Though typically considered the break-through generation of black mayors, these men had important predecessors in cities across the South. One hundred years before the civil rights generation, African American mayors, such as Robert H. Wood in Natchez, Mississippi, and Stephen Swails in Kingstree, South Carolina, also led local governments through tumultuous times. A comparison of first- and second-wave black mayors reveals significant shifts – and continuities – in urban politics, citizenship, and the African American struggle for political representation.By putting into conversation civil rights and Reconstruction scholars who rarely interact despite common areas of interest, this panel assesses the long black mayoral experience. How did African American mayors navigate the tricky politics of race and class in two distinct eras – Reconstruction and the aftermath of the Civil War, and the post-1960s age of anxiety and rise of modern conservatism. What overlapping issues formed and informed their approaches to urban governance, such as debt, infrastructure, development, and services? How were these politicians able to build sustainable coalitions to win elections and to govern? How much did national politics build on or infringe upon their ability to govern at the local level? Ultimately, what were the policies, and tactics circulating among black executives in two key moments of political and racial transition?The three papers here engage these questions across often rigid sub-disciplinary boundaries. Justin Behrend addresses how Robert H. Wood and other black officials in Natchez negotiated the perilous divisions of Reconstruction southern politics in terms of race, class, and color in the 1870s. In contrast to black legislators and members of Congress during Reconstruction, their executive counterparts have received little scholarly attention. Gordon Mantler explores the great potential and limits of winning City Hall by looking at Harold Washingtons early years as Chicagos first black mayor in the mid-1980s. While often viewed as a successful movement triumph, Washington struggled to build anything beyond a fleeting coalition of mostly black and Latino voters in the face of considerable systemic challenges, locally and nationally. Matthew Countryman writes about the role of black mayors in national politics after 1967. The decision of the Johnson administration that year to support the mayoral candidacies of Richard Hatcher and Carl Stokes, in defiance of the local Democratic Party organizations, signaled a new relationship between the national party and black political leadership. Countryman"s paper explores the efforts of black mayors to shape the partys policies on race in cities in the 1970s and 1980s. Spanning more than a century, these papers explore the power and limits of black mayors in urban and national politics.
column2: Different Eras, Same Challenges? Black Mayors During Reconstruction And Civil Rights

column1:
Professor Grace E Hale (University of Virginia)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

The roundtable will discuss the role of digital history in historical scholarship. Digital forms are transforming the kinds of scholarship produced by historians and encouraging new methods of storytelling. The digital increases our need to pay attention to the role of interactivity and visuality in argumentation, challenges the privileging of single authorship, and broadens our potential audiences. Each member of the roundtable will discuss these core issues through the lens of their digital scholarship. Moderator Lauren Tilton will discuss Photogrammar (photogrammar.yale.edu), a web-based platform that allows users to organize, search, and visualize over 170,000 photographs from 1935 to 1944. She will briefly demonstrate how historical archives can be digitally reimagined to increase scholarship, visibility, and usability. Key issues she will discuss include what constitutes a digital scholarly argument, forms of knowledge production, the opportunities and challenges of collaboration, and structures of labor. Grace Hale will discuss Participatory Media (participatorymediaproject.org), an online project with funding from the NEHs Public Programs Division that interactively engages with and presents participatory community media from the 1960s and 1970s. PM centralizes disparate archives of community media and places them in the larger context of Americas public documentary record. Along with issues about the forms of knowledge, her comments will speak to issues of collaboration with community partners and audience.Mapping Inequality (dsl.richmond.edu/panorama/redlining), led by Rob Nelson, updates the study of New Deal America, the federal government, housing, and inequality for the twenty-first century. His comments will focus on interactive maps as a medium of public history. Viewed by more than 80,000 since October, it has been the subject of media commentary across the political spectrum from Dissent on the left to American Renaissance on the right. His comments will assess the effectiveness and limitations of Mapping Inequality and mapping more generally for prompting a broad public appreciation of and reckoning with the history of racial inequality in U.S. history.Monica Martinezs Mapping Violence makes visible the history of violence against Mexican-Americans by mapping border violence in Texas. Historians have outlined protocols and limits for retelling histories of slavery, genocide, colonialism, and rape. Fundamental questions remain about the limits and possibilities created when history and the digital humanities converge. What are the best methods for giving faces and names to the dead and to those that lived in the wake of violence? Martinez will discuss the protocols and limits for visually representing histories of racial violence for the public. While each project addresses a major moment in twentieth century US history, their approach to digital knowledge formation, collaboration, evidence, and audience varies based on their object of study, institutional resources, and stakeholders. The contours of these challenges and opportunities will be central to this roundtable. We will begin with a five minute introduction of each project. The moderator will pose several questions that discuss issues of digital form, project design, authorship and collaboration, and audience. We will then open up the conversation to the audience.
column2: Digital History: Possibilities And Challenges

column1:
Dr. Elizabeth Belanger (Hobart and William Smith Colleges)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Doing History Workshop

Digital stories are brief (typically 4-7 minute) multimedia films that combine photographs, simple animations, sound, and music—all unified by a narrative voiceover. Although originally conceived as an artistic, expressive, and accessible technological medium for ordinary people, digital storytelling techniques have been used in the classroom to integrate disciplinary content and students prior knowledge and skills. Completed projects can be shared in classroom film festivals or shared online, in a variety of formats and organizational schemes.This interactive workshop will introduce participants to the ways in which digital storytelling can be utilized in the undergraduate classroom to deeply engage students in historical thinking and to immerse them in the process of constructing historical knowledge, using archival materials (images, documents, texts, and sounds), critical thinking, and narrative voice. The facilitators, seasoned practitioners of digital storytelling in the classroom, will explain the seven key elements of effective digital storytelling (point of view, dramatic question, emotional content, voiceover, soundtrack, economy, and pacing), and will provide specific examples of how digital storytelling can be effectively incorporated into the undergraduate history classroom as an integrative or creative project. Examples will be drawn from the facilitators recent and ongoing courses in African American History, the Social History of the American Family, Womens History, and American Studies. Digital storytelling capstone projects typically include the following parts: the script, the edited film, and a contextual essay in which students discuss primary and secondary sources and reflect on the process of making history. In our experience, digital storytelling projects provide excellent opportunities to engage students in a variety of practical and theoretical questions central to historical analysis: What is historical truth? What is valid historical evidence? What is an objective stance? What are the genre conventions of history? What is the role of narrative voice, analogy, and metaphor in historical argument? And so on. Significantly, the skills gained from the digital storytelling process (writing, processing and sequencing still images and video clips, basic film editing, spoken-word narration, audio recording, and presenting on social media) are readily transferable to other classes, to workplace contexts, and, more generally, to students own lives.The workshop will conclude with a discussion of how to scaffold digital skills for novice learners, how to design and sell digital projects to students, and how to assess student learning outcomes of digital-story projects. Importantly, we will explore the ways in which small-scale digital assignments of all kinds increase student engagement, critical thinking, digital literacy, and metacognitive reflection in the undergraduate history classroom. Participants will leave with sample assignments, rubrics, and other teaching resources. This is intended to be a hands-on workshop and faculty are encouraged to come with questions and ideas of how they might integrate digital tools into their own classrooms and curriculums.
column2: Digital Storytelling In Teaching History

column1:
Dr. Catherine Olga Jacquet (Louisiana State University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

This panel explores how historians negotiate issues of disclosure and transparency around issues of identity on the job market, with colleagues and administrators, and in the classroom. Panelists will discuss the ways that they choose how to disclose (or refrain from disclosing) their status as, variously, disabled, queer, trans, pregnant, or non-traditionally aged when applying for jobs and once hired. They will also discuss how they have approached coming out in the classroom: pitfalls and benefits from such revelations, as well as strategies for dealing with difference in the classroom.
column2: Disclosure And Transparency On The Job Market And In The Classroom: Age, Disability, Gender, Pregnancy, And Sexuality

column1:
Ms. Tenisha Hart Armstrong (Martin Luther King, Jr. Papers Project at Stanford University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

Although the actual work of conceptualizing, executing and managing large-scale documentary editions and database projects has sometimes gone unnoticed, historians have for decades played an instrumental role in this most fundamental act of scholarship and professional service. Documentary Editions and the Future of Digital History calls attention to the value of large-scale projects that have advanced the profession in fundamental ways, and suggests the multiple benefits that can accrue to the historians and departments that choose to adopt and sustain them. It asks: How have historical documentary editions and database projects shaped historical study and training, and how might they in future? Discussants will offer brief opening remarks, to be followed by extended Q&A involving discussants, moderator, and audience alike.
column2: Documentary Editions And The Future Of Digital History: Advancing Fields And Field-Driven Historical Infrastructure In The Digital Age

column1:
Gabriel Jack Chin (UC Davis School of Law)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel will seek to use our panelists historical research on immigration as a jumping-off point to think about what it means to do history in the present political climate, broadly conceived, and how to engage more broadly with our communities in the public at a time when controversies over migration have been a political flash point in the United States and beyond. What does it mean to create an ambitious new exhibit focused on more recent immigrant history, challenging the distinction between "legal" and undocumented immigration? How does our work as historians embroil us in civic controversy, and how can we best contribute to the debate? How can research on twentieth-century migrant farm workers inform engagement with the present or work with the federal government? What to do about the feeling that your research doesnt just speak for itself—what does it mean to be an expert on migration in the early American republic but that expertise engaging with the broader public or pushing for change? This panel seeks to address these questions, and work with the audience to get somewhere toward some answers.Although we are submitting as a paper session, we intend to experiment with the form of presentations, as this annual meeting hopes to do. Our presentations will seek to use tools of classroom engagement and public history to make the audiences experience less one of passive listening and more one of engagement with the panelists and with each other.
column2: Doing Immigration History In The Present Political Climate

column1:
Dr. Brett V Gadsden (Northwestern University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

In 2016, the Democratic Party suffered a shocking, colossal defeat in the Presidential election. But down ballot Democratic candidates have been losing—badly—for the past several decades. By 2014, Republicans had gained a larger share of seats in state legislatures than at time since the 1920s. Trumps election marks the completion of a long political realignment that began in the 1960s. This transformation has resulted in a Republican Party that, for decades following the New Deal, was a minority party in Congress and most state governments, into one that dominates those branches and levels of government and speaks to the same demographics of voters that once constituted the Democratic Partys base. In light of the recent election and the incoming Trump administration, this roundtable will examine this political realignment and the recent history of liberalism. Few recent books lend more insight into the current state of the Democratic Party and how it got there than Lily Geismers 2015 book, Dont Blame Us: Suburban Liberals and the Transformation of the Democratic Party. Borrowing from the books title and using its account of suburban politics and the rise of suburban liberalism as a starting point for exploring the present moment, the panel will bring together a group of historians who will offer different views on the history and future of the Democratic Party. In tracing the demise of labor and working-class politics and the Democratic Partys embrace of neoliberalism, Dont Blame Us offers a new framework for understanding the political revolutions of the past half-century and the long-term trends that resulted in Trumps election. Panelists will discuss topics such as: the Democratic Partys retreat from New Deal liberalism and embrace of market-driven, technocratic policy solutions to structural inequality since the 1970s; the loss of working-class white voters and struggle to build a multiracial and -ethnic coalition; the debate over "identity politics and the mounting disillusionment of minority voters during the Obama presidency; Republican dominance in local elections; and the extent to which 2016 signaled a broad-based repudiation of liberalism among voters on the left and right.
column2: Don't Blame Us... Again: Historical Perspectives On The Democratic Party And The Rise Of Trump

column1:
Dr. Genevieve Clutario (Harvard University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

The three papers on this panel centralize a core tension in the creation of ethnicity: the external designation of a group intersecting with internal cultural norms, identities, and rituals among group members. Examining this duality maintains a productive focus on the contested and constructed nature of categories that are often naturalized. Each presenter contributes a new perspective into how individuals navigated the fraught zone of interaction with dominant expectations of Asians and Asian Americans in the twentieth century. The papers also demonstrate how gender has fundamentally shaped ethnicity as an imagined and lived reality. Genevieve Clutario highlights the predatory uses of ethnic duality. In her discussion of the Muslim Filipina Princess Tarhata Kiram, Clutario examines the efforts of the U.S. colonial government to use Kiram as a manipulated cultural envoy after WWI. By bringing Kiram to the United States for her college education, the government sought to Americanize her just enough before returning her to the Philippines to serve as a kind of cultural Trojan horse. Kirams body, dress, and behavior all became objects of public scrutiny as evidence of her carefully bounded transformations – or lack thereof. Annelise Heinzs paper focuses on spaces of ethnic construction within the context of an outsider gaze. In 1930s Chinatowns, Chinese Americans promoted the parlor game of mahjong as a commodified form of Chinese culture to white Americans, while simultaneously using the game to create a sense of cultural cohesion. The spaces marked by mahjong games facilitated distinct gendered patterns, as well as rare intergenerational socializing among Chinese Americans. Heinz examines how mahjong culture provides one example of how individuals navigated the limited possibilities of American inclusion; a younger generation connected examples of Chinese authenticity with American popular culture.In her paper profiling Patsy Mink, Judy Tzu-Chun Wu focuses on Minks political negotiations of the expectations foisted upon her as the first woman of color in the U.S. House of Representatives. In her powerful role as Representative, Minks public persona also reinforced Cold War narratives of American democracy. Wu shows how Mink navigated a pervasive focus on her appearance and both gendered and ethnic expectations in her work to challenge Cold War militarism. In addition, our panel embraces the OAHs call for more engaging forms of presentation. Our goal is to facilitate a deeper conversation by using the individual papers as a springboard to discuss unifying topics rather than specific details. To do so, the three presenters will precirculate papers to each other. At the conference, each author will briefly highlight her case study in a dynamic presentation not to exceed ten minutes. Lon Kurashige will then provide a comment that focuses on bringing together the conversation to shared concepts and topics. One such unifying thread will involve foregrounding visual representations in our research and analysis. With visuals, we can vary the form of conversation and invite more exchanges with the audience. Such a format will allow 15 minutes of conversation among the panelists as well as 35 minutes of discussion with the audience.
column2: Double-Edged Ethnicity: Asian/Americans In The Twentieth Century

column1:
Professor Marisela Chavez (California State University, Dominguez Hills)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Film Screening

I am submitting a proposal for my eleven-time, award-winning documentary East LA Interchange which chronicles the story of Boyle Heights, one of America"s great places of diversity, tolerance, and social change. East LA Interchange was released this fall and is being used in over thirty universities for classes within American History, Chicana/o & Latina/o Studies, Asian American Studies, African American Studies, Ethnic Studies, Urban Studies and Planning, and American Studies.East LA Interchange tells the story of working-class, immigrant Boyle Heights, the oldest neighborhood in East Los Angeles. Targeted by government policies, real estate laws, and California planners, this quintessential immigrant neighborhood survived racially restrictive housing covenants, Japanese-American Internment, Federal redlining policies, lack of political representation, and the building of the largest and busiest freeway interchange system in North America, the East L.A. Interchange. We witness Boyle Heights remarkable legacy of political activism and multiculturalism in the face of harsh political, spacial and economic realities.Boyle Heights was once one of the most diverse, multicultural areas in the United States. Founded in 1875, Boyle Heights by the 1920s had evolved into a multiracial neighborhood more diverse than most U. S. cities at the time with Latinos, Asians, African-Americans, and the largest settlement of Jews west of Chicago living and working together side-by-side. A 1954 article in Fortnight declared, Few districts in America are as ethnically dynamic, politically tolerant, and community-proud… East LA Interchange charts Boyle Heights evolution from multiethnic to predominantly Latino as the neighborhood became a nucleus of Mexican-American history and culture in the U.S.East LA Interchange presents a complex picture of the many issues Boyle Heights residents have faced through the years such as access to education, gang violence, discriminatory immigration policies, environmental pollution and gentrification. The question of whether an evolving Boyle Heights can preserve its unique culture and history along with a desire to create new opportunities and a healthier environment for its residents is one that many communities throughout the country are currently facing. In East LA Interchange, NYU historian John Kuo Wei Tchen says, Places like Boyle Heights are literally on the cutting edge of what this country is becoming.Studying Boyle Heights multicultural history and understanding its present serves as an imperative lesson in cooperation and tolerance for our increasingly divided society today. East LA Interchange takes a thought-provoking approach that leaves viewers with questions about the possibilities of community in the U.S.: could a neighborhood like Boyle Heights thrive in our contemporary society where fear and prejudice against low-income and immigrant populations abound? As our presidential elections anti-immigrant and racist rhetoric has shown, the question remains whether the U.S. will be able to learn from the example of Boyle Heights to create an environment that welcomes and celebrates multiculturalism.The film features will.i.am (The Black Eyed Peas), Father Greg Boyle (Homeboy Industries), Josefina López (Real Women Have Curves), Dr. George J. Sanchez (USC), Dr. Marisela Chavez (CSUDH), Dr. John Kuo Wei Tchen (NYU), and is narrated by Danny Trejo (Machete).
column2: East La Interchange Documentary Screening

column1:
Dr. Darryl E. Brock (City University of New York)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 00:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This four-paper panel, Economics and Politics: Civil War Era Latin American Relations with the Southern U.S., argues that southerners capitalized on their Latin American economic connections to promote southern interests. Tracing this long-standing, outwardly focused southern gaze sheds new light on the reality of southern diplomacy, expansionism, and economic modernization both before and after the Civil War. Despite extensive nineteenth-century economic networks between the South and Latin America, historians have generally favored discussions about southern-European relations. Transnational and global contexts related to Latin America and the American South during the Civil War Era have received considerably less attention.The panel members seek to remedy this historiographical shortcoming. Mariana Muazes paper highlights the flexibility of antebellum slavery in the Mississippi Valley when it compares slavery in this southern valley to systems of slavery in the Vale do Paraíba of Brazil. She explores how masters awareness of other systems of slavery impacted the living spaces of slaves. Southerners used their knowledge of Latin American natural resources and trading ports, as well as Latin American systems of slavery, to promote their own economic agendas. Ximena Sevilla creates an environmental history when she argues that definitions of the relationship between humans and nature defined scientific understandings of the Peruvian Upper Amazon during the nineteenth century. By defining this relationship as an overabundance of resources, explorers focused on finding a region with climatic conditions suitable for foreigners willing to expand the commercial networks of these resources. Explorers emphasized the economic opportunities provided by the navigability of the Amazon River and its tributaries in order to connect these remote areas with industrial centers located in the United States. As Darryl Brock demonstrates in his paper, members of the Trans-Mississippi Department, much like members of the antebellum Mississippi Valley elite, staked their very existence on the strength of southern economic connections to Latin America. Cubans such as José Agustín Quintero deftly navigated volatile Mexican politics when they represented southern interests in Mexico primarily through vigorous cotton trade. Evan Rotheras paper illustrates that southern interest in Latin American economic opportunities did not abate in the wake of the Civil War. Instead, writers employed newspaper and literary forums to present places such as Mexico as a viable alternative to Reconstruction-and southerners believed these reports. Former Confederates like Nathaniel Beverley Tucker sought to rebuild their lives in Mexico when they began new occupations as newspapermen and immigration agents. These four papers use archival material from the United States, Mexico, Cuba, Peru, and Brazil to illustrate that nineteenth-century southerners looked south, as well as east and west, in their efforts to ensure survival of the South. Furthermore, this research reminds scholars that Latin Americans sometimes leveraged that southern interest for their own purposes.
column2: Economics And Politics: Civil War Era Latin American Relations With The Southern U.S.

column1:
Professor Frank C Costigliola (University of Connecticut)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

In 1985, Peter and Carol Stearns published their seminal article on emotionology in the American Historical Review. In the ensuing three decades, the history of emotions has emerged as one of the most innovative subfields in the American historical profession. A growing body of literature on emotions such as homesickness, anger, and American cool has covered time periods as disparate as the American Revolution, the War of 1812, and the early Cold War. Since 2014, a book series at the University of Illinois Press has published several important monographs on emotions history, with more entries soon to follow.Despite the exciting work being done on the history of emotions in the American context, there remains a great deal of research to be done specifically on the emotions of the Gilded Age and Progressive Era. Since Jackson Lears No Place of Grace (1981) identified the quest for intense experience as a key motivating force behind turn-of-the-century social change, the period has stood out as a time when emotions were perhaps uniquely important in shaping American society. Never was oratory more orotund, propaganda more reckless, denunciation more bitter, reform more strident, declared Howard Mumford Jones in The Age of Energy (1971). A people thus verbally unrestrained must have been filled with exuberance and wrath. Yet historians still know little about what shaped American emotions, and how those emotions in turn changed American culture, during those years.Accordingly, this roundtable brings together several leading scholars in the history of emotions during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries in order to help sketch the emotional landscape of those decades. The panels chair, Frank Costigliola, is a former president of the Society for Historians of American Foreign Relations and one of the most innovative historians of emotions working today; his article on the role of emotions in shaping George Kennans contributions to the Cold War was published in the Journal of American History in 2016. Jeremy C. Young, an assistant professor of history at Dixie State University, is the author of The Age of Charisma (2017), which argues that the modern emotional connection between leaders and followers in America grew out of a unique group of charismatic social movements prominent in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Brenton J. Malin, an associate professor of communication at the University of Pittsburgh, is the author of Feeling Mediated (2014), which centers on the role of radio technology in shaping American emotions in the early twentieth century. Amy Louise Wood, a professor of history at Illinois State University, analyzes the role of feeling in intellectual, popular, and state treatments of the criminal, and contextualizes these treatments within emotional responses to industrial capitalism. Together, these scholars will outline a framework for understanding the always passionate, often mercurial emotions of the Gilded Age and Progressive Era United States.
column2: Emotions In The Gilded Age And Progressive Era

column1:
Dr. Keith A Erekson (LDS Church History Library)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Doing History Workshop

With the popularity of online family history, DNA testing, and social media, historians have new tools and opportunities to enrich their research methods and to make history come alive for their audiences. This interactive workshop will provide approaches, resources, and examples of life-changing family history projects that engage students with acquisition and analysis of primary sources. Historians own research will benefit from techniques that provide and organize research materials to enliven biography, develop social history context, and expand cultural diversity. Learn the latest genealogical detective work to support students and others who are searching for their families. Discover new ways to work hands-on with material culture artifacts. Explore crossover writing approaches utilizing scholarship, historical inference, and creative nonfiction techniques. Family history provides a way to better articulate the value of history and humanities to peoples lives.
column2: Family History For Historians, Historians For Family History

column1:
Michelle Liu Carriger (UCLA)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

When considering forms of history, we tend to think of those that are self-consciously pedagogical and/or interpretive: the monograph, the lecture, the commemoration, the museum. Scholars interested in popular history have also added television, film, and more popular forms to this list, but embodied engagements (that is, interactions where meaning is made at the site of the body) are often understudied. We assume that history (the narrative, the interpretive process) is kept separate from the knowledge-producing or appraising subject, who we still think of as a sort of blank slate, who learns about and makes meaning from the past quite apart from their own experience or sense of self. This omission has many reasons: bodies are messy; meaning made at the level of affect or emotion is highly personal and difficult to gauge. In recent years, scholars working in memory studies have begun to consider more deeply how history-making occurs at the intersection of many different experiential and constitutive contexts, but in these theoretical formations memory acts as a counternarrative to history, as opposed to a force that acts at the register of recognition.However, for better or for worse, Americans have been learning about and making sense of the past by touching it, wearing it, and feeling it for many years now. It is only recently that scholars working across several fields (history, performance studies, theatre studies, affect studies) have begun to take seriously the ways that people make historical meaning through embodied engagement. This panel will examine the way in which forms of history that involve the body as the primary site of discovery and meaning-making (living history, reenactment, role-playing, fan culture, fashion), has intersected and interacted with its surrounding popular culture. It is not insignificant that these forms of historical knowledge-production have become more prominent as popular culture and consumer culture itself has become more robust, particularly with the post-60s turn across these fields, as scholars like Fred Turner and Thomas Frank have noted, towards individualized experience. Historical knowledge production must be considered in tandem with these developments, and embodied history is a particularly apt site at which to do so.Because embodied history is often practiced outside of formalized institutional settings, it is a particularly rich and variegated form of engagement, deeply dependent on its context. We are particularly interested in the ways in which these forms of historical meaning-making converge with subculture, consumption, and popular culture at large. On one hand, embodied engagements with history have the potential to highlight histories and actors that stand outside traditional narratives that are found in institutional historical settings, on the other, they are in danger of reproducing the kinds of inequities of power and representation that are evident within popular culture at large. The papers comprising this panel take seriously embodied engagement with history, considering how bodies and history interact and affect each other, keeping in mind that for many people, such forms of historical meaning-making are their primary modes of engagement with the past.
column2: Feeling Is Believing: Embodied Practices Of Popular History

column1:
Mrs. Kelly Midori Midori McCormick (University of California Los Angeles, History Department)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

Burdens still fall disproportionately on professional women, namely childcare and eldercare, but in the current climate bullying and threats have increased and taken particular aim at LGBTQ women and women of color. This roundtable of graduate students and senior historians will discuss current issues facing female academics and share the results of a recent study on adjunct faculty undertaken by the Coordinating Council for Women in History.
column2: Female Professor: Reconsidering The Hazards Of The Woman Historian In Academe

column1:
Dr. Madeline Y. Hsu (The University of Texas at Austin)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

After the end of the Second World War the Global South found itself at a junction between two dominant social, political, and economic nation-building models. The reconstruction of post-war economies, the pressures of modernization, the search for state sovereignty, and the surge of participatory democracy changed the social, economic, and political dynamics of the Global South. Meanwhile the United States and the Soviet Union strategized ways in which to win the hearts and minds of the Global South, competing for the design of the postwar world. The Global Souths reaction to these initiatives forced the two superpowers to redefine their strategic agendas. This panel focuses on the reactions that took place in Pakistan, Thailand and Colombia, and the public diplomacy strategies designed and implemented by the United States in order to respond to these initiatives. Through the use of propaganda systems the United States was able to respond to challenges that threatened their regional Containment policies, impeding the spread of Communist, Socialist, and Nationalist agendas across the Global South. By looking at the specific case studies of Pakistan, Thailand and Colombia, the papers on this panel demonstrate that the United States had to develop new institutional and programmatic strategies in order to execute propaganda systems that curved the discourse away from nationalist interests and toward the anti-Communist agendas favored by the United States. Public diplomacy programs were tailored to the internal social, economic, and political dynamics of each of the nation states. Ultimately, the papers argue that in the case of the Cold War there was no one size fits all formula when it came to the implementation of Containment policies and the use of propaganda systems designed to curtail self-determination in the Global South.
column2: Fighting Communism In The Global South:  U.S. Propaganda And The Agendas Of Containment

column1:
Dr. Kathleen Belew (University of Chicago)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel examines the relationship between gender, race and conservatism in the twentieth century United States. Taking a bottom up view, the panel explores how and why white men and women have been drawn to conservative causes across the twentieth century. Looking at debates over race-suicide in the first decades of the century, Trent McNamaras paper probes how moralists constructed a biological and cultural case for large families in reaction to prevailing modernist ideas. Julia Bowes examines the place of gender and ideas about the family in the anti-statist activism of the Sentinels of the Republic during the 1920s. In her paper on the desegregation of hospitals in the Deep South in the 1960s, Karissa Haugeberg analyzes how the female-dominated profession of nurses responded to and negotiated this progressive change. Finally, Kathleen Belews paper explores the role women played in the white power movement amidst fall out from the Vietnam War, looking at the instrumental role women played in building the movement and the symbolic importance of white womanhood to the movement. Collectively, the papers draw upon the complementary methodologies of social history and intersectional analysis to offer new ways of understanding twentieth century political history. Using these analytical strategies, the panel is attendant to the ways identity politics has been produced by political groups and has been a product of how particular groups and communities encountered progressive social change.Each paper raises a distinct question about the forms in which we represent the past. Haugebergs paper considers how the spaces where we situate our historical analysis shape our understandings. Whereas histories of desegregation have either taken place in the suburbs, or studied the laws themselves, Haugebergs paper examines the workplace as a forum where progressive change was enacted, negotiated and experienced. Belew reflects on the ethical demands and challenges of recovering the violence of white supremacists. MacNamaras paper considers how ideas about mysticism and modernity have blended in fashioning political claims. Analyzing how the Sentinels of the Republic fashioned a particular rendering of the American Revolution to serve their political ends, Bowes contemplates how historians create political narratives to speak to the political questions of our own time.Parsing out the relationship between social change, identity and conservative causes, the panel studies diverse terrain and forms of history in pursuit of a common question. As a whole, the panel asks what can gender and race tell us about how and why diverse Americans became committed conservatives.
column2: Fighting Progressive Social Change: Gender, Race And The Making Of Conservatives In The Twentieth Century United States

column1:
Dr. Peter J. Ferdinando (University of North Carolina at Charlotte)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

The history of La Florida is at all times indigenous, settler, white, black, colonial and modern, yet chroniclers of this story have neglected to fully embrace its past and present indigenous peoples. Local, paraprofessional, professional, and popular histories are all in concert with one another to write the story of Floridas indigenous peoples as a vanishing race while denying the legitimacy of existing native nations that remain throughout the state. Unrealistic settler narratives of Florida have a long history. Colonial, settler, and later, vacationers and retirees share the same two tropes- descriptions of the territory are frequently fanciful and picturesque, filled with either dreams of fortune, grandeur and glory or damning the malarial and festering swampland of grim misfortune. Within these narratives there is also the concept of Florida as the first discovered, last settled. As the historiography relates to indigenous peoples, there is the familiar Vanishing Indian motif, that the numerous peoples of the coast had simply vanished, victims of disease and enslavement. The last real Indians of Florida as one recent popular history called them, left in the early eighteenth century for Cuba. These types of settler stories help to justify their racial classifications of the Seminole peoples, attempting to deny their claims to territory while claiming the Seminole were either not really indigenous to Florida or by focusing on their intermarriage with African Americans to deny their legitimacy. This process of denying legitimacy to indigenous peoples is part of what ethnohistorian Jean M. OBrien has argued stubbornly remained in the consciousness and unconsciousness of Americans and a toxic brew of racial thinking. The contact era of Florida history has stubbornly focused on the myths of Ponce de Leon, the slaughter of French protestants by Pedro Menendez de Aviles, and the importance of the presidio at St. Augustine. But often the story of Florida ignores or makes only brief mention of the indigenous peoples along the southern coast, in particular the mound builders near what is now Cape Canaveral and the Ais of the Indian river lagoon. The papers in this session will discuss these peoples and the important ways they engaged in the colonial encounter. In doing so, they will address what it means for a state to encounter an indigenous and colonial history that the chroniclers of La Florida clearly cannot ignore but cannot fully embrace.
column2: Firsting And Lasting In La Florida

column1:
Dr. David L. Anderson (California State University, Monterey Bay)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Policymakers frequently use history to help them form arguments for or against certain policies. Yet policymakers must also understand the limits that different forms of history have for policy formation. Historical analogies are a particularly tempting refuge for policymakers who want to understand how to avoid committing past mistakes. But analogies can also have serious limitations in the hands of policymakers with poor historical sensibilities. If applied to situations that bear little resemblance to the original event, historical analogies are of low value in policy formation. In such cases, analogies can serve to confirm the ideological priors of the policymaker in question rather than help to shape cohesive policy. The Vietnam War looms large in policy formation related to U.S. foreign relations. In particular, policymakers and their advisers who favor an American stance in the world characterized by prudence and restraint tend to draw lessons from Vietnam. Controversy over Americas role in the world today means that Vietnams lessons are increasingly relevant. This panel examines Vietnams place in historical thinking related to policy formation. From policymaking during the war, to postwar policy related to other Cold War battles, to post-9/11 foreign policy, the papers explore how policymakers use different forms of history, as well as the opportunities and limits that historical thinking poses for decision-making. By doing so they reflect on how historians can interact with the policymaking process.Thomas A. Reinstein of Temple University first examines how history applied to policy formation during the Vietnam War. Using recently-declassified documents, he compares hawkish policymakers use of various historical analogies with the intelligence communitys more measured reports using analyses of Hanois past performance. Although policymakers analogies merely served to confirm their preconceptions that the U.S. could win in Vietnam, the intelligence communitys use of history often accurately estimated Hanois future actions. But because these reports did not speak to policymakers pre-existing beliefs, they went ignored or unread.Gail Yoshitani of West Point follows by examining how Vietnam-related analogies applied to Latin American Cold War battlefields. She argues that Vietnam influenced how important Reagan administration officials, key congressional and military leaders, and much of the American public thought about U.S. foreign policy in Latin America during the early 1980s. Each group focused on different lessons from the Vietnam experience.
