In the end these lessons had a significant impact on Reagan administration policy in Latin America.Mark Lawrence of the University of Texas at Austin concludes by looking at how policymakers use Vietnams lessons in the modern age of terrorism. He examines the different forms of history that policymakers have applied to Vietnam while also determining its relevance for policymaking in a post-Iraq War world. In doing so he offers a framework for understanding how policymakers can use history in foreign relations.
column2: Forming Policy In Vietnams Shadow: Historical Thinking And The Usable Past

column1:
Tom Neville (THATClass & the American School of Paris)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

How can we help students learn the form of historical work and historical thinking through the use of primary source tools and archival research?What are the benefits to students and society of learning history and historical thinking, and how can we articulate that the skills gained in history are as necessary as STEM skills?This innovative session will open with short presentations on teaching with primary sources from the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) and from a founder of THATclass (The Humanities and Technology Class) on his experience teaching history to high school students through archival research. THATClasss goal of making history as compelling and necessary as STEM and its practical approach ("What if we replaced the textbook curriculum with archival materials?") leads to authentic historical work, with students framing questions, researching in archives and developing important research skills.After these short introductory presentations to kick off discussion, the chairs will facilitate a design discussion among all attendees with the goal of generating ideas in two areas: 1) How can students of all ages be introduced to the form of historical thinking and historical research through encounters with archival documents and research projects, and 2) how can the historical community make the case that the skills students gains through the study of history and historical research, including assessing the reliability and perspective of primary source evidence, are as critical for the health of American society and civic life as STEM?Attendees will be encouraged to share their own good practices, tools, and ideas for teaching with primary sources, and will spend the final portion of the session designing a message that captures the real value of historical research and thinking, gained through work in historys lab - archival collections.
column2: Forming Student Historians: Primary Sources And Historical Research At All Levels

column1:
Dr. Howard Robert Baker (Georgia State University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This session engages the forms of history found in the life narratives of enslaved people making freedom in the wake of the antebellum slave system. In assessing the evidence that tell us these stories this panel interrogates sources that enliven the interpretation of struggles in enslaved fugitivity. These historical inquiries require analysis of an array of discursive forms taken from legal,political, and economic structures involved in upholding the slave system. The presentations in this session highlight the connections and resonances of enslaved peoples experiential worlds across time and space as they attempted to exercise political autonomy. Brandi Waters examines conflicting interpretations of enslaved resistance in "Fatal Fugitivity: Medical Interpretations of Slave Resistance in Colonial Colombian Courts." Evan Turiano investigates the political significance of enslaved resistance through opposition to the Fugitive Slave Act in"Popular Non-enforcement of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law in Northern Communities, 1850-1860. Christy Hyman focuses her presentation on enslaved peoples navigational literacy of the Great Dismal Swamp landscape through examining their efforts at making freedom in her paper The Courage to Move Through: Enslaved Movement and Freedom in the Great Dismal Swamp.Taken together this panel exposes the multi-layered dimensions of fugitivity practiced by enslaved runaways and insurgents traversing the minefield of antebellum enslavement.
column2: Forms Of Freedom-Tracing The Political Costs Of Freedom-Making In Bondage

column1:
Dr. James I. Deutsch (Smithsonian Institution)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable discussion will bring together two sets of scholars—anthropologists and historians—to demonstrate ways in which the forms of these two disciplines may synergistically augment and enhance each other. The case study will be Chicagos ethnic neighborhoods during a period of 100 years—from 1910 to 2010. Both sets of scholars have studied the patterns of migration, community creation, and displacement of Chicagos African American, Assyrian, Eastern European, Iraqi, Jewish, and Latino communities and will employ their research to highlight some of the first-person perspectives through which immigrants and migrants in Chicago neighborhoods have created, been affected by, and are maintaining aspects of the culture they have brought to the United States in the process of becoming American. Before World War I, Chicagos steel mills, factories, and stockyards attracted large number of workers primarily from eastern and southern Europe. When immigration from those countries was blocked by the First World War, large numbers of African Americans, Mexicans, and white Appalachians moved north, literally changing the complexion of Chicago. With the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965 (also known as the Hart-Celler Act), the face of immigration changed once again, as new immigrants from Africa, Asia, and Latin America made Chicago their new home. By the end of the 20th century, Chicagos immigrant population was as high as its native population, with large numbers of migrants from India, Mexico, and the Philippines living in neighborhoods that remain distinct from those inhabited by descendants of earlier migrants from Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Poland, and the American South. On the one hand, Chicago has claimed the successful incorporation and assimilation of these immigrants. However, anthropologists and historians have also documented the existence of hostility and otherizing, which have long been part of American migration and displacement, and which Gwendolyn Brooks (herself the daughter of African Americans who moved to Chicago as part of the Great Migration) describes so well in her poems, especially A Street in Bronzeville (1945). Of particular interest to both anthropologists and historians are the dynamics of incorporation and assimilation. As noted by William I. Thomas and Florian Znaniecki some 100 years ago in The Polish Peasant in Europe and America (1918–1920), Polish immigrants to Chicago adapted first to Polonia, an intermediate neighborhood that was neither wholly Polish nor wholly American, but rather something in between. Once these Polish immigrants had become acclimated to Polonia, they found it much easier to adjust to American society at large. Their struggles to maintain Polish identity while also becoming American were directly tied to the physical neighborhoods and communities in which they were residing. This roundtable discussion will help demonstrate the variety of ways not only in which anthropologists and historians conceive and present their work, but also how can learn from each other in order to improve their analysis and interpretation of topics that are of mutual interest and concern.
column2: Forms Of History And Anthropology In The Study Of Chicagos Ethnic Neighborhoods

column1:
Dr. Julian Carlos Chambliss (Rollins College)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel investigates forms of history that emerge in public space and in historical narratives that shape—and are shaped by—the spaces they inhabit. Focusing on several historically significant communities in central Florida and southwest Georgia, panelists explore a variety of narrative forms that town promoters—past and present—deployed to promote and define their communities to each other and to the outside world. From the late nineteenth century to the present, these forms of public memory have created appealing mythologies and supplied strategies of empowerment and self-definition. Such narratives were written literally and metaphorically in newspapers and tourism materials, on plaques, in murals, in monuments, in historic preservation, in commemorative festivals, and in urban design. While many of these public texts have been intentionally created by historical societies, writers, municipalities or and booster associations, others are unintentional stories evident only through their absence, or implied in the very brick and mortar of a streetscapes placement, a buildings location in the landscape or decisions about preservation. The panel explores the power dynamics inherent in these historical forms. All three panelists engage themes of race, class, heritage tourism, and community development to show how different constituencies created and mobilized narratives about local history. In central Florida, African Americans in Gilded Age Winter Park deployed their own narratives of freedom as they tried to take advantage of the New South opportunities the region presented. Julian Chambliss describes how African American residents used their newspaper, the Winter Park Advocate, to shape public perception of their community. Scot French shows how, in Eatonville, a historically black central Florida community incorporated in 1887, town promoters have consistently invoked exceptionalist myths that obscured the more complex histories of the town and its deep connections to surrounding communities. Emily Mieras compares the dominant narratives about DeLand, Florida, and Thomasville, Georgia that early promoters created in the late nineteenth century to draw wealthy white northerners to these areas, promoting narratives of white pioneers and racial harmony that belied far more complex (and conflicted) racial and class realities. Each of the panelists illuminates historical narratives that emerged in early town promotion but that have also shaped contemporary understandings of local identity. In DeLand and Thomasville, dominant narratives highlighted white pioneers at the expense of African American stories, a pattern that continues to the present day. In Eatonville and Winter Park, African Americans deployed varied strategies to present their communities to the public and forge a legacy for the future, practices that shaped contemporary community identities and claims to heritage tourism. The early forms of town promotion in all these communities resonate in contemporary versions. The elisions and mythologies of the earlier era continue to shape tourism and local branding today. By illuminating the origins and layers of these historical narratives, the panel suggests possibilities for complicating these stories in the present.
column2: Forms Of History And Community Forms: Race, Place, And Historical Narratives In The New South

column1:
Professor Kendra Taira Field (Tufts University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

This roundtable explores the practice of historians writing about family ancestry and working with descendant communities. Recently descendant communities have organized, advocated for recognition, and participated in the work of historians, producing contributions to scholarship, research, teaching, and public engagement. Georgetown University held a Liturgy of Remembrance, Contrition, and Hope in April 2017 with the descendants of the enslaved families sold by the university in 1838, and the GU272 Descendants Association offers one model of community organization. Other descendant communities have emerged around free black town settlements, Native American boarding schools, and disabilities communities. This roundtable brings together scholars and descendants currently engaged in these collaborations to discuss the new forms of historical scholarship and engagement made possible by the move from ancestry to history.
column2: From Ancestry To History: Understanding Descendant Communities

column1:
Ms. Cat Ariail (University of Miami)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

The contemporary literature on gender history indicates the multiplicity and complexity of gender expression, as well as its grounding in cultural, geographical, and historical context. R.W. Connells Masculinities, Judith Butlers Gender Trouble and Undoing Gender, and Joan W. Scotts The Fantasy of Feminist History and Gender: A Useful Category of Analysis stand as just a few of the seminal works in the development of gender history as a field. These authors and others have increasingly pointed to the significance of the body to gender expression, examining not just biological traits but how gender is performed on and using the body.The papers in this session examine the points where gender norms conflict with the lived reality for particular populations. In "Gender Expression and the Body: Images of Marines from Leatherneck and Time" by Sarah E. Patterson, the author looks at how images of masculinity and femininity play out on the bodies of male and female Marines in certain magazine images from the twentieth century. Patterson investigates the tension between masculine and feminine traits in the uniquely hypermasculine environment of the Marine Corps during a time when womens increasing participation in the military raised questions about the reality of mens and womens places in society.
column2: Gendered Bodies In Public Spheres: Military, Athletic, Carceral

column1:
Ms. Kate Grauvogel (Indiana University Bloomington)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel examines the cultural politics of reproductive rights, feminism, and mothering from the postwar era to the present day. As debates about womens rights and freedoms became more heated in the wake of second-wave feminism, and as more women gained greater self-determination, the decisions women made about reproduction and childrearing were inflected by a highly politicized public sphere. These three papers address the intersection of postwar feminism, womens decision-making, and broader political debates. Examining the social environment in which hormonal birth control emerged from the 1940s through the 1960s, Kate Grauvogel considers how birth control became a source of tension: at once an emblem of sexual freedom and a source of health concerns regarding its possible side effects. As Grauvogel argues, feminists often interpreted any criticism of the pill on health grounds as a critique of social progress, which served to limit discussions of other birth control options. Sarah Rowley explores the cultural politics of abortion in the 1970s, a time when a cultural fascination with the 1950s in popular culture often served conservative goals. Arguing that abortion debates were deeply imbedded in a politicized cultural obsession with the past, Rowley examines how abortion rights and anti-abortion activists both framed their arguments around nostalgic versions of the American past. Leslie Paris examines a counterculture that began well before the 1960s and has continued to grow: the natural parenting movement. As Paris argues, this history reflected a widening skepticism about traditional male medical authority. While the movement was a source of judgement and anxiety for some, it served a wide range of women who invoked it to achieve a range of communal, political, and economic goals
column2: Gendered Cultures And Countercultures: Contraception, Abortion, And Mothering In The Postwar Years

column1:
Miss Miya Carey (Rutgers University - New Brunswick)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Historians most often discuss age in biographies, using it to indicate the passage of time in their subjects life cycle. This panel proposes to change the form of history in which age is a central feature. Rather than treating age as way to mark chronology, we will consider age as a category that structures broader narratives of power and politics. Throughout American history, age has, in one way or another, shaped how historical actors exercised political power, how their politics were perceived, and the acceptable range of their political expression. The voting rights, citizenship, political styles, and modes of political protest of children, Old Maids, grandmothers, and young adults were all in various ways dependent on ideas about the particular ages at which individuals can be political and, if they can, how. This panel will feature scholars of youth and the elderly, exploring the ways in which age, together with race, sexuality, and gender, has functioned as a political identity and as a factor in shaping political possibilities in a democracy. Drawing on speeches, organizational records, and political tracts, Corinne Field, Assistant Professor of Women, Gender & Sexuality at the University of Virginia, will reveal how white and black woman suffragists re-purposed the categories of grandmother and old maid to claim political power between 1870 and 1900. Vanessa May, Associate Professor of History at Seton Hall University, will examine how ideas about age, gender, and sexuality shaped the policy-making power of Dr. Martha May Eliot, who became Childrens Bureau Chief in 1951 at sixty years old. Miya Carey, a doctoral candidate in History at Rutgers University, will approach the analysis of age in history from the perspective of adolescent black girls engaging the Civil Rights Movement from within single-sex youth programs. James Marten will comment. Marten, Professor and Chair of the History Department at Marquette University, has written prolifically on the history of children and is the current editor Journal of the History of Childhood and Youth. In total, this panel will begin to rethink the form that narratives of age might take in histories of the nineteenth and twentieth century United States.
column2: Growing Up And Growing Older In The United States: Age As A Category Of Analysis

column1:
Professor Nan Enstad (University of Wisconsin)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

In a 1917 lecture at Munich University Max Weber informed his audience that modern life is characterized by rationalization and intellectualization, and, above all, by the disenchantment of the world. The instrumental logics of modern institutions, he believed, had deprived the world of mystery and had stripped it of much of the anthropocentric significance on which human societies had always anchored belief. Freud later inverted Webers formulation, arguing that civilization itself—far from removing the scales of enchantment from moderns eyes— precipitates a raft of irrationalities at odds with the Enlightenment project of reason. In the decades since, understandings of the modern mind have largely gravitated to these two poles— ambivalent or sometimes celebratory accounts of demystification on one hand and more pessimistic renderings of the modern mind as beset by the spooks of capitalist modernity on the other.This panel seeks to complicate both of these paradigms. Not only did modernity not disenchant the world, but modern forms of enchantment have defied reduction to the pathologies and coping mechanisms of modern life. Nan Enstads paper explores a form of enchantment lying paradoxically at the very heart of Webers supposedly rational modern bureaucracy— corporate personhood. Examining the 1890 incorporation of the American Tobacco Company, she shows how the market and nation-state breathed life into the corporate golem with magical implications for the wider culture. Similarly, Christopher Whites paper highlights entwinement of rationalization and enchantment by focusing on the magical effects of a ubiquitous piece of mid-20th century consumer technology— the television. Analyzing the construction of televisual space in science fiction programming and the conflation of spiritual and electrical energies by televangelists, he argues that TVs served as conduits for an imagined, spiritualized elsewhere. Whites focus on media is mirrored in Jacques Vests paper, which argues for an increasingly enchanted understanding of recorded sound in the decades after the technologys introduction in 1877. Audiences came to understand recorded sound in terms that emphasized the immanence of recorded subjects and the commensurability of self and other. Finally, Rivka Maizlish explores the tension between science and enchantment through the Texas Folklore Society, which broke away from the national organization in 1924. Led by University of Texas professor J. Frank Dobie, the TFS rejected the scientistic pretensions of Franz Boas and others and elevated imagination and enchantment over professionalization and standardization.If, as Bruno Latour has argued, moderns have never successfully disentangled mind and object, then disenchantment and re-enchantment must be transcended in favor of more nuanced language. Instead of an enchanted on/off switch in the historical mind we confront the possibility of shades, registers, and modes of enchantment; of complex overlapping temporalities of ebb and flow; and a diffusion of narrative and political valences for these forms of enchantment. Enchantment becomes, in this telling, a more historical story than those told by Weber or Freud. By juxtaposing different phases of modern enchantment, this panel brings into focus some of the broad contours of this more heterogenous narrative.
column2: Haunted Modernity: Modes Of Enchantment In Nineteenth And Twentieth Century America

column1:
Dr. Valerie Ann Martinez (Our Lady of the Lake University)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

The purpose of the proposed roundtable is to unveil the sequence of events surrounding the 2016 debate over the creation, production, review, and final renunciation of the controversial textbook _Mexican American Heritage_ proposed by the Texas State Board of Education for its new Mexican American history elective for public school students. The University of Texas Textbook Review Committee, which consisted of six members under the guidance of Dr. Emilio Zamora, in collaboration with twenty-six other renowned scholars of Mexican American history from across the country, participated in the review, tabulation and final analysis of over 700 errors found within the textbook written and submitted by Momentum Instruction LLC. The roundtable will foreground the events within the larger context of debates over education reform beginning with the 2010 Texas K-12 revision of social studies standards and the instrumental role of the National Association of Chicana and Chicano Studies (NACCS), its Texas chapter known as NACCS Tejas Foco, and its affiliates in developing a Mexican American Studies K-12 curriculum. Participants will discuss in detail the public hearing process as well as the significance of the recorded testimonies. Public testimonies reveal the solidarity of an inter-ethnic coalition of community members including academics, politicians, students, and concerned citizens against the textbook as they passionately revealed the detrimental personal effects of learning a flawed and incorrect history. Our roundtable will conclude with an interpretive analysis of the larger implications of the production of knowledge and power in education, as well as the role and potential for mobilizing historians for government action.
column2: Historians And The Politics Of Ethnic Studies:  Lessons From The Mexican American History Textbook Fight In Texas

column1:
Professor Frank P Barajas ()

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 10:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Doing History Workshop

With virtual audiences that range in the thousands, historians well known as public intellectuals in various social media platforms come together to discuss and demonstrate their approach to building online identities based on their professional work. How did they do it? How has it impacted their professional work? How has it changed their notion of what it means to be a historian? What implications or possibilities might social media yield for our profession?
column2: Historians In The Twittersphere: Crafting Social Media Identities And History Publics

column1:
Mr. Rudi Batzell (Assistant Professor, Lake Forest College)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

The subfields of history that focus on labor and on capitalism certainly overlap in important ways, and yet they typically involve a different focus, framing questions, and methodology. This roundtable brings scholars from both fields to discuss what they can and should be learning from one another, as well as the opportunities for connecting the two subfields and for collaboration between the two. How might labor and working-class history benefit from looking more closely at corporate strategies or economic change? How might the history of capitalism benefit from more sustained attention to working-class politics, culture, and workplace action? The roundtable will take up these questions and more.
column2: Historians Of Capitalism And Labor–A Conversation

column1:
Dr. Yoni Appelbaum (The Atlantic)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Doing History Workshop

Newspaper op-ed pages, magazines, and digital publications are eager to publish work from scholars; many scholars are eager to be published in such outlets. This workshop is designed to help historians learn the mechanics of that process. We"ll look at identifying a subject for an essay, matching it to the right outlet, writing a compelling pitch, and mastering the craft of rendering the past accessible to popular audiences.
column2: Historians Writing For The Public

column1:
Dr. Thomas G Andrews (University of Colorado Boulder)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

The library, archival, and museum collections of the National Park Service (NPS) are as diverse as the parks themselves. Just as the history of the NPS and its parks intersects with many aspects of U.S. history, so too do the agencys collections of historical documents, photographs, architectural plans, and artifacts. Research materials held by the NPS primarily relate to the acquisition, development, and operation of the national parks and to the history of the events and landscapes that the parks commemorate, preserve, and interpret. But these collections are potentially useful not only to historians of the parks, the environment, and tourism, but also to scholars studying westward expansion, urban planning, the New Deal, the Civil War, historical memory, race relations, Progressivism, womens history, maritime history, and many other topics. Many historians outside of the NPS are unaware of the agencys archival and museum collections, while others are unsure how to gain access. This panel will introduce the types of historical research materials in the parks, libraries, and service centers of the National Park Service (NPS), discuss how to identify and access these materials, and identify under-examined sources and research topics. Panelists will also provide examples of how scholars have used NPS collections to explore a variety of topics in American history, and explore how research in NPS collections can reach beyond academia to shape the agencys research, operations, and policies.
column2: Historical Research In The National Parks: Resources And Opportunities

column1:
Professor Dan Bouk (Colgate University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Blank forms shape what information is recorded, shared, used, and saved. By structuring information, preprinted forms can powerfully structure, shift, and reinforce both political conversations and social relations. This panel explores the diverse ways historians can use and critique these forms, considering their influence on the practice of history. A diverse set of papers draws on examples spanning the 18th to the 20th centuries, considering such topics as occupational training, economic indicators, and daily life under the conditions of plantation slavery.
column2: Histories Of Forms And Forms Of History

column1:
Dr. Kriste Ann Lindenmeyer (Rutgers University-Camden)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

History Departments around the nation face declining numbers of majors and of students in general. Reasons include shifts in student interests, negative perceptions of a history degrees value, an expansion of ways for high school students to take history courses for university credit, and changes in general education curricula that increase non-majors ability to avoid history entirely. To meet these challenges, departments must be more creative and more willing to question their self-defined roles in order to defend their discipline. This roundtable will examine some of these factors and as well as identify ways to address them.
column2: History Enrollments: Declining Numbers And The Pursuit Of Effective Solutions

column1:
Scott Petersen (Producer/Director Hitchhiking to the Edge of Sanity)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Film Screening

Hitchhiking to the Edge of Sanity takes a look back to the turbulent social upheaval of the early 1970s and follows an idealistic writer and his soon-to-be-married photographer friend as they set out to find their purpose via a terrifying road trip across the Sahara Desert. Dissatisfied with Nixon and Vietnam War 1970, the two subjects of my film spent several months in Europe and Africa searching for and interacting with alternative political systems.In 1971 in Accra, Ghana, Steve Ewert woke up in a cold sweat. Bugs crawled out his mouth. Fear gripped his very soul. Im losing my mind! he cried repeatedly to his travel companion, Dick Russell. What started out as two young Kansas kids setting out to find themselves, turned to disillusionment and danger. Photographer Ewert and writer Russell trekked across Europe "Forrest Gump" fashion—meeting political figures, writers, photographers, and anarchists. Along the way, thieves stole their VW Bugs (twice!) and police almost arrested the pair in Amsterdam. If they were looking for unique experiences, Ewert and Russell certainly found them.But the most fascinating and dangerous part of the trip started when the pair crossed the Mediterranean and hitchhiked across the Sahara Desert, a 3000 mile trip that started in revolutionary hotspot Algeria and ended in sub-Saharan Ghana. With Ewert taking numerous pictures with his Nikon F and Russell prodigiously writing on his trusty Smith Corona Skyriter, the duo eventually took a ride with a multilingual Dutch revolutionary who would triumphantly quote from Chairman Maos "Little Red Book." Eventually, they made it out of the desert despite being perilously close to perishing more than once. "Hitchhiking to the Edge of Sanity" is their story of adventure, discontent, and, ultimately, friendship.
column2: Hitchhiking To The Edge Of Sanity

column1:
Daniel Janke (Northern Town Films)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Film Screening

Combining narrative storytelling and richly textured imagery in a 16-minute short animation, How People Got Fire tells the story of how the crow brought fire to their people. In the village of Carcross, in the Tagish First Nation, Grandma Kay relates the history. And 12-year-old Tish narrates the story of the present. Past and present alternate and come together in beautifully rendered visual sequences. The metaphor of fire conveys the ongoing struggle to keep alive a communitys cultural memory.Release date: February 2010 (New York City)Director: Daniel JankeScreenplay: Daniel JankeMusic composed by: Daniel JankeCast: Louise Profeit-LeBlanc, Austin Smith, Amy Smarch, Mae Hume, Jonnie-Lyn KushnirukProducers: Svend-Erik Eriksen, Martin Rose
column2: How People Got Fire

column1:
Professor Martha Biondi (Northwestern University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Kings life and legacy fifty years since his death serves as a useful example of the challenges historians face when studying a complex historical icon who has become a national holiday and monument. Kings role in organizing nonviolent direct action campaigns in 1963 Birmingham and 1968 Memphis offers contrasting forms that history can take under different times and circumstances. The two panelists will also use different forms of history through film, multimedia materials, music, and historical narrative to pose unanswered questions about King, the nature of the social movements he led, and the various ways we can and should translate our historical research and writings to stimulate public debate and inspiration for contemporary movements. Professor Carson has been a commentator or reviewer for most of the major civil rights documentary films and is now making a film about King and the Birmingham campaign of 1963. Michael Honey in 2016 launched a film on nonviolence, labor and civil rights and immigrant rights organizing, taking us from the 1960s to the present. Both presentations will include film clips from their films and each presenter will take 30-35 minutes, to leave 20-30 minutes for commentary and discussion introduced and moderated by Martha Biondi.
column2: How Should We Remember Martin Luther King, Jr.? Fifty Years Since Memphis,  His Controversial Life, Disputed Legacy, And Unfinished Agenda

column1:
Dr. Arica L. Coleman (Independent Historian and Time Magazine Contributor)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 11:30 to 13:00

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Luncheon

Independent scholars enjoy flexible work environments and the ability to pursue multiple research projects at once. However, these virtues are often tempered with concerns about uneven income streams, access to research databases, and professional association. This keynote luncheon panel will feature historians who work as independent scholars, speaking candidly about the joys and frustrations of this their chosen careers, and offering insights on the importance of independent scholarship for the discipline of history. This keynote luncheon panel will address the following questions: 1) Why pursue a career as an independent scholar? 2) How does the work of independent scholars differ from that of public historians? 3) What challenges do independent scholars face in gaining full access to research libraries? How might Independent Scholars work with universities, the OAH, and other organizations to open access? 4) How do independent scholars enlarge and diversify the historical profession, and how might academia collaborate with and support the growing number of independent scholars? 5) What approaches and ethics do historians share, regardless of the venues in which they work?
column2: Independent Scholars Luncheon: The Independent Scholars Life: Opportunities And Challenges

column1:
Dr. Mikaela Morgane Adams (University of Mississippi)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

When considering the subject of Native Americans and medicine, a few topics tend to predominate. Population decline from Old World diseases, the mystical role of medicine people, public health problems on reservations, and the forced sterilization of American Indian women are a few of the most frequently studied issues. Many such studies unfortunately treat Native people and knowledge in isolation, absent the historical, social, and cultural contexts from which they emerge. The papers in this panel demonstrate the importance of studying American Indian health and wellness within the context of national and international developments, linking discrete moments and key episodes to broader trends in medicine, politics, and popular culture. The session shows that familiar topics within Native American history, namely Indian removal, representations of Indianness, and federal assimilation policies can be productively reconsidered by examining them through the lens of health and well-being. The papers simultaneously demonstrate how subjects within broader U.S. history and the history of medicine, such as the 1830s cholera outbreak, 19th-c. debates on medical and social reform, and the 1918 influenza pandemic, can be fruitfully explored from the perspective of American Indian studies. The session further demonstrates how discourses of power and identity were formed and reformed at the intersection of indigeneity and medicine. The proposed panel consists of three presentations on American Indians and the history of medicine ranging from the antebellum period through the end of World War I. Paul Keltons work focuses on the experiences of indigenous people during the era of Indian removal. His paper explores the role that cholera played during the forced internment and migration of Native communities from their eastern homelands to Indian Territory. Kelton argues that Indian suffering in the cholera outbreak was not the result of deficient immunity but was a direct consequence of a national policy of ethnic cleansing. Had eastern Indians been permitted to remain in their ancestral territories where they could manage the impact of the outbreak, a real American medical tragedy might have been avoided. Angela Pulley Hudsons study considers the emergence of Indian doctresses as urban medical practitioners during the middle of the 19th century. She investigates how these women (some Native, some not) performed Indianness in the context of an exploding market in healthcare, analyzing how their identities and activities shaped and were shaped by popular notions of indigenous womanhood. Her paper focuses on a series of these urban entrepreneurs from the 1840s through the 1870s, examining their careers in the context of mid-century reforms. Mikaëla Morgane Adamss paper addresses the devastating influenza pandemic at the end of World War I by focusing on its spread to the Haskell Institute, an Indian boarding school. She explores the impact of the disease on students, staff, and their families, using their experiences to illuminate the aggressive assimilation policies that underlay the operation of such institutions. Adams argues that the influenza outbreak at Haskell allows us to consider how the guardian/ward rhetoric of federal Indian policy influenced Native health and well-being.
column2: Indigenizing American Medical History: New Approaches To Health And Sickness In Native America

column1:
Dr. Brian W Frehner (University of Missouri-Kansas City)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

The imposition of legal structures was central to the consolidation of U.S. government authority over Indigenous peoples, their lands and resources in the American West during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. This modified paper session examines the various kinds of legal borderlands that this produced and that Indigenous peoples in the North American West were forced to negotiate on a variety of scales. Organized around the three papers described below with two discussants, Erik Meeks and Michel Hogue, the session will function more like a roundtable, with all five participants taking just ten minutes to address the themes raised in the papers before opening the discussion to the audience. Jeff Shepherds paper reflects on ways in which members of the Blackfoot Confederacy negotiated both the U.S.-Canada border and reservation boundaries, as well newly imposed racialized identities. Brian Frehner considers ways in which Choctaw people responded to the imposition of exploitative legal structures intended to facilitate the taking of natural resources from their reservation, in some cases turning them to their own purposes and empowering themselves. Andrea Geiger examines the courtroom itself as a legal borderland and site of both cultural contact and colonial encounter, drawing on a series of linked cases in which five indigenous men were charged with murder in Alaska in 1902 after a traditional legal sanction imposed on another member of their community went awry.
column2: Indigenous Legal Borderlands In North America

column1:
Keola Awong (Hawaii Volcanoes National Park)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

National park units are located in the ancestral homelands of sovereign Indigenous nations, and while traditional stewardship of and cultural practices in those areas have continued over time, they have been influenced by changes in activism, legislation, agency structure, and policy. Speakers from different regions including California, the Great Lakes, the Southwest, and Hawaii will share the ways that Indigenous communities have worked to ensure that their perspectives are incorporated into park management, hiring practices, natural and cultural resource stewardship, and visitor services, including interpretation and education programs. A number of related questions will be addressed, such as: What strategies or tools have Indigenous communities used to influence park management policies? What impact have laws, including the American Indian Religious Freedom Act of 1978 and the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act of 1990, had on relationships? What have Indigenous communities gained from relationships with the NPS: are there noteworthy successes or illustrative challenges that remain unresolved? Discussion will also focus on program areas in which Indigenous perspectives, history, and culture have yet to be considered or integrated into NPS management.
column2: Indigenous People And The National Park Service: The Second Century

column1:
Ms. Emily Elisabeth Esten (Brown University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

In recent years, history graduate programs have encouraged and incorporated more public history and digital humanities training into the graduate student practicum. The influx of new pedagogy promises to reach audiences outside the academy as well as reshape the discipline and how it communicates historical accounts. Our panel seeks to build on these developments and articulate how the increasing intersection of public and digital histories affect how graduate students produce scholarship, how they will teach their own courses, and how to contribute to the discourse of what it means to be a humanities scholar in the twenty-first century. Our panel discussion examines three themes: reaching public history audiences, how and what the fine arts and liberal arts can teach each other about digital communication, and the emerging field of digital public humanities. Matthew Reeves discussion takes on the challenge of exploring the concept of double empathy and argues that historians must deploy empathy for both their subjects and modern audiences. Marc Reyes contribution discusses what he learned assisting a course outside the history department and what digital media, design, and history departments can learn from each other to produce cutting-edge scholarship and greater digital media literacy. Emily Estens presentation blazes a new path by probing the relationship between digital public humanities and traditional historical scholarship and how historians are shaping critical digital pedagogy. All three approaches – audience empathy, digital interdisciplinary, digital public humanities – offer historians novel interpretive tools and insights for our cacophonous digital age. Panel chair Tom Scheinfeldt, a pioneer in the field of digital humanities, will provide the contextual frame for the assembled papers and guide the discussion. This panel, consisting of graduate students at different phases of their training, intends to examine the intersection of public and digital histories and what that means for the humanities both inside and outside the classroom. Despite the OAH Programming Committees concerns regarding all graduate student presenters, we feel our panel necessary to comment on real-time changes in the training of historians and what these changes mean for the future of the discipline. Our field is constantly changing, and the OAH is changing with it: increased audio/video recording and indexing represents a best practice for making information accessible within the profession and for the public. As current graduate students with experience in the classroom and with public-facing projects, we are excited for these changes and our papers explore similar emerging practices. Our panel answers the OAHs call for presentations that explicitly address new ideas for the classroom and redefine the boundaries of modern digital scholarship. Marc Reyes: 89 North Street, Willimantic, CT, 06226, marc.reyes@uconn.edu, (816) 405-7219, University of ConnecticutEmily Esten: John Nicholas Brown Center for Public Humanities & Cultural Heritage, Brown University, Box 1880, Providence, RI 02912, emily_esten@brown.edu, (774) 644-7523, Brown UniversityMatthew Reeves: 9322 West 49th Terrace, Merriam, KS 66203, marx93@mail.umkc.edu, (913) 802-9252, University of Missouri-Kansas CityTom Scheinfeldt: Bishop Center, Room 243, Storrs, CT 06269, tom.scheinfeldt@uconn.edu, (860)-486-4862, University of Connecticut
column2: Intersections Digital And Public: Emerging Perspectives On Digital Pedagogy, Scholarship, And Audience Engagement

column1:
Melanie Chambliss (Northwestern University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel examines the historical preservation and archival assembly undertaken by three African Americans between the end of the nineteenth century and the 1950s. These individuals – Arturo Schomburg, William Henry Dorsey, and L. S. Alexander Gumby – were deeply invested in both preserving the historical achievements of people of African descent and creating a record of people and events that could be used to study African American history. Intended for a range of private and public audiences, the collections that they amassed became part of a broader argument about the contributions of Black people to world history and U.S. culture.In keeping with the theme of the 2018 OAH Annual Meeting, this panel examines the forms and functions of history when used to establish and preserve a historical record during the strengthening of Jim Crow policies. The process of constructing and then using African American history over the course of several decades during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries enables scholars to better understand the political functions of African American archives and historical memory.Each of the three panelists focus their paper on a Black collector and explain the intended purposes of their collections, the creators archival methodologies, and the diverse ways in which individuals used these collections. The paper presented by Melanie Chambliss analyzes the now-famous collection of Arturo Schomburg whose documents became the foundation of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in New York City. She writes about Schomburgs work of historical recovery using diverse sources of Black history that Schomburg assembled to produce a non-traditional form of history that centered the lives of African descended people. Aston Gonzalezs paper traces the growth of the collection amassed by Black Philadelphian William Henry Dorsey who collected hundreds of thousands of visual, textual, and material records of African American intellectuals and politicians during and after the Civil War. White and Black Americans studied his collection, W. E. B. Du Bois used its materials to write his landmark study The Philadelphia Negro, and Dorsey donated much of his archive to one of the first historical societies established to preserve and celebrate African American history. Kristin Gilgers essay scrutinizes the production of more than 150 scrapbooks by L. S. Alexander Gumby, a largely understudied figure of the Harlem Renaissance. She writes about the community that he fostered as he entertained prominent Black artists in his home and the collective Black identity that he modeled in his voluminous scrapbooks.The papers on the panel explore and answer questions at the foundation of the historical practice. They provide scholars with three examples by which to study the multifaceted relationships between historical actors and those who recorded their actions. The panel offers insights into the intent and methodologies of Black archivists, the evidence they compiled, and the audiences to which they aimed their sometimes radical racial and political appeals.
column2: Intervention And Recovery: Assembling Black Archives In The United States

column1:
Dr. Cara Caddoo (Indiana University, Bloomington)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Historians often look to print media for documentation of what we already know to be important. We mine the black press for civil rights stories; we read newspaper headlines to confirm our sense of the national and international events that mattered; and we write the histories of papers of record, such as the New York Times and Washington Post, that are still widely read. Yet our notions of what must be important can blind us to the actual media landscape of the past. This panel assembles three projects that reconstruct the print media of the Gilded Age and Progressive era. The three papers ask simple questions that reveal new stories: what kinds of media actually traveled through the mail? What array of newspapers did Americans actually read? What stories and morals did print media actually communicate each day? Cara Caddoos paper considers the black weeklies of Memphis, Tennessee. One of these, the Free Speech, is known almost entirely for Ida B. Wellss editorials that denounced the practice of lynching. But Caddoo looks beyond these few famous editorials to the everyday contents of Memphiss black weeklies and finds something else—a constant emphasis on property as a symbol of security and success. Richard Popps study assesses postal traffic to reveal an enormous trade in cheap magazines—essentially, Gilded Age junk mail. Popp turns the 1870s and 1880s media market itself into the story, and takes a fresh look at the kinds of materials that millions of Americans received in their mail boxes. His paper finds a center of publishing not in New York or Chicago but in Augusta, Maine, and trawls the flimsy pages of the Peoples Literary Companion rather than the glossy pages of Cosmopolitan or McClures magazine. Julia Guarneris paper examines the Hearst chain of newspapers but looks beyond the companys flagship titles and past Hearsts most brazen decades of sensational journalism. Hearsts papers of the 1910s and 1920s, mostly operating in medium-sized cities, contain little remarkable journalism. Yet their business model—which catered to local tastes using a nationalized, generic template—allowed a mass media to win over varied audiences throughout the United States. All three panelists get at hidden stories by paying attention to the economics of media. Caddoo is interested not only in the economic lessons that the black press taught its readers, but also in the economy that made the black press possible; she discusses the ways that black owners and readers used their own properties to produce and consume the news. Popp studies the material economy of junk mail alongside the economic rationale for blanketing the country with cheaply-produced magazines. Guarneri shows how, in an era of mergers and syndication, a concern for the bottom line produced generic yet profitable city papers. Because economics are central to our questions about media, we have asked Richard John to serve as commentator. We look forward to hearing Johns take, as a historian of media and business, on the media landscapes that we evaluate in our papers.
column2: Junk Mail, Generic Papers, And Real Estate News: The Unread Media Of The Gilded Age And Progressive Era

column1:
Cecil E Canton (California Faculty Association)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

Historians probe the lives of working people and are themselves workers. We do our research and teaching in settings that are surrounded by work and deeply impacted by labor and other social justice struggles. This roundtable session brings together rank and file worker-leaders of university-based labor unions from across California who are organizing for dignity on the job—from regular and adjunct faculty to TAs to service and patient-care workers—and against the corporatization of higher education. They are also connecting their labor activism to a wide range of social justice movements, from #BlackLivesMatter to immigrant rights to LGBT struggles and beyond. And in so doing, they are forging a new model for democratic organizing to resist the neoliberal university and the erosion of public education.
column2: Labor And The University

column1:
Professor William John Bauer (University of Nevada, Las Vegas)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

California is a center of American Indian history. In the sixteenth century, the area now known as California was the most diverse area in North America, boasting a population of between 300,000 and 1,000,000 people and nearly 100 different languages. Beginning in the late eighteenth century, Spanish, Mexican, Russian and American invaders imposed their own colonial regimes on Indigenous people, which included forced labor, reductions to missions, ethnic cleansing and genocide. The invasion of California precipitated a catastrophic population decline; perhaps 30,000 California Indians survived the waves of colonists. In the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, California Indian people reconstituted their communities through wage labor and purchasing land, and constructed the foundation for the revitalization of their nations in the late twentieth century. In 1988, the Supreme Court case California vs. Cabazon Band of Mission Indians opened new possibilities for American Indian gaming. Today, California has the largest population of American Indians in the United States. California Indian history has been at the middle of debates about the past. Recently, scholars have centered California in histories of genocide, ethnic cleaning and violence, the structure of settler colonialism and the dynamics processes by which Indigenous peoples practiced survivance and persistence. This panel addresses those historical and contemporary significance of American Indians in California. This panel examines the forms and politics of California Indian history. It pays attention to the different historical methods and sources that exist in California Indian communities, such as land and basketry. In addition, it explores how California Indians deploy their histories to reinterpret the past, fight for land and protect resources. William Bauer argues that California Indian used their oral traditions to discuss and interpret their past, present and future. Concows possessed a visual understanding of the past; when they saw their landmarks they could recall stories about their history. Concows then used these histories to reinterpret California history and claim land in the Sacramento Valley. Vanessa Esquivido-Meza considers the gendered labor involved in making baskets. Esquivido-Meza positions California Idnain women at a the center of a story involving land, plants and history. Finally, Khal Schneider examines the legacies of treaty making in California. In the 1850s, California Indians signed treaties with the United States, but the Senate failed to ratify the documents. In 1929, the Indians of California sued the United States for the land claims. In order to grain compensation for these ungratified documents, California Indians and reformers crafted a version of the states history that supported Indigenous rights and politics.All three presenters are members of California Indian communities. Clifford Trafzer, Rupert Costo Chair of American Indian History at UC Riverside, will chair the session.
column2: Land, Baskets And Treaties: The Forms And Politics Of California Indian Histories In The Twentieth Century

column1:
Gergely Baics (Barnard College)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

Confronting a nation that incorporates so many iconic cities, spectacular urban growth, stark social and racial inequalities, suburbs, and ex-urbs, Americas urban historians have found plenty worthy of study without casting their eyes beyond the countrys borders. Their research has now created a complex and convincing narrative of urban life that hinges on the turning points of the American story; Revolution, the Rise of Capitalism, Civil War, Great Migrations, Great Depressions, Post-War Crisis, and Civil Rights.At the same time, those scholars who do not consider themselves urbanists are now deeply engaged in the project of writing histories that situate America in transnational and global places and that acknowledge the spatial turn. Now underway is a three-part Cambridge History of America and the World, a series that will certainly institutionalize some of these trends in the field. Over the past few years the OAHs annual meeting has incorporated an increasing number of panels approaching issues from a transnational and urban perspective. Often, urban historians have been part of these efforts that have nevertheless principally focused on the twentieth century.Now is the time to move towards a more expansive inquiry into American cities and the global urban panorama. Producing such a history is certainly an ambitious project. However, the small scale of the individual city lends itself to providing insights into how large-scale, global, processes play out at ground level. Indeed, it is precisely the potential of cities to address the scalar issues that are at the heart of global history that makes the project of a global urban history so compelling. Fulfilling this potential requires American urban historians to reach across not only national borders, but also the time and space of the U.S. past. In this spirit, our round table brings together five scholars who, with their expertise, cover this past between 1600 and 2000. All are committed to realizing the potential of global urban history in an American setting. The brief presentations of each participant will leave ample time for discussion of the issues involved in pursuing large-scale projects such as these. It is our hope that both the panel and the audience will benefit from an improved understanding of the central issues, benefits, and questions involved in approaching the American urban past on a global scale.
column2: Large Scale Forms Of U.S. Urban History

column1:
Professor Mario T Garcia (University of California, Santa Barabara)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This paper session will cover the political histories of Latina/o religious communities in the 1970s that begins with a simple premise: Latina/o politics are religious politics. By that we mean that religion is fundamental to understanding Latina/o politics and social movements in the United States. The pendulum of Latina/o religious politics oscillates between a strict adherence to fundamentalist thought and an acknowledgement of religions liberative force. Two sides of the same coin that are critical to understanding Latina/o religious politics. But religion is never just an institutional force with strict gatekeepers; its historical power has come from the people—from those who sit in the pews—and from clergy whos reading of the Biblical text has moved them to political action. This is where we believe our paper session can contribute to ongoing conversations about Latina/o civil rights and politics in the 1970s. This is a conversation that we believe is sorely needed because the linkage of faith or religion to political activism has been a sorely neglected field in Latina/o history. Latina/o historians like others in Latina/o Studies seem to believe—incorrectly—that faith and politics represent two separate spheres. Yet in reality, faith, both Catholic and non-Catholic has been an important aspect of Latina/o political history, but one not well documented. Faith-based movements have been documented with respect to César Chávez and the farm workers movement; Reies López Tijerina and the land grant movement in New Mexico in the late 1960s; and of Católicos Por La Raza in Los Angeles as a Chicano Movement faith-based group. Some similar documentation has also occurred with respect to some Protestant groups. As a whole, however, the linkage between faith and politics remains a large gap in Chicana/o and Latina/o historiography. Our paper session brings together historians from around the United States and the Netherlands for a conversation on the central role Latina/o religious politics has played in major cities such as Chicago, Los Angeles, and Houston. Anne Martinez will present a paper on her research on the via crucis reenactments in Pilsen, the long-established Mexican neighborhood in Chicago, where the via crucis has been performed since the late 1970s. She challenges notions that religion serves as a palliative, rather than a source for community formation toward activism. Mario T. Garcia will present a paper on his on-going biography of Fr. Luis Olivares who is best known for being the key leader of the sanctuary movement in Los Angeles in the 1980s. Garcia will explore Olivares earlier experiences with faith-based politics with the United Neighborhoods Organization (UNO) from 1975 to 1980 and prior to his engagement with the sanctuary movement. Felipe Hinojosa will present a paper on how urban renewal programs and white flight brought together two unlikely allies in a struggle to deal with a changing neighborhood in Houston"s Northside. White Presbyterians and Mexican American activists negotiated the politics of a neighborhood in transition even as they fiercely debated the role the church could and should play in community activism, politics, and social change.
column2: Latina/O Religious Politics In The 1970s: Suffering, Hope, And Activism

column1:
Ms. Alisha Joy Hines (Duke University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Liberal social theory has long posited a firm and stable divide between the private realm of domestic relations and the public realm of market relations. Historians of women and gender have consistently challenged this binary. This panel contributes to that revisionism by considering the ways in which the family was actively constructed in relation to large-order projects of commodification. Taking moments of enslavement, insolvency, and inheritance as their respective points of departure, the papers on this panel offer new perspectives on the history of the domestic realm and illuminate fresh links between race, gender, and the history of capitalism.Jessica Marie Johnson examines French Atlantic codes and statutes which sought to legislate sex between African women and European men. By engaging practices of sex and manumission in the Caribbean before the 1685 Code Noir, Johnson considers ways African women navigated out of bondage alongside anxieties expressed by colonial officials over how to deal with the mixed-race offspring in their midst. Alisha Hines considers black women who took on the legal posture of white men in antebellum court rooms by claiming and pursuing protection of their right to property. In the cases she considers, black women employed the language of property and possession to claim rights to their children and their childrens labor. These particular performances of legal personhood are significant in the context of a multiplicity of legal avenues that were available to black women in pursuit of their freedom and freedom for their kin. She hopes to explore the ways in which accessing certain scripts in the antebellum legal theater shaped and re-shaped black womens notions of gender, family, and freedom. Daniel Platt examines the history of property exemption law in the postbellum period, focusing on how borrowers and lenders struggled to fix the ambit of the generous legal protections afforded to insolvent heads of family households. Confronted with a diversity of unconventional family forms, jurists weighed kin-based definitions of the domestic against dependency-based definitions, ultimately privileging hierarchical models of family life drawn from pro-slavery discourse. These cases show, the surprising durability of pre-emancipation legal logics and the role of market entanglements in concretizing the family as a usable legal category in the Gilded Age.The new history of capitalism has drawn attention to under examined aspects of Americas economic past and has helped scholars recognize the centrality of the commodification of land, natural resources, and labor, especially reproductive labor, to the history of the Atlantic World. Questions of human agency and of the naturalizing power of different discursive tropes have recently received less attention, however. By exploring the entwined history of family, property, and market, this panel seeks to demonstrate the value of feminist analysis to the revived study of political economy as well as advance scholarship on the circuitous and contested history of natural domestic relations.
column2: Law, Family, And The Logics Of Commodification

column1:
Dr. Dan Berger (University of Washington Bothell)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

Mass incarceration raises several questions about the forms of history. While prisons are, in general, state institutions, they do not present ready access to their archives. Much of what we know about what transpires inside of them owes to other sources: namely, prisoner testimonials or autobiographies, and court records. Episodic riots also provide occasional media reports. As the study of mass incarceration occupies increasing space in historical scholarship and classrooms, this roundtable investigates the forms and stakes of prison history. In particular, we will discuss the methodological and pedagogical challenges raised by putting prisons and prisoners at the center of analysis. The roundtable is occasioned by the publication of Rethinking the American Prison Movement (Routledge, forthcoming fall 2017). Aimed at undergraduate and high school audiences, this textbook is the first broad survey of prisoner activism between Reconstruction and the present. The book outlines different forms of prisoner activism in response to convict leasing, political repression, prison managerialism, and the shift from rehabilitative incarceration to punitive incapacitation. These include micropolitical challenges to prison slavery, lawsuits targeting religious persecution or sexual violence, spontaneous uprising against racism and violence, mutual aid networks to provide health care and peer education, and popular pressure campaigns waged by outside supporters to free incarcerated dissidents. This roundtable brings together scholars focused on different historical periods of study, from the late nineteenth century to the postwar period, to discuss how the function of prisons changed from one of forced labor to one of mass warehousing. It also connects traditional historians with scholars working in both legal studies and literary studies to discuss the different interpretive frameworks needed to research, write, and teach about prisons. We will consider the prison not only as a conceptual and physical space for making history, but also the ways in which scholars use forms of history to explore different modes of engaging prisons. We will also discuss the Prison Abolition Syllabus and other recent public history efforts, such as the States of Incarceration project at the Humanities Action Lab, which provide alternate modes of connecting this history to contemporary discussions about mass incarceration and prison abolition.
column2: Law, Resistance, And The Forms Of Prison History: Roundtable On Rethinking The American Prison Movement

column1:
Professor James N Gregory (University of Washington)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 11:30 to 13:00

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Luncheon

Based on new insights from the online Mapping American Social Movements Project, this talk will reframe the history of the American left in two ways. First, by emphasizing that for most of the last century, radicalism in the US has been based in multiple social movements not electoral parties. This social movement left has been more discontinuous and more innovative than its counterparts in most countries and operates in different ways, achieving influence through alliances and through channels that have often involved the Democratic Party. Second, by exploring the nations political geography. The left has mattered in some places much more than others and radical geography has changed over time. By paying attention to the institutional dynamics and geographic complexity of this social movement left, we gain a fuller understanding of how it has operated and what it has accomplished over the past century.
column2: Lawcha Luncheon & Annual Meeting: Remapping The History Of American Radicalism

column1:
Dr. Mary R.S. Bracy (Independent Historian)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

Collaboration is an unusual practice in the history profession. Historians isolate themselves in their research, test ideas at conferences, and make brief sojourns to libraries away from home. While academic conferences and scholarly publishing offer historians an opportunity to share their research with other academics, we must expand our understanding of collaboration beyond the peer review process. The profession is moving, albeit slowly, toward more inter-departmental, co-authored, and cooperative relationships. A 2004 Journal of American History roundtable highlighted the beneficial aspects of Interchange between scholars, and the various forms in which we present our research. Historians increasingly venture outside their offices, classrooms, and disciplines to collaborate on popular representations of history such as films, games, preservation sites, and graphic histories. These kinds of collaborations shift away from the lecturer-audience relationship, engage the public with different perspectives, invigorate our field, and invite people to share in the appreciation and study of history through different mediums. Working with various people and institutions, our panel concluded that collaboration is a necessity for producing physical and digital venues for teaching history. The majority of this presentation should be viewed as a case study of a graduate programs efforts to convey history to the public. Three of our panelists discuss their experiences working on the museum exhibit Ready to Roar. Shae Cox, the Project Manager, provides an in-depth discussion of the logistics for overseeing the accessioning, housing, handling, and display of material objects from six museums as well as individual lenders from across the nation. Alan Mattay, Ready to Roars Digital Curator, examines the collaborative process of creating an expanded digital exhibit for UNLVs public history website. Lee Hanover, Head of the Research Team for Ready to Roar, demonstrates the value of collaborative label writing that maintains scholarly research while being accessible to the general public. Billy Marino examines the contribution of his work, Atomic Liquors, to Intermountain Histories, a website and mobile application which brings together several regional universities as part of a collaborative digital history project. Mary Ruth Sanders reexamines how teaching--specifically teaching difficult topics such as the history of terrorism--benefits from a variety of collaborations on different levels. Associate professor of history at UNLV and the chair of the OAH Membership Committee, Michael Green, will chair and comment for this session. Our panel will experiment with the traditional academic conference format by incorporating digital, visual, and tactile components, which highlight various forms of collaboration as an integral facet of the stories we tell.
column2: Levels Of Collaboration: Presenting University Research Through Public And Private Institutions

column1:
Ms. Mary Jo Binker (Eleanor Roosevelt Papers)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

As the first American president, George Washington was keenly aware that each of his actions potentially set a precedent that would influence his successors, and he worried about the implications of everything from affairs of state to details of dress and social etiquette. The lives of presidents and their wives after their departure from the executive mansion also have a history, and it deserves more attention. From Washington on, statesmen leaving the highest office have worried about the proper role of a former head of state while looking for ways to extend their influence or enhance their legacy. In an era before anyone thought of pensions for ex-presidents or their spouses and the very concept of retirement was in its infancy, what ways of obtaining an income were acceptable and what would shame them or tarnish their former office? Similarly, what forms of public service or attempts to benefit the nation with their experience would be beneficial and which would be dismissed as shameful, unworthy attempts to hang on to the loaves and fishes of office? A few presidents, such as John Quincy Adams and William Howard Taft, accepted elective or appointed office after leaving the White House, and even some former first ladies, such as Dolley Madison, found it possible to play a rather public role at the center of power. More often, statesmen and women who wished to remain involved in public affairs did so less directly and in a wide variety of ways.This session looks at the increasingly varied and complex role played by former presidents and their spouses. Featuring documentary editors from three prominent publishing projects, it presents test cases spanning more than a century, spread across different regions, and including both genders. Andrea R. Gray looks at Thomas Jeffersons involvement in all aspects of the highly visible effort to create a nondenominational, state-funded university while balancing this very public act against his strong desire for personal privacy and the tactical need to conceal his lobbying efforts from a legislature in which he still had many enemies. Ryan Semmes examines Ulysses S. Grants world tour, which has often been portrayed as a purely private sightseeing expedition, but which seems rather to have had wide-reaching diplomatic implications of which Grant was fully aware and which he hoped to use as a springboard to a third presidential term. Mary Jo Binker writes on the centrality of Eleanor Roosevelts Val-Kill home to her postwar career as a leading exemplar of human rights and democratic values using material drawn from her syndicated newspaper column, My Day. Burton Kaufman, the dean of historians of presidential retirements who is currently working on a biography of Barack Obama, will comment on the papers, point to the many ways that documentation for recent as well as older presidencies is now becoming accessible, and pull together the common threads and potential for further work before opening the session to discussion from the floor.
column2: Life After The White House

column1:
Dr. Rudy P Guevarra (Jr. Arizona State University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Paul Spickard, "Shape Shifters: A Theory of Racial Change." We are accustomed to thinking of identities—racial, ethnic, etc.—as if they were unalterable features of individuals and groups. A is Black, B is Jewish, C is Chinese, and so are all of the members of their respective families and kin groups, and so must they remain. In the American West, many people have changed identities over the course of their lives, or over generations in families, as they have moved from one social context to another, or as new social rules have been imposed on them. This is not racial, ethnic, or religious imposture. It is simply the way that people"s lives have unfolded in fluid social circumstances. Spickard presents a theory for understanding the shape, means, and meanings of racial change, based on the life stories of several such shape shifters from the American West.Rana Razek, "Between Arab and Black: Zammouri, Race, and Arab American Identity, examines competing narratives of Zammouri (Estebanico), the Muslim Moroccan slave brought to the Americas on the ill-fated 1527 Narváez expedition. One of the few survivors, Zammouri was a translator, healer, guide, and scout, and was reportedly killed by Zuni Indians in what is now New Mexico. Arab Americans and African Americans both lay claim to Zammouris legacy of discovery and conquest, in order to enhance their claim to inclusion. For the Zuni, rather, Zammouri was a harbinger of conquest and colonial violence, and is memorialized as Chakwaina, the black monster kachina. From the Native perspective, Zammouri represents the beginning of a long and violent history of colonization that continues to the present day. For Arab and African Americans, Zammouris position as a Black/African/Arab/Muslim/Slave and non-European is essential to the story. These opposing narratives speak to issues of race, power, and colonialism then and now. Zammouris changing racial identity illuminates Arab American racialization and racial in-betweenness; if early twentieth-century Syrian Americans were positioned somewhere between Arab and White, today, Arab Americans have drifted demonstrably toward the dark end of the racial spectrum.David Torres-Rouff, "West of Jim Crow: A Conceptual and Empirical Framework." What happens when Jim Crows structural function is separated from the crucible of Black-White relations in the post- Reconstruction South? I argue that policies and practices we call Jim Crow also arose in the North American Southwest beginning in the eighteenth century and developed within successively Spanish, Mexican, and American intercultural communities.
