Without recourse to chattel slavery as a touchstone for social, political, and economic relations, people in the Southwest developed institutions that defined and differentiated racial hierarchies; that sponsored unfree labor and imprisonment for profit; and that relied on legal and extralegal violence to impose social and spatial segregation. On what knowledge did Southern Whites rely when developing what we now call Jim Crow? Did the Southwest provide a model, and did a direct transfer of knowledge take place? Addressing Jim Crow"s long shadow requires a reckoning of its compound, multiregional origins and its multiracial history.
column2: Making Race In The American West

column1:
Ms. Emma Balbina Amador (University of Michigan)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

The OAH Membership Committee invites new members, first-time attendees, and graduate students to discuss the benefits of membership in the organization and attendance at the annual meeting. Meet with members of the OAH Membership Committee and learn how the OAH can help you in your history career. Regardless of whether you are a graduate student, public historian, history educator, faculty member, or independent historian, the OAH can help you accomplish your career goals.
column2: Making The Most Of The Oah

column1:
Dr. Heather Armstrong Dron (UCSF)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

The 1970s ushered in major changes in American medicine. Strict standards of informed consent spurred by the consumer and womens health movements reshaped the doctor-patient relationship. Simultaneously, a resurgence in midwifery challenged mainstream prenatal care and childbirth practices. But did these newly won rights extend to womens ability to make their own medical decisions during pregnancy and childbirth? Much of the literature on womens reproductive rights in the post-World War II era has focused on the legalization of and womens access to abortion and contraception. These papers instead turn attention to the rights and status of pregnant women in the decades after Roe v. Wade and Eisenstadt v. Baird to reveal womens ability to make medical decisions about themselves, their fetuses, and their providers as a contested arena.Using a reproductive justice framework, this panel takes a fresh look at the state of pregnancy and maternity care in America in the 1970s and 1980s, focusing specifically on medical experimentation and the law. Heather Drons paper examines the FDA"s effort to exclude pregnant and potentially pregnant women from clinical trials in the wake of the thalidomide disaster, leading to 1977 federal guidelines that banned testing of investigational drugs on women of childbearing potential. It then explores the long-term implications of this policy for pregnant women who consumed medications without knowing potential risks and benefits to themselves and their fetuses. Rebecca Kluchins paper tracks the rise of forced cesarean sections in the 1980s when hospitals and doctors asked courts to compel pregnant patients to accept medical treatment on behalf of their fetuses. It demonstrates the extent to which the politics of fetal personhood shaped pregnancy and childbirth and compares the ways lawyers and doctors used Roe to make opposing claims: one side argued that Roe required women who chose to continue their pregnancies to sacrifice on behalf of their fetuses while the other side insisted that Roe granted women the right to prioritize their health over that of their fetus. Wendy Klines paper identifies legal pressure placed upon lay midwives in the mid-1970s, focusing in particular on the arrest of California midwife Kate Bowland for practicing medicine without a license. Women demanded changes in their maternity care and midwives responded, but the state and organized medicine used the courts to block these efforts and employed Roe in their legal attempts to discredit lay midwives. This paper studies the tensions this created among providers and the limits such lawsuits placed on womens choices in childbirth for decades thereafter. This panel will include three papers and a chair, but comments will be given by the audience only. Each scholar will have twenty minutes to deliver her paper and each paper will be followed by five minutes of audience questions. The last fifteen minutes of the panel will be devoted to discussion between the audience and panel about all three papers. This panel will be chaired by Jacqueline Wolf, an expert in womens health and medicine who has written extensively on childbirth in America.
column2: Maternal Health, Fetal Health And U.S. Law, 1970-1990

column1:
Professor Sari Altschuler (Northeastern University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Science is not value-neutral or color-blind, as twentieth-century philosophers and historians were at great pains to demonstrate. They received strong push-back at the time, but weve come a long way since then. In this current age of Fake News, the very phrase studies show prompts a skeptical response. Rather than dismiss all science as equally skewed, historians can show what kind of politics certain lines of scientific inquiry promoted, and which moral and political values underlay specific scientific presumptions. This interdisciplinary panel looks at different moments in the American past, when medical theories about the body and about disease served as ammunition for or against radical social projects. The first paper highlights the links between chemistry and radical religious ideas. Kirsten Fischer (Assoc. Prof., History, Minnesota) examines medical vitalism in the 1790s, according to which a vital power animates the tiniest particles of matter. Some vitalists concluded that the bio-chemical processes of life required no transcendent Creator-God, and their vitalist theories led to a radical (and heretical) rethinking of Christianity and all other revealed religions. Eric Herschthal (Ph.D. candidate, History, Columbia), by contrast, shows how medical theories hindered a radical project, namely abolition on a transnational scale. Herschthal explains how medical explanations of yellow fever in the U.S. and Great Britain hampered the abolitionist movement in the 1790s and diminished hopes for Sierra Leone as an abolitionist colony. Sari Altschuler (Assistant Prof., English, Emory) also focuses on theories of disease, but to different ends. During the cholera pandemic of the 1830s, abolitionists deployed theories of the spread of cholera to oppose slavery. Both Herschthal and Altschuler demonstrate that the way people understood the movement of microbes containing yellow fever and cholera shaped the racial politics in each case. A comment on these papers will come from Joyce Chaplin (Prof., History, Harvard), a renowned expert on cultural histories of science. We hope the audience will join us in a discussion of how to think about the intertwining of moral values, political agenda, and scientific projects, past and present. (This panel is diverse in terms of academic discipline, rank, and gender.)
column2: Medical Science And Radical Moralities In The Early United States

column1:
Verenize Arceo (University of California, Merced)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Although migration has long been a central theme in U.S. history, social and cultural historians quest to establish the subjectivity of previously marginalized immigrant groups has transformed the discipline. Re-centering immigrants and their histories has been key, first to the cultural, and then the transnational turn, as migration, community formation, and the development of social identity have become touchstones of North American social and cultural history. The papers in this panel build on these developments, revealing new insights as to the forms of history as both practice and profession. As practice, the works to be presented suggest that exploring immigrants in their local contexts is an essential form of U.S. history, and one central to an ongoing evaluation of the meaning and nature of Americanness, the significance of political boundaries, and the strength of transnational ties. One paper reconstructs the material lives of Chinese in Californias Central Valley during the nineteenth century. The other three consider Latinx communities in Southern California and North Carolina, focusing on the impact of education, local networks, and cross-cultural connections. Together, these works extend the cultural and transnational turn to small-scale communities, revealing them to be the collective crucibles in which U.S. residents forged the meaning and texture of America. Each paper represents archival research conducted by undergraduate students. We suggest this is an important and often underappreciated form of history, one that reflects the convergence of teaching and research. Finally, these authors are all women, Latinas, and first-generation college students interested in pursuing a career in history, revealing the ways that changes in the subject and form of historical inquiry have the power to transform the profession itself.
column2: Migrant Communities, Transnationalism, And History As Practice And Profession

column1:
Dr. Reena N. Goldthree (Princeton University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable discussion explores the overlapping histories of migration and empire in the early twentieth-century United States. By highlighting how colonial histories of various forms have shaped migration streams to the U.S., this work challenges notions of American exceptionalism by demonstrating how U.S. immigration patterns have resembled those of other imperial nations, such as that of Britain. This work also highlights the agency of migrants within the U.S. domain as a necessary part of a broader history of American empire that includes not only examples of state power but also claims of non-state actors, in particular those of migrants contesting racial ideologies, immigration laws, and discriminatory labor practices. This work, then, explores a history of empire shaped as much by the force of U.S. state power overseas as by the claims of colonial migrants within the United States. War, occupation, and economic upheaval pushed many people from the outer reaches of American expansion to the center of conflicts in the United States and its territories over colonialism, migration, labor, race and citizenship. Such migrations were marked by what historian Paul Kramer has described as asymmetries of power as migrants arriving in locations as diverse as California, New York and the Panama Canal, faced exploitative labor regimes and a variety of discriminatory laws. Yet in asserting claims to work, live, and become citizens in the United States, migrants desperate to find work in the domestic U.S. contested, at times successfully, the colonial categories that defined them as foreign. This work contributes to an emerging literature on the history of the U.S. in the world that shows not only the reach and power of Americas imperial ambitions but also its limits, as migrants challenged American labor regimes, racial ideologies, and immigration laws within the United States.Building on pioneering work at the intersection of imperialism and immigration in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries such as that of Paul Kramer, Dorothy Fujita-Rony, Catherine Choy, and Eiichiro Azuma, participants in this session will discuss their latest work in this field, ranging from the Caribbean to the Pacific, and facilitate a discussion with the audience on new directions in the field. Julie Greene (Chair) will speak on her current project entitled, Movable Empire: Labor Migrations the Making of U.S. Global Power, 1890-1934, which focuses on labor migration as a defining element of American expansion in the early twentieth century. Moon-Ho Jung will speak on his current project, entitled, The Unruly Pacific: Race and the Politics of Empire and Revolution, 1898- 1941, highlighting the role of migration and empire in racial formations. Reena Goldthree will speak on her recent work, A Greater Enterprise than the Panama Canal: Migrant Labor and Military Recruitment in the World War I-Era Circum-Caribbean, (Labor, Special Issue: Labor and Empire in the Americas, 2016) and Robert McGreevey will discuss his book, Borderline Citizens: The United States, Puerto Rico, and the Politics of Colonial Migration, 1898-1934, (forthcoming, Cornell University Press, 2018).
column2: Migration And Empire

column1:
Professor Ruth M Alexander (Colorado State University)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

How are forms of oppression connected, in the past and the present? How are social movements connected?With the emergence of movements for black lives, environmental protection, nuclear disarmament, LGBTQ rights, and immigrant rights, the term intersectionality has often been raised. This, however, is not a new phenomenon. From Selma to Stonewall to the ERA to the Central Park nuclear freeze rally—and beyond—the question of whether movements are interconnected in an overall fight for social justice or viewed as singular issues has been longstanding. Participants in this roundtable will consider the forms that social movements have taken and assess the effectiveness of varying strategies and tactics. They will also consider the intersectionality of discrimination and the movements to eradicate it. What can we learn as historians to apply to social justice movements today?
column2: Movements For Change: Whats Worked?

column1:
Professor Tyler G. Anbinder (George Washington University)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

We live in an era of proliferating media outlets and diversified audiences. Moreover, increasing numbers of scholars are choosing non-academic careers. Historians narrative styles, too, have evolved to meet the challenges presented by 21st century economic and technological opportunities. This panel brings together writers in various areas who are pushing the boundaries of their field, trying new narrative styles, and bringing history to new audiences. Rachel Martin earned her PhD in gender and memory studies at the University of North Carolina, but abandoned the tenure-track hunt for a career as a freelance writer and researcher. She has won awards (and made a New York Times What Were Reading list) for her work on the intersection of food, civil rights, and memory in Memphis. What does it mean to be a writer with a PhD? she asks herself, and us. Tyler Anbinder, professor of history at George Washington University, is attempting to turn census data and bank records into a compelling narrative that could appeal to non-academic readers. Likewise, Jim Downs, associate professor of history at Connecticut College, is a pioneer in the field of medical history. Winner of the Andrew Mellon New Directions Fellowship, Downs is currently studying medicine at Harvard University to illuminate his work on emancipation. Finally, Michael Landis, assistant professor of history at Tarleton State University, aims to push the boundaries of political history and bring previous neglected voices into the political narrative. His current work on Georgia in the 1850s-60s seeks to tell a comprehensive story that includes both women and men, black and white, enslaved and free, rich and poor. Can a gripping political narrative contain all those voices at once while still offering a coherent argument? he asks. The chair of the panel is Lora Burnett of Collin College. A prolific blogger and student of US intellectual history, Burnett strives to bring nuanced intellectual and policy history to new audiences and engage the general public in serious historiographical debates. As a leading figure in the Society for US Intellectual History, she is well-positioned to lead our discussion. Overall, this panel is about the craft of writing. We will speak frankly about goals, successes, and failures, while also debuting new narrative approaches and possibilities. More importantly, we hope to spark a productive discussion with the audience about the role of writing in the historical profession and the future of the narrative form in our discipline. We are eager to hear audience comments and will maximize audience participation in the discussion. Since the OAH is the leading coalition of American historians, we feel the 2018 annual meeting is the perfect venue for this much-needed discussion.
column2: Narrative Challenges In The Writing Of History

column1:
Professor Zara Anishanslin (University of Delaware)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable will highlight recent scholarship in the era of the American Revolution and explore its significance. Topics will include frames, contexts, and comparisons; sources and methods; recent works of particular significance; and the connections between the American Revolution and the contemporary world. Participants will give explicit attention to teaching themes and strategies.
column2: New Approaches To The American Revolution: A Roundtable

column1:
Professor Kimberly A Hamlin (Miami University (Ohio))

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

In this panel the co-editors will present their overview of A Companion to the Gilded Age and Progressive Era (Wiley Blackwell, 2017) and feature four of the contributors discussing their essays in depth. This collection of thirty-four new historiographic essays covers the years between 1877 and 1920, a period which saw the U.S. emerge from the ashes of Reconstruction to become a world power. The volume and the authors in this round table present fresh interpretations of the period and its historiography. Nichols and Unger will provide a brief overview of the work, drawing from their introductory essay Gilded Excesses, Multiple Progressivisms. This discussion will reveal the wide range of relevant specialties explored in the books essays. Robert Johnston will kick off the specific contributors portion with a recap of his provocative essay Influential Works about the Gilded Age and Progressive Era, in which he reflects on the trajectory of major scholarly works on the period. Even as the older emphasis on political culture and political economy has been superseded by a new focus on race, gender, and empire, enduring questions of democracy continue to be central. In her discussion of Gender, Kimberly Hamlin challenges the widely argued notion that the nineteenth-century concept of separate spheres for men and women eroded during the GAPE. Hamlin argues that separate spheres gave way to gendered lives as distinct standards for men and for women and the gender binary became naturalized. In Art and Architecture, Alan Lessoff argues for a broad understanding of arts role in society. He emphasizes that the agendas pursued by artists and architects were distinct from questions of bourgeois uplift, especially institutional development, professionalism and professional status. He also traces the creation of an American national art that would gain recognition internationally. Allan Lumba will round out the panel by placing the period into its proper global perspective in Empire, Expansion, and Its Consequences. Lumba examines the crucial significance of the GAPE in the historical analysis of U.S. empire. He reveals how a robust and varied historiography has critiqued the dominant narrative of American exceptionalism, then maps out new approaches to U.S. empire during the GAPE, specifically through global and transnational analyses of labor, finance, migration, and political organizing.Combined, the panelists and their topics provide a sense of the vibrant state of the field and underscore the importance and increasing relevance of this historical era.
column2: New Directions In The History Of The Gilded Age And Progressive Era

column1:
Dr. Dillon Jackson Carroll (Hunter College, CUNY)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Since the war ended, Americans have been fascinated with the Civil War. Arguably more books have been written about the conflict than any other event in American history. But for all we have learned about every general and battle of the war, we know remarkably little about the war"s veterans. Appomattox marked the end of the war, but not the end for the men who fought it. This panel, filled with diverse young scholars, seeks to point the way for new directions in studying Civil War veterans. Most of the recent scholarship on Civil War veterans has focused on trauma, and deservedly so. Eric T. Dean, Jr."s "Shook Over Hell" was a groundbreaking monograph that compared Civil War veterans with Vietnam veterans, and argued that veterans of the Civil War may have suffered with PTSD or something like it. Since its publication, a coterie of historians such as James Marten, R.B. Rosenburg, Patrick Kelley, and Rusty Williams have turned their attention to Soldiers Homes in the post-war North and South. David Silkenat and Diane Miller Sommerville have published research exploring the rising rate of suicide among Confederate veterans. Other scholars, among them Brian Craig Miller, Brian Matthew Jordan and Frances Clarke, have explored physical trauma and how amputees shaped post-war society, culture and the memory of the war. While these works are important and deserve mention, they ignore the inner lives of Civil War veterans. Using archives from around the country, and varying methodologies, the work on this panel explores the inner lives of Civil War veterans after the guns were silenced at Appomattox. Kathleen L. Thompson explores the Grand Army of the Republic as a coping mechanism for Civil War veterans in the postwar years. Katharine Dahlstrand, an East Tennessee native and combat veteran, attempts to understand the social network of Tennessee veterans in the postwar years. She combs through over 1,500 responses of Tennessee Civil War veterans to a questionnaire sent to them by state library archivists, and created GIS maps that document the critical moments of their lives. Finally, Dr. Dillon J. Carroll examines how veterans" perceptions of mental illness was different than that of asylum physicians. Veterans tried to carve out a space of legitimacy to protect themselves and their comrades from the shame of mental illness. In contrast to asylum doctors, many Civil War veterans described mental illness among themselves, and other soldiers as a result of being "broke down" or "played out" a vague term that gave a sense of the multiple stressors of war. "Played out" was less clinical, and organically became popular among the soldiers. This would protect them from shame during the war, and help them win pensions after it. All of this work explores little known aspects of Civil War veterans, namely, what their communities were like after the war, how they coped with trauma, and how they perceived that trauma in new and different ways.
column2: New Directions In The History Of Veterans Of The American Civil War

column1:
William Adams (University of Kansas)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

With the perilous ascendance of Donald Trump to the presidency and the openings it has given to resurgent forms of white nationalism and racism in the U.S. it would be salient to continue thinking about how to combat these forces. Diverse movements for anti-racism in America once faced similar challenges, certainly with the conservative ascendance that saw Richard Nixon elected in 1968 and again in 1972. Beyond the important but well-known movements and leaders of civil rights and black power activisms, however, anti-racist social movements also had a solid base in lesser studied institutions, organizations, and structures which gave anti-racism a foundation for growth across a broad cross-section of the population. This panel looks at various local examples of institutional anti-racism that worked to combat the rightward shift of American politics through the late 1960s and 1970s and suggests that the diversity of ideologies and modalities of such initiatives simultaneously revealed strengths. Using Chicago as a quintessential urban locale, this panel suggests that institutions as different from each other as government run war on poverty organizations which gave voice to issues of racism and sexism, progressive formations like Friendship House and the Catholic Interracial Council which combated the Cold War conservatism of the Catholic Church, and local Black Press businesses and institutions that gave voices to millions of black migrants from the South in a period of intense racism and reaction, are collective but understudied sites for anti-racist labors that allowed activists a diversity of channels to combat the rightward march in American politics into the 1970s.
column2: New Histories Of Anti-Racist Activism In Chicago

column1:
Professor Erika Doss (University of Notre Dame)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Philosophers, scientists, and theologians are typically entrusted with the task of explaining to us our place in the world if not also the cosmos. But for many Americans, the search for both personal and cosmic meaning has been an extracurricular pursuit. It has taken place in public spheres as well as private spaces, in mass movements as well as solitary reflection, in popular culture as well as so-called high art. Exploring some of the many ways in which Americans have undertaken the quest for meaning in an increasingly rationalized, secular world, this roundtable-style panel brings together a range of subjects and stories that shed light on the rich archive of spiritual seeking in recent American history. It shows how Americans of various backgrounds have sought to make the search for meaning into something more than just another academic subject—something more like a way of life. Our brief presentations address topics including, but not limited to: cosmic humanism, spiritual modernism, cinematic existentialism, and what we might call mass market deconstructionism. The ultimate goal of the panel is to spark a conversation with the audience about some of the many ways in which we might begin to investigate the pursuit of meaning, spirituality, and transcendence in recent American history, and to show how philosophical, religious, and scientific ideas get turned into lived experiences. At the intersection of contemplation and practice, the search for meaning complicates our common assumptions about what constitutes intellectual and cultural history.
column2: New Perspectives On Quests For Meaning In Twentieth-Century American Thought And Culture

column1:
Professor Peter Coclanis (UNC-Chapel Hill)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

Few topics in economics today—or in economic history—are as controversial as the role of government, particularly its regulatory role. Unlike the case with many topics in economics, there is no consensus, even among those operating within the mainstream neoclassical paradigm, regarding the proper scope, terms, and limits of governmental economic and social regulation. For example, we find proponents of economic and social regulation arguing their cases on very different grounds, e.g., to promote economic stability, to bring about greater competition and/or equity, to protect consumers, to remedy market failure, etc. And opponents of regulation? They, too, base their opposition on a variety of grounds, ranging from governmental inefficiency to a desire to reduce transactions costs, and from the likelihood that regulators are subject to capture by the entities purportedly being regulated to a belief that there is no such thing as market failure at all.The lack of consensus becomes even more pronounced both when we go beyond neoclassical approaches and when we bring economists and historians together to interpret the role of regulation in American history. Regarding disciplinary disagreements about the effects of regulation in our history: Some economists and some historians see regulation as a key source—and guarantor—of Americas economic strength. On the other hand, others in both disciplines argue that America has long been over-regulated and/or that the countrys economic performance historically would have been enhanced had we relied more heavily on private law—the common law, contracts, civil proceedings, and the like-- rather than on (often unelected) governmental administrators to mandate outcomes.In this roundtable we bring together four leading authorities on the history of governmental regulation in America, representing both history and economics, to discuss recent work on regulation and to share some of their current insights on the topic. The regulatory interests (and perspectives) of the participants are diverse—they have written extensively on governmental regulation of business, agriculture, media, food/health, and intellectual property among other topics—which will ensure that the discussion will be broad as well as deep. In light of the profound changes in American politics of late—and, withal, aggressive challenges to the traditional role, even legitimacy of, governmental regulation--this roundtable, sponsored by the Economic History Association, is as timely as it is important.
column2: New Perspectives On The History Of Regulation:  A Roundtable Discussion

column1:
Professor Kendra Taira Field (Tufts University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This double session aims to highlight a range of new work on the politics of land policy and law in the context of nineteenth-century American economic and territorial expansion. Drawing on political economy, settler colonial studies, scholarship on international law and empire, and the new history of capitalism, panelists will present novel approaches to the workings of land politics in this crucial period. Each session will feature four brief presentations outlining the goals and stakes of research in progress, followed by two discussants. By assembling a range of interventions, these sessions aim to delineate the emerging contours of revisions in the history of land policy and law in the nineteenth century.
column2: New Perspectives On The Politics Of Lan And Capitalism In The Nineteenth Century: Reconstruction And Gilded Age (Part 2)

column1:
Dr. Lauren Kientz Anderson (Independent Scholar)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

Today, when transnational feminist activism is thriving—from global linkages among fast food, factory, and domestic workers, to transnational movements against violence and for reproductive, economic, and racial justice—understanding the history of transnational feminisms has never been so vital. In this roundtable, four historians and public intellectuals – Lauren L. Anderson, Eileen Boris, Erik S. McDuffie, and Premilla Nadasen – will draw on their own work to engage new representations of transnational feminist history. Building on the recent transnational scholarship that has enlivened and enriched the field of U.S. womens and gender history, their conversation will underscore the complexity and breadth of twentieth-century transnational feminist history and its relevance today.They will reveal new representations of transnational feminist history in both content and form. In terms of content, Anderson, Boris, McDuffie, and Nadasen each trace transnational figures and movements that either challenge the primacy of Western, white, liberal feminism or that complicate this history by exploring how such feminist groups were embedded within imperial and racial political economies. Lauren L. Anderson examines the work of a number of black American women who promoted interracialism and internationalism in the interwar years. Eileen Boris reveals the close connections that both equal rights feminists and labor feminists had with U.S. empire from the 1930s through the 1950s when the ILO was revising labor instruments for colonial territories. She examines how equal rights versus protection for working women meant relatively little in colonial territories and mandates. Erik McDuffie will discuss the transnational activism of Midwestern black women in the Garvey movement from the 1920s through the 1970s, emphasizing both their importance to building the transnational Garvey movement and the paradoxes of their work. Above all, his remarks will speak to the underappreciated ideological complexities of twentieth-century black womens transnational activism. Premilla Nadasen will draw on her activist work with the domestic workers alliance and her recent research on Miriam Makeba to think through the ways in which transnational feminism has been constructed and its utility for women of African descent.In terms of form, the panelists, all public intellectuals as well as historians, will discuss how new forms of transnational feminist history can reach broader audiences, particularly when in dialogue with contemporary activism and politics. Panelists will discuss the dialectical relationship between historical memory and political engagement today in the ILO, transnational worker activism, Black Lives Matter, and other contemporary activism, and through mediums such as op-eds, social media and blogs.The chair and moderator, Katherine Marino, will draw from her own work on Pan-American feminism, transnational anti-fascist feminism, and international human rights to frame the question of what it means to develop a critical and intersectional historiography of transnational feminism. She will also ask what importance transnational feminism has played in political and social movements in the U.S. historically and today.
column2: New Representations Of Transnational Feminist History

column1:
Gary Nash (University of California, Los Angeles)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

For many years Americans learned from their schoolbooks that abolitionists calling for the end of slavery were disturbers of the peace, neurotic meddling fanatics who threatened to tear apart the fragile new nation. As for those in the colonial period who spoke of the Golden Rule and the indivisibility of all who sprang from Adams seed, the less said the better because even those of their own religious community, mostly the Society of Friends, scorned, censored, and disowned them. In recent years, however, the early abolitionists have earned some grudging respect. Helped along by a revival of Quaker studies, the charge of fanaticism has been partially put at bay. Yet the impact of these early antislavery stalwarts, who worked within a broad Atlantic setting and helped to create what is now regarded as the worlds first modern social movement, has barely reached the pages of high school and college textbooks and is almost entirely unknown to the general public. New scholarship has the potential to change that situation.This roundtable discussion will consider recent work on the first wave of abolitionists before the American Revolution, almost all of them Quakers preaching universal love and the brotherhood of all mankind; and a second, overlapping wave who insisted that the new republic would not survive slavery"s continuation without massive bloodshed and the scourging displeasure of a watching God. As it happened, the early abolitionists – despite their small numbers and the repression they faced – contributed more to the abolitionism that emerged during and after the 1830s than we thought.The five members of the proposed roundtable, all specialists in the history of early abolitionism, will consider a broad range of issues. Who were the early opponents of slavery and how did they arrive at their abolitionist positions? What were their social backgrounds and experiences and how did these shape their antislavery ideas? What variety of ideas did they express? What tactics and strategy did they use to advance their cause? What reception did they get and what impact did they have, in the short term and the long? The participants will also discuss how early abolitionism played out in rural as opposed to urban settings, its characteristics before and after the American Revolution, and its successes and failures at local, state, national, and international levels. They will conclude by asking, where might future scholarship on early abolitionism go?The participants in the roundtable are Jean R. Soderlund (Lehigh University), chair; Gary B. Nash (UCLA); Marcus Rediker (University of Pittsburgh); Manisha Sinha (University of Connecticut); and Nicholas Wood (Yale University).
column2: New Work On Early Abolitionism: A Roundtable

column1:
Mr. Seth Blumenthal (Boston University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

Just weeks after winning the presidency, Donald Trump told reporters that he planned to display a letter from Richard Nixon in the Oval Office. Mrs. Nixon told me that you were great on the [Phil] Donahue Show. As you can imagine, she is an expert on politics and she predicts that whenever you decide to run for office you will be a winner! wrote Nixon to Trump in 1987. Each of the papers/presentations in this panel will focus on different cultural and political connections between Nixon and the Trump presidency. Nixons media and youth strategies, along with efforts to rehabilitate the disgraced Presidents legacy, have direct links to the political culture that led to a Trump presidency.Kathryn Brownells Richard Nixon and the Political Origins of the Information Age will examine Nixons war against the network broadcasting stations. Firmly believing that the media had kicked him around, Nixon stood determined to involve his administration in telecommunications policy-making, especially prioritizing efforts to undermine the influence of network television in American life. This paper will show how the concept of cable deregulation, and the roots of the modern Information age emerged not as a product of the Reagan or Clinton administrations. Rather, these policies originated in the Nixon administration as he embraced the concept of media diversity to weaken the influence of the major networks that he felt had undemocratically influenced American political discussions. Seth Blumenthals paper Changing Perspectives of Young Voters since 1972 looks at Nixons efforts to gather support from non-college youth. Before baby boomers, the terms college and non-college voter received scant attention. By 1972, Nixons re-election campaign set out to counter his anti-war opponent, Senator George McGovern, who had built an insurgent campaign that attracted many campus liberals. Thus, Nixons Young Voters for the President organizers intended to maximize the presidents vote among the segment of new voters who have not attended college and who are employed. Utilizing popular imagery from film, television and political ads, this paper discusses young voters shifting significance in the changing realignment narratives from 1972 to the present. Michael Koncewiczs The Ongoing Effort to Rehabilitate Richard Nixon will cover recent attempts to by Nixon loyalists, scholars and journalists to rescue the 37th Presidents legacy. In 2016, the Nixon Library renovated its museum galleries for the first time since the Librarys opening. With the exception of the Librarys nonpartisan Watergate Gallery which was completed in 2011, the Librarys new exhibits continued to adopt a defensive tone that sought to build on recent conciliatory depictions of the controversial President. This paper will not only analyze the Nixon Library, but will instead try to place it alongside other forms of Nixon revisionism that can be seen in both Nixon scholarship and popular culture. The panel will encourage audience participation throughout each of the presentations and will rely on using audio (Nixon tapes) and videos (recent depictions of Nixon) in order to expand on the conferences theme of The Forms of History.
column2: Nixon In The Age Of Trump: How The 37Th President Shapes Todays Political Culture

column1:
Dr. Kathryn Cramer Brownell (Purdue University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable explores controversial presidencies throughout American history. During these presidencies, Americans were deeply divided about whether a president represented real Americans or was instead a threat to the republic, the Constitution, civil liberties, and sometimes the world. Participants will explore the forms of protest and opposition against perceived illegitimacy, and the forms presidential leadership has taken when the American people have been deeply divided. What has prompted the imputation of illegitimacy? To what extent have presidents been able to overcome the charge of illegitimacy? What lessons from the past can inform our own contemporary political divisions?
column2: Not My President: Questions Of Legitimacy

column1:
Dr. Joseph E. Hower (Southwestern University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Since the ratification of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, women of all backgrounds have moved en masse into the nations workforces, facilitating their passage from peripheral to integral participants in American capitalism. Their rate of workforce participation jumped nearly nine percentage points in the 1970s alone – twelve million more women were in the labor force by the end of the decade than at its beginning. The majority of women pouring into the workforce worked in the service, retail and financial sectors – sectors that formed the core of a neoliberal financialized capitalism. Contemporaries and scholars alike have celebrated womens new opportunities in the workplace during the late twentieth century. But the struggle remained incomplete. Women, including many mothers of young children, began to participate at the center of a transforming economy without a new family-friendly paradigm such as flexible schedules. Few working-class women were presented with opportunities to earn the "family wage" that had been the ideal province of the male wage earner. Finally, women"s new roles as workers too often threatened to reinforce racial hierarchies. It seemed that women"s workforce participation met the needs of globalizing corporations at the expense of working people.Many contested the neoliberal degradation of labor standards and fought collectively for fair wages, flexible schedules and robust social benefits. This session explores mechanisms women employed to gain power within a transformative capitalism, including labor and civil rights organizations. Traci Parker considers black womens efforts to eliminate race and gender discrimination in hiring and promotion at Sears, Roebuck, and Company in the post-Civil Rights Movement era in African American Women and the Sears, Roebuck, and Company Affirmative Action Cases. Lane Windham, in a paper entitled "Rosa the Retailer: Women, Unions and Resistance in the Retail Workforce," explores how sales clerks, cashiers and distribution center workers in the 1970s and 1980s tried to organize new unions and use their union contracts to resist the low-road employment policies that mark the retail workers" experience today. In Betty the Bureaucrat?: Clerical Workers and Comparable Worth in the 1970s, Joseph Hower examines the efforts of female office workers in state and local government to use both unions and civil service systems to challenge budget cuts and raise the wages and status of feminized office work.
column2: On Whose Terms?  Women Workers, Labor Rights And Late 20th Century Capitalism

column1:
Professor Benjamin Leontief Alpers (University of Oklahoma)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

On-line journal editors, bloggers, and programmers from Educations Histories, The Programming Historian, and the U.S. Society for Intellectual History, will discuss the changing nature of publication and the push by scholars to change the methodology and the public dissemination of scholarship. The roundtable will consider questions about the shifting terrain of scholarship, the rise and legitimacy of digital publication, the growing demand for open-access venues, the need for transparency in peer review, and the use of digital tools to create new forms of history.
column2: Open Access, Transparent Peer Review

column1:
Dr. Jana Kate Lipman (Tulane University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Iwo Jima, Okinawa, Yokohama. World War II defines Americans understandings of these locales, from brutal Pacific battles to tangible post-war reminders of U.S. victory and military power. These places were sites of war and conflict, and their histories entangled international and local politics from across the Pacific that endured far after the fighting was over. Laborers, sex workers, and refugees moved in between Japan, the Philippines, Okinawa, and the Bonin Islands, and their experiences, and governments attempts to control their movement demonstrate the contours and conflicts between the United States and Japan in the post-war era. In the first paper, Sho Masaki analyzes the removal, and then repatriation of some, but not all, of the residents of the Bonin Islands. In the second paper, Taihei Okada focuses on comfort women or sex workers under both the Japanese imperial system and under U.S. occupation, and he argues how the control of sex workers defined both regimes. Finally, Colleen Woods turns to the workers who built the U.S. military bases in Okinawa, examining the labor history of Filipino and Okinawans. Collectively, these papers demonstrate the vast number circuits that developed in the post-war era, and the precarious nature of work and resettlement in the early Cold War. This panel also brings together scholars from Japan and the United States and is co-sponsored by the Japanese Association of American Studies.
column2: Pacific Crossings, Occupation, And Post-War Politics In Japan, Korea, And The Philippines

column1:
Professor Lila Corwin Berman (Temple University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

The market-based strategies of foundations and non-profits such as the Gates Foundation and the Clinton Foundation have received a great deal of attention by proponents and critics alike, many of whom dub these activities philanthrocapitalism. While the last decade witnessed a new attention among historians to the role the state has played in fueling financialization and the impact of financialization on government, there has been scant attention to the role of non-profits and foundations in those processes. This panel aims to correct that oversight by examining the role of non-profit organizations in adopting and promoting the expansion of market-based solutions and ideas, particularly as a solution to social inequality. It will also explore the relationship of these institutions to the American government against the changing political and economic landscape of the last decades of the twentieth century. The three papers explore these larger questions from different and distinct vantage points. First, Lila Bermans paper explores how massive transformations in philanthropic practice and rhetoric enabled the expansion of market logic into new spheres of American life by looking at the efforts of American Jewish philanthropists to make capital aggregation into an acceptable and wise charitable strategy. She suggests that this approach did not change American Jewish philanthropy, but contributed to the wider belief that American progress best occurred through the growth of free markets. Claire Dunning similarly examines the ways in which an existing non-profit model helped to fuel financialization. However, in this case, she will examine community development corporations and the role of non-profit finance intermediaries in affordable housing development. By looking at several Boston-area efforts to improve neighborhoods, she argues that the rise of financial language and tools in the social sector emerged as much from grassroots activists needing access to capital as it did from elites seeking to deploy their wealth for charitable purposes. Finally, Lily Geismer takes up these issues from the perspective of the state. She looks at Bill Clintons programs to promote private sector investment and access to loans and capital as a means to address poverty and inequality in distressed communities both as president and at his foundation. Probing Clintons commitment to idea of the doing well by doing good, Geismer will examine the development of a Democratic and liberal version of neoliberalism, and the role of foundations in fostering it, which has come to shape many of the prevailing ideas about markets and private investment as a tool to address to poverty and social inequality. Jonathan Levys recent work on non-profit corporations, for-profit corporations, and the fiscal state across the twentieth century will inform his comments on the three papers. By placing these topics and issues in conversation, our intent is to reveal the complexity and spectrum of market-thinking and policy, particularly among those identifying as liberals or Democrats, and to better understand the new and dominant place that foundations and non-profits from have come to play in the development of public policy and the financialization of everyday life.
column2: Philanthrocapitalism:  Foundations And The Turn To Market-Based Solutions For Inequality Since The 1970s

column1:
Ms. Felicia Janine Bevel (Brown University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

In what ways do children encounter the past beyond the space of the classroom and the pages of the textbook? This roundtable turns to childrens museums as alternative sites of historical engagement where children can travel back in time through play. From interactive exhibits on local immigration history to hands-on activities that introduce historical methods, childrens museums enable their young visitors to learn not only about various historical moments but also witness the investigative work necessary for researching and disseminating history. Through play, children can place themselves within the narratives they encounter. Childrens museums thus offer a useful window into the ways that play shapes how various histories are told and how children then understand these histories. Of particular importance are the ways that childrens museums present the histories of people in the margins. This roundtable therefore also addresses the age-specific, play-based activities and programming that introduce race, gender, and other intersectional identities through a historical lens and consequently encourage broader conversations about difference and belonging that can continue beyond the museum. Understanding these spaces as both sites of innocent play and as extensions of the classroom, it additionally invites conversation about museums and pedagogy more broadly. As Kristina DuRocher, Rebecca de Schweinitz, and other scholars have argued, age is an important analytic for understanding how various racialized and gendered political projects have unfolded throughout American history. However, as this roundtable contends, age is also critical when considering how this nations past is now disseminated to and consumed by various publics. This roundtable brings together academics and museum professionals who have either designed programming for children in museums or researched and taught on historical engagement inside museums. As the Associate Director of School Programs at the New-York Historical Society, Allyson Schettino discusses the institutions childrens history museum and its unique approach for engaging students with the past: teaching history through the eyes of young historical figures. Working within education departments at museums, Krystal Gladden and Stephanie Cunningham both broaden the discussion by considering the pedagogical tools that museums not specifically for children can nevertheless use to teach students history, particular histories of people of color. Tiffney Laings creation of History Makers and other educational toys about African American history, however, illustrates how conversations about histories of marginalized communities can continue beyond the museum. The final two panelists sit on the academic side of the table. Currently researching how people engage with race in exhibitionary settings, Anni Pullagura addresses the affective labor that children perform when encountering forms of difference in museums. And having taught a course on the history of race and childhood, Felicia Bevel considers how age is an important category of historical analysis within museums, classrooms, and other sites of learning. Together, these six panelists explore how play, both within and beyond childrens museums, helps children engage with the past.
column2: Playing With The Past: Childrens Museums As Alternative Sites Of Historical Engagement

column1:
Dr. Elizabeth M Covart (Omohundro Institute/Ben Franklin's World)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

History podcasts have arrived. iTunes lists over 200 history podcasts and professional historians produce some of those available for download. In order to stimulate conversation about the unique ability of podcasting to expand disciplinary approaches to the past and more widely disseminate historians ideas, this session will bring together six scholars whose podcasts take different forms, reach diverse public audiences, and have varied purposes.The participants podcasts reflect the medium"s capacious possibilities. Since 2011, Adam Smith has partnered with the BBC to broadcast historically informed programming with high production values designed to explain American history to his predominantly British audience. Liz Covarts Ben Franklin"s World features weekly interviews with historians who discuss their work on early American history and how historians practice history. Remarkably, she has developed a business model around engaging conversations about historical scholarship. Nicole Hemmer"s weekly podcast Past Present engages with contemporary politics and culture by focusing on breaking news and timely stories. In each episode, she moderates a discussion with fellow historians Natalia Petrzela and Neil Young, whose disparate interests, expertise, and personalities spur an entertaining exchange of views that bring historical antecedents to the fore. Similarly, Ed O"Donnell"s In The Past Lane seeks to explain "why things are the way they are" in a thought-provoking but entertaining way. The podcast features interviews with historians, history thinkpieces, and analyses of portrayals of history in popular culture, such as the TV series Mercy Street. Julie Golia"s Flatbush + Main is a monthly podcast from Brooklyn Historical Society. With co-host Zaheer Ali, Julie interviews scholars and analyzes oral histories and archival sources to unearth local histories with national resonance. In 2017, Graham Peck will work with Saint Xavier University"s students and radio station to create podcasts on the life of Catherine McAuley, founder of the Sisters of Mercy, to illuminate and promote the charism that lies at the heart of the university"s mission.Despite its challenges, podcasting enables historians to reimagine the discipline. Its relatively low start-up costs reduce barriers to entry and enable historians to forge direct connections with listeners. The medium encourages experimentation with format. Most podcasts have multiple hosts, guests, segments, and subject matter. Podcasts also encourage creative use of evidence. Podcasts leverage the expertise of guests and hosts to distill complex problems or unknown pasts into engaging stories and analysis. Their use of music and recordings creates immersive listener experiences that appeal to broad audiences. And, most importantly, podcasts create intimate connections between historians and individual listeners, relationships historians can leverage through the power of websites and social media. Although there are real challenges in creating successful podcasts--finding time to research, record, and edit them, acquiring and maintaining an audience, tracking and analyzing the audience, and balancing podcasting with other professional demands--podcasts are still uniquely suited to reaching new public audiences interested in history, a goal of great import for all historians.
column2: Podcasting: History's Future In The Digital Age?

column1:
Dr. Brian D. Behnken (Iowa State University)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

For several decades now, scholars have recognized the central role that law enforcement has played in shaping the socio-legal parameter of settler colonial societies. Throughout North America, policing strategies and the technologies used by law enforcement have proved critical in shaping settler colonial efforts to discipline bodies and cement national formation. Colonial policing, to borrow from John Brewer, naturalized both martial and psychological programs of policing that were designed to order settler societies along racial, class, and gender lines. The issues associated with law enforcement and settler societies continue to impact the lives of Indigenous people, the poor and working class, migrant communities, and people of African descent. The recent spate of violent encounters between police officers and African Americans and Latino/as in the United States suggest that the violent legacy of law enforcement is far from a relic of the past; it is instead a lived reality. This roundtable builds on historical analyses of law enforcement and settler societies in North American contexts. The participants aim to present fresh insights into a range of topics associated with settler colonial law enforcement – such as the use of violence in policing, technologies of power, and the impact of gender and sexuality on colonial policing practices – to advance our understanding of law enforcement in settler colonial contexts throughout North America.
column2: Policing Settler Colonies: Life And Death In North America

column1:
Dr. Sara Georgini (Massachusetts Historical Society)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

When do maps tell the truth about American history, and how do they form challenges to our narratives of development and change? When we interpret the American past, we use geography to provide physical, metaphorical, and visual links between bygone eras and the present. Historians, operating as teachers, scholars, and public intellectuals, work with maps and the broader landscape of geography in order to connect the physical spaces in which we reside with the political meaning they obtain. Museums, archives, and classrooms are pedagogical geographies in which we work every day, yet they themselves are apart of a wider world of information, cartographic technology, and intelletcual representation. Further, what role do regions play in the formation of Anglo-American colonization and nation-building? Teachers and researchers have long identified the traditional regional format—with New England, the middle colonies, and the South—but how did these ideas of sectional allegiance shift over time? How did people conceive and challenge modes of geopolitical belonging in the face of historical change? Our panel reevaluates the role of maps and regions as complex historical forms that made and unmade empires in the early Atlantic World. To begin, Nicholas Gliserman shows that the 1680s were a period of boundary making and contestation in northeastern America, as imperial officials sought to embed cartographic practices within a total reorganization of empire. But how did this project play out in real time, on the ground? Gliserman argues that scholars have overstated the initial success of imperial reforms, and that the archival organization of cartographic (and textual) materials has played a key role in what we think we know about the era. Next, Nora Slonimsky reappraises the relationship between geography, representation, and state-building through the work of colonial cartographer Lewis Evans, who produced one of the most popular and pirated maps of North America in 1755. His General Map was a mosaic of representation; depicting indigenous sovereignty as well as settler advancements, Evans sketched out the political and commercial realities of life in British North America. As Slonimsky argues, Evans also exerted his sovereignty over the cartographic text by exeercising the claim of copyright. In this first entanglement of law, politics, and commerce, nearly thirty years before the current scholarship dates the start of intellectual property in America, representation and labor came to the forefront of imperial border disputes that would linger into the early republic. Finally, moving out from the archive and the raw construction of its contents, Benjamin Park looks at the intelletcual inequalities embedded in geographic representation. During the first two decades of the 19th century, for example, the significance of regional identities blossomed during national political debates over slavery . Divisive questions about the regionaliztion of slavery, as Park demonstrates, animated white elites, radical evangelicals, and free blacks; their answers held major implications for the formation and growth of young America.
column2: Political Geographies Of Representation: Regions, Boundaries, And Property In Early America

column1:
Dr. Julio Capó (Jr. University of Massachusetts, Amherst)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: State of the Field

Historians have long noted the whiteness of queer history and the degree to which whiteness has itself often gone unremarked, making it the de facto norm in scholarship about queer life in the United States. In recent years, however, scholars have produced groundbreaking work on queer people of color and centered intersectional analyses. This panel is a state-of-the-field roundtable that focuses on how different racial categories—African American, Asian American, Latinx, Native American, white—inform and transform queer history, and in turn how queerness is (or is not) incorporated into analyses of racial identity.
column2: Queer History And Race: A State Of The Field Roundtable

column1:
Professor Edward Countryman (Southern Methodist University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

Historians have always been drawn to the apparent contradiction between all men are created equal and the regimes of racial hierarchy that structured early U.S. society. This roundtable brings together historians whove recently published on race in the Revolution and the early republic, and invites them both to survey the state of the field and to explore new avenues of research in this area. The session will engage the lived realities of race in the late eighteenth century, the development of race theory and racial prejudices, and the political and social consequences of race thinking. The participants will also consider the pros and cons of thinking in parallel about Native Americans and African Americans in the early United States; the extent to which U.S. racial theories and practices were distinctive from European and Latin American thinking; the relationship between race thinking and the first phases of antislavery activism and Indian reform"; the employment of race thinking by people of color themselves; the political uses of race; and the distinctiveness (or otherwise) of the Revolutionary moment in the broader narrative of American history.
column2: Race In The Era Of The American Revolution — A Roundtable

column1:
Dr. David Barber (University of Tennessee at Martin)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel examines the social experiences of activists in different social movements during the post-World War II era. Each panelist explores varied responses to racial inequality on the local, state, and national levels. The papers each highlight myriad responses to the climate of Cold War repression, focusing especially on how race and ethnicity influenced political action. As the so-called Cold War consensus unraveled, the day-to-day resistance strategies of activists shifted to challenge the the United States claims as a champion of democracy and the leader of the free world. The connecting thread between the panelists is their focus on people who risked political imprisonment for the circulation of radical speech, ideas, and action. Domestic responses to the rise of Third World liberation movements also appear in these presentations, as they fostered inventive and distinctive collaborations across racial, national, and gendered boundaries. Another thread linking these papers is an analysis of how activists crafted strategies to defy state authority and surveillance. Subject to increased state scrutiny at the height of the Cold War, these groups still challenged the normal operation of the state.
column2: Race, Radicalism, And Reaction In The 1960s And 1970s

column1:
Dr. George Hawley (University of Alabama)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

People approach American politics in many forms—from social media aggregators to old-fashioned newspapers—and, in recent years, conservatism has dominated both scholarly and non-academic conversations. Despite the increased interest in right-wing politics, radical conservatism remains an underrepresented facet of political history. This panel uses far-right activists as a medium to understand the broader history of conservatism in the twentieth century. To illuminate the influence of the Radical Right, this panel focuses on three time periods and subjects: anti-Semitism within the anti-New Deal conservative coalition; the fight to repeal taxation, particularly the Sixteenth Amendment, during the 1960s; and the complicated relationship between conservatism and right-wing populism in the late twentieth century. Utilizing archival resources, newspapers, and periodicals, these three papers argue that far-right conservatism helped shape modern politics through populist rhetoric and grassroots activism, notably by reducing the political spectrum to a communist-or-conservative binary and using conspiracy theories to push the American polity rightward. These papers illustrate that reactionary conservatives were not simply anxiety-addled eccentrics; rather, ultraconservatives pursued platforms and forged political connections in an attempt to establish their idealized vision for the United States. This panel highlights the strands of ultraconservatism that permeated twentieth century right-wing politics, including anti-Semitism, fiscal reactionism, anti-statism, and anti-elite populism. Ultimately, the far-right created complex webs of local, regional, and national activism, delineated the divisions within contemporary conservatism, and helped shape the contours of the modern conservative movement.
column2: Radicalism On The Right: Ultraconservative Activism In The Twentieth Century

column1:
Dr. Michael Allan Eissinger (Fresno City College / California State University, Fresno)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

Californias Central Valley is pejoratively known as the other California. In so many ways the region is qualitatively distinct from its southern California and San Francisco Bay area neighbors. From its history, culture, voting patterns, and economy, the region is distinct from coastal California and is often referred to as Appalachia West. This panel discussion brings together four experts on the history of race, labor, and civil rights in Californias Central Valley. Each panelist will frame a set of historical questions as to how their own research rethinks the history of race, labor, and civil rights in the other California.
column2: Re-Forming Narratives Of The Other California: Race, Labor, And Civil Rights In Californias Central Valley

column1:
Professor Karen Alliene Benjamin (Saint Xavier University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This session reexamines how southerners sought to bring about residential segregation in their region in the first decades of the twentieth century—the practices they developed and the influences behind these practices. It offers new perspectives, examining school site selection as a tool of segregationists and exploring the larger constellation of ideas from which local segregationists drew.Karen Benjamin analyzes an overlooked method that city planners and other elites used to achieve residential segregation in southern cities: school site selection. Since many young families seek to live near the schools that their children will attend, locating schools for black and white children in not just separate neighborhoods but in racially isolated locations has proven effective in deepening racial separation. Benjamin calls upon historians to consider school site selection as one of the most effective tools to impose residential segregation, especially once the courts declared racial zoning to be unconstitutional. Elizabeth Herbin-Triant places the story of local residential segregation campaigns in one state in a larger context, showing how the particular situation of middling whites in North Carolina came together with inspiration from other southern states and other countries to propel forward an effort to separate the residences of black and white people in the state. Recent work (such as Carl Nightingales Segregation: A Global History of Divided Cities and Marilyn Lake and Henry Reynoldss Drawing the Global Colour Line: White Mens Countries and the International Challenge of Racial Equality) argues that there was an international exchange of segregationist ideas. Herbin-Triant is interested in where middling whites, the group behind residential segregation in North Carolina, fit into this exchange. She explores the question of to what extent campaigns for residential segregation were meant to benefit elite whites, and to what extent they were meant to benefit middling whites.
column2: Reconsidering Residential Segregation In The South Through School Site Selection, Class, And A Transatlantic Exchange Of Ideas

column1:
Dr. Lorena Valdivia Marquez (UCD, Department of Chicana/o Studies)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

In November 2012, a group of Chicana/o Movement elders and allies—including myself—came together and formed the Sacramento Chicano Movement Oral History Project (hereafter, Project). The purpose of the Project was to collect Chicana/o Movement activists/participants oral histories about their involvement and contributions in the Mexican American civil rights movement in Sacramento from the years of 1965 through 1980. The group felt a tremendous responsibility of recording the lived histories of this aging population and make known their efforts, dreams, and struggles as they lived and remembered them. The Project was successful in collecting 100 richly detailed and textured oral histories. However, the content of the oral histories is not the focus of the conference panel. Rather, the focus is on the process through which the Project committee gathered the oral histories. The process was very involved and required tremendous time and organizing from the Project steering committee. The interviewees were selected/identified by Project committee members and also through recommendations and referrals from the Sacramento Chicano Movement co-hort. All interviewees signed a consent form which granted permission for the Project to release their audio-video recordings to the Sacramento State University Archives. The interviewers were for the most part undergraduate students who were enrolled in my Qualitative Methods courses, which I currently teach in the Department of Chicana/o Studies at the University of California at Davis. Teaching in Chicana/o Studies facilitated the production of the oral histories because the department strongly supports faculty who work closely in the community. All oral histories were audio-video recorder, edited, and will be submitted in the near future to the Sacramento State University Archives and made available to the general public and researchers interested in understanding Chicana/o Movement experiences.To provide the audience with an understanding of how the process unfolded, the first speaker, Senón Valádez, will address how his idea to document the oral histories of the Chicana/o Movement in Sacramento came about and how he put together the steering committee. The next speaker, David Rasul, will talk about how he actively engaged members of the Chicana/o Movement cohort and encouraged their participation. Then, Rhonda Ríos-Kravitz, will speak about the Projects efforts to apply for funding and some of the pitfalls and triumphs in this struggle. Lastly, Feliciano Valádez, will speak about his experience in video recording all the interviews pro-bono. To demonstrate the outcome of the work, we will show a ten-minute clip of a documentary showcasing the lives of Chicana/o Movement activists in Sacramento.
column2: Recovering Chicana/O Movement Oral Histories

column1:
Professor Cameron Blevins (Northeastern University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

The state has attracted growing attention from U.S. historians as a category of analysis. Recent work by historians of law, politics, gender, slavery, race, and capitalism have not only brought the state back in to American history, but recast our understanding of the states history and its role in society. What, then, does the burgeoning field of digital history contribute to this new body of literature? Some historians complain that digital history is too infatuated with flashy bells and whistles and has failed to make substantive scholarly interventions. This panel aims to change that by bringing together four historians who are using digital mapping to reinterpret American state power in the long nineteenth century. Each of the panelists will present very brief (5-10 minute) introductions of their projects. Rather than showcasing the digital tools themselves, they will concentrate on the major research findings and scholarly arguments that those new methods have allowed them to make. Their overviews will serve as a concrete starting point for the heart of the session: a conversation amongst the panelists, co-chairs, and audience members on broader topics such as the rapidly changing historiography of the American state, theories about space and geography, and the role of analysis and interpretation in the practice of digital history. Nicole Phelps begins by tracing the history of the US Consular Service between 1789 and 1924. Historians have traditionally seen the work of the consular service through its role in expanding trade. While important, consuls did much more. Charting the rapid spatial growth of the US Consular Service reveals the countrys shifting global interests, the expanding mandate of the service, and the way its growth forced US citizens and foreigners to confront US sovereignty abroad. Next, Benjamin Hoy charts the growth of federal infrastructure in both Canada and the United States between 1860 and 1930. He uses GIS software to show where people were hired and fired, where posts were built or fell into disrepair, and what incidences received federal attention and which did not. This analysis shows a highly uneven process, encompassing a vast range of capacities and approaches to deploying state power on both sides of the border.Jamie Pietruska uses digital mapping to recover a large-scale network of weather-reporting stations in the United States in the nineteenth century. This network has traditionally been seen as the product of government efforts that appeared in the wake of the U.S. Civil War. Instead, Pietruska uses datasets compiled by historical climatologists to reveal a longer and much more dynamic spatio-historical trajectory, one in which overlapping information networks both competed and collaborated with state initiatives. Finally, Cameron Blevins focuses on the single largest arm of the federal government: the U.S. Post. Mapping this massive network debunks any lingering notions of a weak or limited nineteenth-century state. Charting how it spread and functioned across such a large territory leads to a fundamentally new model of state power that was much more ephemeral and spatially expansive than historians have previously understood.
column2: Reinterpreting The American State: Digital History's Intervention

column1:
William R. Black (Rice University)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

The scholarly consensus that the North and South were fundamentally different societies by the mid-nineteenth century is no longer much of a consensus. Recent historical scholarship demonstrates that slavery was not just a southern institution but a national one, both economically and politically. Many historians have taken issue with Eugene Genoveses formulation of a pre-capitalist slave South and instead argued that slavery was intensely capitalist and inseparable from northern agriculture, manufacturing, and finance. This panel further complicates the dichotomy between a slave South and a free North by focusing on multidirectional interactions in the Midwest, broadly defined to include the Ohio Valley South. For slaveholders and enslaved people in the early republican Ohio Valley, Cumberland Presbyterians in the antebellum lower North and upper South, and prisoners in Civil War–era Kentucky, the Ohio River was not a hard boundary between slavery and freedom, if indeed it was a boundary at all. The various flows of people, goods, and ideas in this mid-continental region—catalyzed by the confluence of Native Americans, Euro-Americans, and African-Americans—tied the two sides of the Ohio River together at the same time that other forces were dividing them. This panel joins Christopher Phillips, Edward L. Ayers, Bridget Ford, and others in their effort to examine the lives of people in this middle border region, and what the construction of a distinct North and South looked like on the ground in all its messiness.
column2: Reinterpreting North And South In The Midwest

column1:
Dr. Lauren H. Braun-Strumfels (Raritan Valley Community College)

Date: 2018-04-14
