Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Looking at the United States from Europe in the late nineteenth century, the U.S. seemed very willing to accept millions of newcomers each year, until restrictive quotas were put in place in the World War I era. But not all would-be migrants had the freedom of movement to leave their home states. In the historiography, the march towards restriction in the early-mid twentieth century is typically framed from the U.S. perspective, ignoring foreign governments efforts to police and restrict emigration before the war. How did European states, empires, and colonies -- in our case studies Italy, Austria-Hungary, and Malta -- view and attempt to intervene in the complex political, social, and economic forces driving attitudes and legislation about transatlantic migration? How did the restrictions that the sending countries put in place affect migrants experiences? How did U.S. and European governmental restrictions respond to one another? This panel explores the role that European governments of sending countries played in the rise of a global regime of migration restriction, bring together migration history with foreign relations. European restrictions constricted who could migrate, for how long, under what circumstances, and what kind of relationship they could have with their home state and individuals there after leaving. By focusing on restriction from sending countries and responses to European restrictions, this panel frames migration restriction to the U.S. as a transnational phenomenon and emphasizes that restriction emerged as a feature of governmental responses well before the passage of the 1924 Johnson-Reed Immigration Act, and that European governments continued to legislate emigration after U.S. laws were put in place.
column2: Rethinking Migration Restriction: Sending State Activism In The Era Of Mass Transatlantic Migration

column1:
Sean Parulian Harvey (Northwestern University)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel features the 2017 Huggins-Quarles Prize winner, Sean P. Harvey, whose promising dissertation explores the origins of the U.S./Mexico borderlands maquiladoras and the emergence of the North American Free Trade Agreement in the latter half of the twentieth century. Mr. Harveys paper will be in conversation with the works of two early-career historians that place race and labor at the center of the study of 19th and 20th c. U.S. political economy. Together, these three papers examine the ways in which U.S. And non-U.S. state actors and corporate elites worked to establish and consolidate territorial claims in disputed lands/borderlands and regulate and control natural resources and labor migration. As these three papers will discuss, what often appears as inevitable U.S. capitalist expansion and development resulted from a wide range of collaborations and contestations on the part of state actors, corporate leaders, labor leaders, migrants and indigenous inhabitants. Each of the papers in this session explores a different case of U.S. capitalist development and borderlands control as co-constitutive across the 19th and early 20th century. Sean Harveys A Clutch for Bilingual Bureaucrats: Runaway Plants and the Rise and Fall of the Commission for Border Development and Friendship, 1966-1972 looks at the role of labor unions and Republicans in Congress in shaping border economic development in their effort to protect the exportation of American jobs. Maria Quintanas paper closely looks at mid-twentieth century understandings of the labor contract as a guarantee of cheap labor to employers as well as rights and freedoms to migrant workers. Manu Vimalasserys The Exclusions of Colonialism: Chinese Exclusion as Colonial State Formation goes back to the late 19th century to examine the Central Pacific Railroad Companys efforts to chart a route across Paiute lands using federal land grant policies and Chinese migrant labor to achieve native dispossession.
column2: Rethinking Race, Labor, And Capitalism In U.S. History

column1:
Dr. Christina Cecelia Davidson (Duke University)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This round table session will explore the variety of ways that digital history projects are reviewed. Participants will approach the topic from the perspective of contributing editors of digital history sections in traditional journals as well as that of reviewers for newer scholarly publications. What are best practices for these reviews? How are they different from reviews of traditional manuscripts or books? What opportunities and challenges exist in this emerging field of review?
column2: Reviewing Digital History

column1:
Ms. Claire Goldstene (New Faculty Majority)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

In recent years, graduate programs in U.S. history and the OAH have offered increased support to Ph.D. graduates pursuing alt-ac careers. While many practicing historians find gainful employment outside of academia, their intellectual curiosity, research skills, and creative historical analyses do not diminish. Upon receiving a graduate degree in history, many advanced degree holders want to revise their graduate work for publication or pursue new historical projects but find this task daunting without institutional support. This session seeks to reach a broad audience among the historical community by addressing how to maintain an active scholarly publishing record while working outside of academia. The format will offer a combined roundtable-workshop: panelists will discuss their experiences and share relevant, practical advice for 30 minutes, followed by a 30-minute hands-on workshop and strategizing session where participants will develop individual action plans. The session will conclude with a 30-minute group discussion and Q&A. The panelists and commentator all received their doctorate degrees in U.S. History or a related field and have pursued successful careers as tenure-track and contingent faculty, K-12 educators, and state and local government employees as well as serving as volunteers, activists, and practicing historians. Audrey Russek is a former assistant professor of History and currently oversees the Grants Office for the fifth largest school district in California, where she serves as the offices lead grant writer. She has published several scholarly articles, book chapters, and book reviews. Her current projects include two articles and the final revision of her book manuscript based on her dissertation. Claire Goldstene has published a number of journal articles and an academic book. She currently works as a senior Public Information Officer at the California Contractors State License Board and teaches at UC Davis Extension. She also serves on the Contingent Faculty Committee for the Labor and Working Class History Association. Erica Peters is the co-founder of the Culinary Historians of Northern California and has extensive experience as a university lecturer including her current position at the University of the Pacific. She has published several books and articles. Darren Speece currently holds the position of Assistant Dean of Students at Sidwell Friends School in Washington, DC, where he teaches courses in U.S. and environmental history. His publications include an academic book, several scholarly articles, and an essay for the popular press. All of the panelists have maintained an active scholarly research and writing agenda outside of academia and aim to guide other interested history practitioners on a similar path. This session will cover topics including:•how to stay informed about recent academic publications without institutional access to university library holdings;•how to make time for writing when working full- or part-time outside of academia;•how to write a research grant proposal without academic affiliation;•how to pursue professional support for historical research and publication in non-academic careers;•how to maintain a network of academic writers and reviewers for work-in-progress;•how to develop collegial networks both inside and outside academia.
column2: Revising History: Writing And Publishing Scholarship Outside Academia

column1:
Dr. Kati Curts (Sewanee: The University of the South)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

When the disgraced megachurch pastor Ted Haggard talks about his meth-fueled escapades with a male prostitute that became public in 2006, he remembers the event, simply, as the scandal. Scandal has been an important part of popular culture, and Haggard is not alone in labeling and remembering certain historical phenomena in terms of scandal. How does scandal operate as a form of history? This panel will probe this question by examining four case studies of scandalous episodes from the Gilded Age and beyond. With a combined interest in how questions of race, religion, gender, and sexuality played out in the popular press and culture, the panelists will explore how Americans fascination with scandal led to new articulations of proper religiosity, morality, sexuality, and gender expression.Carolee Klimchocks study of elite women eloping with their coach drivers argues that, although always sensational, these stories would eventually become sanctioned and even romanticized in some newspaper articles. Unlike their more conservative counterparts that valued traditional morality, this new class of reporters emphasized the romantic nature of elopement scandals. Occasionally, they even turned a blind eye on the interracial nature of elopement scandals, decades before interracial marriage became legal. Suzanna Krivulskaya will present the surprisingly widespread phenomenon of ministerial elopements which reached its peak in the 1890s. The paper will focus on the roots of how both the self-proclaimed secular press and, increasingly, the mainstream media used these scandalous episodes to question and undermine traditional religious authority in places across the United States. Rachel McBride Lindseys paper will move the panel into the early twentieth century and consider the scandalous religious career of Josie K. Folsom, a midwestern Spiritualist leader and religious entrepreneur. Amid accusations of fraud and forgery of spiritual writings, Folsoms career highlights the important yet often overlooked material and visual aspects of the study of religion, morality, and authenticity. Finally, Kati Curts will present a religious history of Elizabeth (Baby Doe) Tabor, whose sensational rags-to-riches-and-back-to-rags life story played out not only in newspapers, but also in Hollywood film and Cold War era opera. Focusing on Baby Does later reclusive life in a Colorado shack and analyzing her materiality, Curts looks at the scandals surrounding the unusual career of Tabor and highlights the profound importance of scandal for the study of religion and American frontier history. In addition to the traditional paper format, several panelists will also present a digital history component of their projects. The panels chair and commentator, Bobby Smiley, a digital history librarian, will then address the challenges and opportunities for the changing forms in which historians study and present their projects in the digital age.
column2: Romance, Reverends, And Renegades: Scandal As Gilded Age History

column1:
Professor Peter Conti-Brown (Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

In an examination of African American beauty industries, central banking, and victory gardens, this roundtable showcases the diversity of projects that can be classified as business history. By uncovering innovative archives and questioning disciplinary boundaries, participants explore how business—in the form of institutions, cultural productions, or corporate imaginary—shaped lives in the twentieth century. They ask, further, how forms of business history scholarship—from corporate histories to case studies to public installations—engage multiple audiences.
column2: Roundtable: The Forms Of Business History

column1:
Dr. Jennifer Helgren (University of the Pacific)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable examines the creation of a two public history projects, the Digital Deltas and the Oak Park Grassroots Oral History project. Participants will discuss how their efforts to design, collect, preserve, and disseminate, the diverse regional community histories of Sacramento and of the San Joaquin Delta. The Digital Deltas website, for example, features the many histories of Filipino, Chinese, Japanese, Sikh, Hispanic, and African American partners whose perspectives and artifacts offer new narratives of this complex agricultural and urban, multicultural region at the heart of Californias largest and most important watershed area. Similarly, the Oak Park project seeks to retain the rich, radical past of Sacramentos historically Black neighborhood, once home to a chapter of the Black Panthers Party and a continuing center of business and cultural leadership despite the urban pressures of poverty and gentrification.
column2: Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta Histories

column1:
Professor Guy Chet (University of North Texas)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

Colonialists and early-nationalists view the Revolution differently. Specifically, early-nationalists view it as a story of change—the culmination of a long incremental process through which shared circumstances in America produced common cultural traits in colonists and increasingly differentiated and alienated them from their compatriots and government across the Atlantic. Scholarship on colonial America, by contrast, is generally more skeptical regarding Americanization and the cultural divide between provincials and Britons. This panel examines how scholarly research shapes public understanding of the Revolution. A survey of representative undergraduate syllabi, leading textbooks, and popular histories reveals that the common periodization of the Revolution reflects the dominance of early-nationalists in framing Revolutionary pedagogy. Ending the Revolutionary era in 1789, with the founding of a new nation-state, conditions students to see emergent nationhood as the key storyline in the coming of the Revolution. It frames a narrative of gradual cultural change during the colonial era, driven by uniquely American circumstances like slavery, economic and demographic dynamism, ethnic tensions, and other effects of expanding frontiers. By contrast, a large body of colonial scholarship offers an alternate understanding of the ends—and end point—of the Revolution. It challenges the idea of the colonies centrifugal trajectory, traces forces of Anglicization in America, sets the Revolution in the context of English culture, and presents it as a product of cultural change taking place in England, rather than America. Scholars of Indigenous America see a different periodization altogether, one that does not hinge on the Revolution, but traces a continuous history of conquest, accommodation, and change that created an Anglo and Native America. While scholars have benefited from this lively debate on the origins, meaning, and ends of the Revolution, students and laypeople are largely unaware of it. To allow maximal time for audience participation, this panel comprises three panelists—an eastern-seaboard colonialist (Chet), an expanding-frontier early-nationalist (Hyde), and a specialist on Europes Age of Revolution (Lerner). It is chaired by a preeminent scholar of the American Revolution (Countryman). Panelists will discuss how their vantage points on the Revolution—from America and Europe, from the West and the East, from the nineteenth century and the seventeenth century—frame their classroom narratives on the Revolution, and how receptive or resistant students are to these narratives. Since many in the audience will be as experienced as the panelists in teaching Revolutionary history, the panel presentations (10-12 minutes each) will initiate an open-forum discussion, instead of a traditional Q&A session directed at the panelists. Instructors in the audience will be invited to relate how a professors research agenda can enforce a particular classroom narrative on students, whether students are aware of this, and whether professors enlighten or confuse undergraduates by trying to address this by presenting the Revolution from multiple perspectives in a single class. Given that scholars cannot accommodate conflicting conceptual frameworks in their research monographs, can they achieve such intellectual pluralism in an undergraduate classroom?
column2: Scholars As Instructors:  The Impact Of Research Agendas On The Teaching Of The American Revolution

column1:
Professor Estelle B. Freedman (Stanford University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Despite the once-presumed reticence about sexuality in American history, the field has flourished in the past generation, thanks to abundant print and archival sources, from newspapers, pamphlets, speeches, fiction, cartoons, and film to letters, diaries, and memoirs. Some historians have made extensive use of oral history as the basis of their scholarship on sexuality, particularly in lesbian, gay, and trans history (including Elizabeth Kennedy and Madeleine Davis; Nan Alamilla Boyd; Horacio Roque Ramirez; Marcia Gallo; Daniel Rivers). Indeed, queer historians have often had to employ oral history to uncover sexualities that had once been officially suppressed, and they have already done a good deal of theorizing about sexuality and oral history. Whether subjects identify as queer, straight, gender non-conforming, or asexual, historians may encounter both silences and revelations in oral history interviews. Like the lacunae and crossed out passages in letters and diaries, sexual silences in oral histories can be as revealing as what has been recorded, if we read their meanings carefully. This session builds on the theories of oral historians who have written about reticence and silence, and the memories behind them, to explore some of the spaces that fall between silence and speech in interviews, particularly those related to sexuality. The papers explore the terrain of what might be called unrevealable revelations," an approach that speaks to the conference focus on forms of representation by asking how scholars can or should represent what they are discouraged from telling. The papers will also address the limits of oral history for probing communities in transition and displacement and effects of public policy on shaping our access to historical memory. Panelists will explore both the private side of knowledge – in particular, womens sexual secrets and revelations – and the silences engendered by the public/policy side of sexual history, in which queer oral history has played a critical role.
column2: Sexuality And Oral History: The Challenges Of Public And Private Knowledge

column1:
Mr. Chris Carlsson (Shaping San Francisco)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Workshop

Shaping San Francisco has been engaged in archiving and presenting San Francisco and Bay Area history from below since the mid-1990s. The technological and social trajectory of our project is a living laboratory demonstrating a variety of contemporary forms in which history is made. We host a unique online archive at Foundsf.org which consists of almost 1,800 webpages containing thousands of historic photos, hundreds of video clips from oral histories weve conducted, as well as dozens of historic film clips gleaned from the Prelinger Archive and ever-expanding YouTube collections. We collect and archive primary sources along with excerpts from books and original essays, thereby doing double duty as both a repository of historical materials for future historians as well as an interpretive site for understanding how the many threads of history have brought us to this juncture. In addition to this extensive work of organizing and maintaining our online archive we also produce two seasons annually of Public Talks that are themselves sites of history production. We record and archive our Talks as podcasts. We also host two seasons of walking and bicycle tours each year, taking anywhere from one to several dozen people on curated walks or bike rides through the City to peel back the layers of history in situ. After over two decades of this work we are in partnership with academic programs at Stanford, UC Berkeley, the University of San Francisco, and a dozen local history groups in addition to the San Francisco Public Library and the California Historical Society. Weve also published three anthologies of essays on local history with City Lights Books, the last of which, Ten Years That Shook the City: San Francisco 1968-78 won the California Book Award for contribution to publishing in 2011. At the annual OAH conference in 2018 to be held in Sacramento we propose to host a workshop that demonstrates the multifaceted work weve been doing, and then to convene a critical discussion that would challenge the limits of the effort. Some of the questions we hope to discuss are:1. The role of amateur history production vs. that done by professionals.2. Journalism as the first draft of history—mainstream newspapers and neighborhood newspapers3. Objectivity and neutrality in history production: false goals?4. Browsing as narration, and the loss of coherence.5. If multiple points of view, multiple voices are the proper way to frame historical information is there a role for the Grand Narrative?6. Curriculum standards and public history—inevitable conflict? We propose to present the project for 60% of the workshop time and reserve 40% for critical discussion.
column2: Shaping San Francisco: The Forms Of History

column1:
Chris Blakely (Rutgers University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

The relationship between animals and slaves has recently become an important aspect in the study of New World slavery. Scholars have recently studied numerous aspects of how slaves worked with livestock, as fishermen, or against animals meant to track their very movements. As well, slaves were burdened by living as livestock, often infested with living microbes, vermin, and pests that could both harm and entertain. Slaves found much relevance for these encounters with animals in trickster tales, for labor as cowboys, and even as friendly companions. Many slaves wrote of their experiences with animals throughout the Atlantic World. Often, slaves discussed running from hounds while using their knowledge of the environment to escape the skillful noses of their masters dogs. Many slaves were also burdened through working with agricultural animals in their daily lives. Other slaves found in animals an ephemeral, ritual, and symbolic space to come to terms with the horror of laboring in their masters fields. Animals, and African knowledge about the specific powers of animals within spiritual traditions, often provided forms of psychosomatic resistance to the masters goals of social death. Throughout the Atlantic World, the relationship between animals and slaves created methods for masters to assert their power, as made famous in scenes from the recent film Django Unchained (2012). However, slaves also formulated spaces for resistance in the transgressive particular spaces that animals inhabited. This dialectic, between the power of masters to create bio-political weapons out of animals and the agency of slaves to resist that power through their own beliefs in different animals inherent innocence and transgression, offers a new lens for analyzing the continuum of slave experience in the early modern Atlantic World.
column2: Slavery, Animals, And Environmental Agency In The Atlantic World

column1:
Charles Cobb (Duke University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

We propose a panel on the "SNCC Digital Gateway: Learn from the Past, Organize for the Future, Make Democracy Work," a collaboration including the SNCC Legacy Project, Duke University, and Civil Rights Movement scholars. The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, or SNCC, was founded in 1960 when legendary organizer Ella Baker brought together sit-in leaders from across the South. The only national civil rights organization led by young people, SNCC activists became full-time organizers, working with community leaders to build grassroots organizations in the Deep South. SNCC focused on voter registration and on mounting a systemic challenge to the white supremacy entrenched in the country"s political, economic, and social structures.While scholars have written a number of important books exploring and illustrating the significance of SNCC, the general public tends to know very little about the movement beyond Dr. King and a few high profile demonstrations. Even the attention that has accompanied the series of 50th anniversaries of movement milestones has tended to reinforce a top-down and "Big Events" focus. As the movement"s victories are facing serious challenges and as young people across the country have renewed interest in direct action, organizing, and challenging ingrained power, it is essential that a fuller, richer accounting of SNCC"s history reach the wider public, especially students, activists, and today"s version of the "ordinary people" who were at the heart of the Civil Rights Movement.The SNCC Digital Gateway, which had a soft-launch on December 13, 2016, is designed to meet this need. Using documentary footage, audio recordings, photographs, and documents, the site portrays how SNCC organizers, alongside thousands of local Black residents, worked so that Black people could take control of their lives. It unveils the inner workings of SNCC as an organization, examining how it coordinated sit-ins and freedom schools, voter registration and economic cooperatives, anti-draft protests and international solidarity struggles. The website includes a wide range of historic materials (hosted in digital collections at repositories around the country); over 150 individual profiles; more than 100 events pages; Inside SNCC pages that explore how the organization worked; an Our Voices section, which presents aspects of SNCC"s history from the eyes of the activists themselves; and a Map, which connects users to the people who worked--and the events that happened--in specific places. The project team is currently identifying and developing materials that are especially germane today, and exploring relevant and accessible formats for sharing it.Our panel will include four people from the editorial board--SNCC veterans Judy Richardson and Charles Cobb, Jr., and scholars Hasan Kwame Jeffries and Emilye Crosby--reflecting on the project and resulting website. After a brief introduction to the website, the panelists will discuss how the project and website content was developed; plans for using the site to engage teachers, students, activists, and others (as well as initial experiences); and their hopes for how the website and its content will inform future generations. [If possible, we will also include a Mississippi K-12 teacher who has developed lesson plans and used the site in teaching.]
column2: Sncc Digital Gateway: Learn From The Past, Organize For The Future, Make Democracy Work

column1:
Dr. Adriana Greci Green (Fralin Art Museum, University of Virginia)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Most historians incorporate some form of material culture into their research, and many of us rely on visual evidence to create powerpoints for classroom teaching. This panel argues for going beyond the use of material culture by incorporating hands-on experience into teaching and as a component of our research. In practice, this involves developing knowledge, skills and values from direct experiences outside a traditional academic setting. The three panelists discuss the various ways in which their research and teaching has pursued this emerging academic pathway. Nancy Shoemakers broad-based approach discusses how her research depends on understanding how soap was made and its implications for those people who engaged in the process. She discusses the three kinds of experiential research employed in her work: fieldwork to fields and factories, her chemistry research that allows her to better understand the process, and her personal experience in manufacturing soap. Both Professors Sleeper-Smith and Marrero work in the western Great Lakes, where Sleeper-Smith examines womens role in the fur trade and Marrero explores the Indigeneous-French culture of nineteenth-century communities near Detroit. Sleeper-Smith examines the prosperity that the fur trade brought to Indigenous communities through the trade silver that was manufactured to obtain Indian peltry and its extensive proliferation to show how the fur trade was indicative of Indigenous prosperity, rather than decline and demise. Marrero shows the prevalence of music and song as a medium of cultural transmission in Great Lakes French communities. Professor Marreros research incorporates the hybrid songs that characterized the shared culture of French and Indigenous nations. Professor Sleeper-Smith will display a small collection of Indigenous silver objects to discuss their meanings in Indigenous culture. Professor Marrero will sing and analyze one of the songs that embodies the musical tradition of French Detroit.
column2: Soap, Silver, And Song: Experiential History In Research And Teaching

column1:
Professor Mark Buccella (University of Minnesota)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 11:30 to 13:00

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Luncheon

Erika Lee is a Distinguished McKnight University Professor, the Rudolph J. Vecoli Chair in Immigration History, and the Director of the Immigration History Research Center at the University of Minnesota. She is the author of three award-winning books in U.S. immigration and Asian American history: At America"s Gates: Chinese Immigration during the Exclusion Era, 1882-1943 (University of North Carolina Press, 2003), Angel Island: Immigrant Gateway to America (co-authored with Judy Yung, Oxford University Press, 2010), and most recently, The Making of Asian America: A History (Simon & Schuster, 2015, 2nd ed., 2016, Chinese version, 2018), which was the recipient of the 2015 Asian Pacific American Award for Literature from the American Library Association. It was an Editors Choice by the New York Times and named to the Best Nonfiction Books of 2015 list by Kirkus Reviews. She is currently working on a history of xenophobia in the United States. At the IHRC, she directs the Immigrant Stories digital storytelling and archiving project (immigrantstories.umn.edu) funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities, and she co-organized the #ImmigrationSyllabus project (www.immigrationsyllabus.umn.edu).SHGAPE is able to offer a limited number of luncheon tickets at a lower rate to graduate students on a first-come, first-served basis. Please purchase the luncheon ticket at full prince and contact alwood@ilstu.edu before March 10 to receive a refund of the difference. Please note that all refunds will be issued after March 10.
column2: Society For Historians Of The Gilded Age And Progressive Era Luncheon: America First, Immigrants Last: American Xenophobia Then And Now

column1:
Professor Cathleen D Cahill (Pennsylvania State University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: State of the Field

This state of the field panel will investigate new scholarship and debates in the field of American Indian history. A panel of leading historians in the field will lead this round table discussion about the methodologies, theories, and historiography that define the field. Scholars will also feature an analysis of their own scholarship and how it advances the field of American Indian history. A talented pool of historians will guide discussion about a range of topics, periods, and schools of thought.
column2: State Of The Field--American Indian History

column1:
Professor Stephen Kantrowitz (Univ. of Wisconsin-Madison)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: State of the Field

There has been a proliferation of new work on the movement to abolish slavery in the United States, the process of the emancipation of enslaved people, and the meaning of those changes through the Civil War and beyond. This panel brings together leading scholars to consider these new historiographies, their significance for understanding the history of the nineteenth century, and their lessons for our contemporary politics.
column2: State Of The Field: Abolition And Emancipation

column1:
Professor Marisela Chavez (California State University, Dominguez Hills)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: State of the Field

This spring marks the fiftieth anniversary of many critical Chicana/o Movement actions including the East L.A. Blowouts. In this roundtable, the panelists will reconsider 1968 alongside the rise of Chicana/o Movement historiography. Since the first calls for raza studies, scholars have worked diligently to recuperate these histories and build a body of scholarship that explains that significance of Chicana/o experience. This panel will assess this work, its revelations about the movement, the emergence of its foundational scholars who have documented and theorized its relevance, and the future of the field.
column2: State Of The Field: Chicana/O Movement History

column1:
Dr. Thomas G Andrews (University of Colorado Boulder)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: State of the Field

This state-of-the-field roundtable will consider the past, present and future of the field of Western history. Thomas Andrews, Ari Kelman, Amy Lonetree, Mary Mendoza, and Christina Snyder will discuss, among other topics, recent trends in indigenous history, memory studies and public history, the history of the Southwest and other borderlands, Chicano/a history, and environmental history. They will explore a region whose shifting landscapes – both in terms of historiography and book publishing – seem to have placed it, once again, at the center of a number of important disciplinary debates.
column2: State Of The Field: Western History

column1:
Professor Laura F Edwards (History Department, Duke University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: State of the Field

This roundtable reconsiders the narrative of women"s rights across the nineteenth century. The common struggle-for-suffrage narratives dominated the discussions of Clintons presidential candidacy and will only be amplified as we approach the centennial of the Nineteenth Amendment. Meanwhile, within the profession, so much stellar work has come out demolishing such a narrative. But little of it has come together to produce a new synthesis. One—or several—that can begin to edge out suffrage-centric narratives in popular discourse, college surveys, and historiographical discussions.
column2: State Of The Field: Which Way Forward?  A New Synthesis For Nineteenth-Century Womens Rights

column1:
The Audience ()

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel examines the form of African American womens biography in two ways. First, our panel consists of two academic historians and one filmmaker who is a professor of communications. We will compare the possibilities and pitfalls of telling black womens stories in the traditional form of biography versus the format of film. Second, our panel considers the forms that biography takes when the subjects present challenges to linear storytelling. Blairs paper addresses the secrecy that enveloped the life of comedian Jackie Moms Mabley. How to construct a life narrative of Jackie Mabley, a woman who strenuously resisted incursions into her private life, often revising previous renditions of her past? Mabley presents a challenge to her biographer, not only because she so skillfully managed her public persona, but because both her comedic dissemblance and her secrets register personal trauma and reflect the changing racial, gender, and sexual politics of her times. Blair explores the challenges presented by Mableys life story and the craft of biography.Hudson, in her paper about the expatriate and psychoanalyst Marie Battle Singer, examines the self-fashioning that Singer practiced in her career abroad. Singer migrated to Germany in the 1940s, and then to London where she studied with Anna Freud and set up practice on Harley Street. In oral histories with Singers friends and family, Hudson (and her co-author) has discovered a wide range of tales that Singer told in order to place herself in a black world that the British would recognize. Singer was especially fond of linking herself to the history of slavery; she regularly described herself as the granddaughter of illiterate slaves even though her grandparents operated a secondary school in Okolona, Mississippi. This paper investigates the form this biography might take given the stories and fabrications Singer created about herself.Davis faces some of the same problems of fabrication as she wrestles with the stories of jazz musician Clora Bryant and abolitionist Sojourner Truth. Davis explores the form of African American women"s biography in her paper about her films: the documentary feature, "Trumpetistically Clora Bryant" and her current experimental work in progress, "The Way of Truth: A Meditation on Sojourner Truth." Both women presented challenges to Davis as she translated their lives in film. Clora Bryants fifty year career in the jazz world of Los Angeles provided Davis with compelling material as a storyteller. Yet Davis faced important questions about form and narrative. Sojourner Truths life, as historians have documented, is filled with myths and silences. In this new project, Davis aims to explore Truths control over her representation. All three papers will address questions that animate the work of historians and filmmakers: How should the narrator handle the significant silences that attach themselves to black womens lives? Which forms, in either genre, are best-suited to tell the story of womens lives? How should the voice of the narrator come through (or not) in the story? Are there new forms of writing and filming black womens biography that we might pursue?
column2: Storytelling And African American Women's Biography

column1:
Dr. Lloyd Barba (Amherst College)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

The field of Pentecostal studies is a growing one. While early works on Pentecostal history were largely written by ministers untrained in scholarly techniques, more recently, scholars devoted to appropriate disciplinary methodologies have published a wide range of works. These scholars are academics, like the ones on this panel, and may hold positions in a variety of institutions, some seminaries, some private universities, and some public colleges. To what degree this more secular approach will be accepted by more traditional Pentecostal institutions is currently under debate. The editors of Pneuma, the Journal for the Society of Pentecostal Studies, a group largely comprised of those with Pentecostal affiliations, wrote in Fall 2016 that the field should expand and move toward theoretical discourses in the social sciences, physical sciences, and comparative religion. Papers such as the ones proposed in this panel are key to expanding the field in this direction.In addition, while early Pentecostal histories documented the lives of the mostly male ministers, these historians are also concerned with recovering the pasts of those often left out of the traditional narratives. In particular, this panel discusses the ways in which Pentecostal women often subverted traditional forms of authority while also upholding church teachings. The Pentecostal movement benefited from the work of women, both in the ministry and in the laity. Women contributed to the ongoing theological and political debates within their ranks. The role of women both in society and in the church was of concern to the movement. Women in the ministry often faced discriminatory policies such as licensing restrictions that limited their roles in the church and meant they were always in danger of losing their pulpits. Despite these restrictions, women often either ignored or found ways to work around such rules. Women in the pews also contributed to building the physical church, often by providing the funding for the construction of new facilities. Mexican-American women in California, for example, sold tamales, a product usually created through communal labor. In this way, the kitchen became a place where these women both upheld and challenged Pentecostal teachings. Discussions about such women have the ability to help Pentecostals reexamine their narratives and to create more inclusive ones.
column2: Subverting Authority: The Pentecostal Women Who Built Their Movements

column1:
Ms. Rebecca K Marchiel (University of Mississippi)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Recent interest in the history of capitalism has drawn attention to the influence of market forces on American society and culture, but has also opened new avenues for understanding how daily life and social protest reshaped capitalism to meet the needs of the economically disadvantaged. This panel will contribute to this historiography by focusing on Chicago in the Twentieth Century. By examining various groups of people who sought to take control of their economic futures, this panel will consider the evolving methods by which the economically marginal responded to the forces of capitalism. Whether through participating in extra-legal gambling, protesting for relief, or pressuring financial institutions to expand lending policies, this panel finds that urban residents pushed against economic constraints to protest the ramifications of American capitalist practices and improve their lives. In the process, this panel will assess the historic possibilities and limitations of taking control of economies.In Policy Gambling as Black Womens Work and Black Womens Space, Betsy Schlabach (Associate Professor of History, Earlham College) finds that African American women in Chicago used policy gambling as a source of employment and security, but that same security was compromised by the mobility and evasiveness the work required. Using arrest records and following the daily habits of African American women policy workers, Schlabach concludes that work in the policy industry demanded simultaneous visibility and invisibility, an impossible task. In Unemployed Workers, Urban Reformers, and the Fate of Capitalism in 1930s Chicago, Abigail Trollinger (Assistant Professor of History, St. Norbert College) centers on the Workers Committee on Unemployment, a Depression-era organization through which jobless workers called for more relief funds and an end to casework. Trollinger demonstrates that, in partnering with moderate reformers and distancing themselves from Communist rhetoric, these WCOU workers committed to reshaping, rather than abandoning, American capitalism. Finally, in Urbanites Fight for Capital during 1980s Financial Deregulation, Rebecca Marchiel (Assistant Professor of History, University of Mississippi) explores the activism of the urban reinvestment movement, a multiracial coalition of low- and moderate-income urbanites, founded in Chicago in 1972. Marchiel shows that activists – responding to 1980s budget cuts and changes to federal banking regulations that created new openings and obstacles for residents of capital-starved neighborhoods – successfully partnered with banks to expand affordable housing opportunities in Chicago, but in doing so foreclosed more equitable alternatives for urban revitalization. Together, these three papers offer a landscape of the economically disadvantaged in Chicago who, over the course of the twentieth century, made claims to their economic fates and ultimately altered the meaning and practice of capitalism in the city.The chair and discussant is Jon Shelton, Assistant Professor of Democracy and Justice Studies at the University of Wisconsin-Green Bay. He is the author of Teacher Strike! Public Education and the Making of a New American Political Order (University of Illinois Press, 2017), and his research has also been published in LABOR: Studies in Working-Class History of the Americas, the Journal of Social History, and the Journal of Policy History.
column2: Taking Control Of Capitalism In 20th Century Chicago

column1:
Dr. Andrew C. Isenberg (Temple University)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

The inevitability of U.S. western conquest, often described as the process as expansion or Manifest Destiny, is a narrative that continues to plague American history. Even as historians have made immense strides to reveal the complex worlds of indigenous and Hispanic peoples whom this conquest overran, their stories are still framed as foreordained declension stories: of course the United States military and demographic dominance would eventually subsume the West. Yet, as this roundtable will discuss, neither the United States nor most of its citizens assumed inevitable U.S. triumph. On the contrary, the future of the West remained fluid, and federal officials and American settlers responded to this fluidity by experimenting with permanent alternatives to U.S. dominance.Building upon their contributions to the special issue of the Pacific Historical Review Alternative Wests: Rethinking Manifest Destiny (February 2016), the panelists will discuss the many narratives that contradict the story of inevitable U.S. expansion, particularly those that were voiced and acted out by Americans themselves: the creation of independent governments in Florida, Texas, Oregon, and Utah; the willingness of U.S. officials to seek out Native people as allies and cater to their wishes; the varied imaginings of different – and permanent – western polities among countless Americans; and the many migrations and trading partnerships that directly countered U.S. western expansion. The panel will thus explore various means to disentangle western and U.S. history from the trope of Manifest Destiny, and offer historiographical paths that reveal the complexity – and even unlikelihood – of U.S. conquest.
column2: Taking The State Back Out: The Irrelevance Of The Federal Government In The West, 1803-1861

column1:
Dr. Lauren Tess Bundy (Merrimack College)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

Bostons experience of public school desegregation (1974-1988) was violent and divisive, and consequently, residents memories of the crisis are frequently partisan and distorted. Recently, however, Boston Public Schools and area universities have encouraged students to interrogate mandatory busing and challenge the dominant narrative, which emphasizes the policys failure, by examining why African-American activists fought for years to end Bostons policies of de facto segregation. Spurred on by the 40th anniversary marking court-ordered integration and the resulting citywide remembrances, area archival repositories identified and digitized relevant primary sources.The digitizing of the historical record led, in turn, to the establishment of a multi-institutional digital archive that houses material from several repositories with differing missions and collecting foci. Inter-archival collaborators collected material on the same subject from widely different perspectives – government and school officials, the courts, anti-busing and integrationist activists, parents, students, and educators – to present a more complicated and nuanced narrative of desegregation. Educators then used the digital archive to create primary-source-based curricula for elementary, secondary, and college students. The resulting learning modules emphasize student acquisition of the critical stance needed to think historically, interpret and evaluate data, and to engage in meaningful civic participation. Further, students could understand how authority is constructed and contextualized, thereby gaining knowledge of how archives are organized by human decisions, and how humans shape archives and, in turn, historical interpretation. Presenters will discuss the development of inter-institutional collaborations among archivists, activists and educators, and the value of primary-source-based curricula for the teaching of historical, information, and civic literacy. Participants will leave with a blueprint for creating inter-archival collaborations on any topic using available digital tools and services.
column2: Teaching Contested History: Digital Archives And Digital Maps

column1:
Ms. Abigail Feely (American River College)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

In 1999, the same year that Larry Page and Sergey Brin moved their eight employees out of a garage and into Googles first office building, Neil Postman issued a prescient warning: we need to teach students to use technology, not be used by it. Even before smartphones and streaming video and before Google became a verb, Neil Postman looked forward into the future of technology while simultaneously reaching back for the wisdom of educator John Dewey: The best way for citizens to protect their liberty is for them to be encouraged to be skeptical, to be suspicious of authority, and to be prepared (and unafraid) to resist propaganda.1 Dewey and Postmans admonitions have only become more relevant in the 21st century. Teaching students to think critically has always been central to our work as history educators, and has become even more essential in the digital age. Digital forms of history create new epistemological realities and dilemmas that impact the construction of historical knowledge. Historical information in the form of websites, blogs, newsfeeds, social media posts, and other items generated in google searches greatly impacts how students come to know history in the 21st century. And in a culture of google-knowing, what some have termed a post-fact age, student often mistakenly imbue online information with authority without first considering how to evaluate it. The superabundance of instant online content requires that students master the ability to evaluate sources. This roundtable will feature a lively discussion among historians from around the nation that represent historical pedagogy across several segments: the high school, the community college, and the 4-year college. These panelists represent historians who are committed to student success and critical thinking development, as well as harnessing the advantages (and disadvantages) of the internet in creative and timely ways. A useful and relevant discussion, both philosophical and practical, will cover of the impact of digital information on student thinking and the use of the digital media into our classrooms.The audience will be invited to join the panelists in discussing:•The impact of the internet and social media on student thinking, assumptions, and skills.•Designing pedagogy in a culture of google-knowing.•Best practices in teaching students to evaluate online information and sources; how to increase students" abilities to find, ethically use, synthesize, and evaluate information from electronic media. Using online archives in face-to-face classes to teach source credibility.•Teaching students how to marshal historical information to engage in and evaluate online discussions and controversies that require a historical awareness. •The relevance of history in digital spaces: strategies for tying historical literacy to current events and cultural discussions trending on social media and in newsfeeds. •Specific state-wide and campus-wide pedagogical initiatives including: The Information Literacy Academy and the California Community College Success Network Threshold Initiative. 1.Neil Postman, Building a Bridge to the 18th Century (New York: Random House, 1999): 160.
column2: Teaching Historical Literacy In The Digital Age

column1:
Dr. Marika Elizabeth Manos (Long Beach Unified School District)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Doing History Workshop

This workshop will focus on how to approach Advanced Placement Historical Thinking Skills (Analyzing Historical Sources and Evidence, Making Historical Connections, Chronological Reasoning, and Creating and Supporting a Historical Argument) when teaching with primary sources. The presenter offers a structure for deciding which historical thinking skill to highlight depending upon the source and task. For example, before answering a historical question or identifying the significance of a source, students need specific instruction around Making Historical Connections or Chronological Reasoning. After modeling how to identify teaching points, the group will construct a set of tasks to develop students ability to Analyze Historical Sources and Evidence. Then, she will take the features of complexity identified in the source to model a writing task that scaffolds the Creation and Support of a Historical Argument. After modeling a lesson, participants work together to identify possible teaching points in an additional document. To close the presentation, participants will share ideas about teaching students to think like historians and discuss points for clarification.
column2: Teaching Historical Thinking Skills: An Approach To Teaching With Primary Sources

column1:
Ms. Erin N Bush (George Mason University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This round table brings together faculty from a wide range of institutions and points in their career to talk about incorporating digital tools into the classroom. Coming with varied experience levels with digital tools, what lessons have they learned, what cautions do they offer, what suggestions do they have? This session will have something for those looking to integrate a digital tool into one assignment, those looking to create an entire digital history course from scratch, and everyone in between.
column2: Teaching History Digitally

column1:
Dr. Cameron Addis (Austin Community College)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 09:00 to 12:00

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Workshop

The Committee on Community Colleges is hosting a teaching-oriented workshop for the 2018 OAH meeting in Sacramento, California. The theme for this years meeting is Teaching in an Era of Partisanship. All of us have dealt with partisanship throughout our careers, but the recent election, advent of fake news, and hardening and broadening of media along partisan lines has made it increasingly challenging for teachers and professors to deal with controversial material. Yet, deal with it we must, since controversy is inherent in teaching meaningful history. We encounter a variety of students across the country and encourage instructors from a wide range of demographics to submit a paper. Panelists will present and discuss their creative lectures, lessons and activities that use history to focus on filtering information or recognizing bias, or help to put this hyper-partisan era of fragmented media in historical perspective. The panel will include 3-4 presenters a Q & A session and lunch with a keynote speaker.
column2: Teaching In A Partisan Era

column1:
Dr. Rachel B. Reinhard (UC Berkeley History-Social Science Project)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

The 2011 FAIR Education Act represented a major step forward in broadening the inclusivity of the history taught in Californias K-12 classrooms. In particular, it mandated that the history of LGBTQ people be included in all middle and high school curricula. This session explores how teachers are working to integrate LGBTQ history into their courses. The panel is comprised of academics who have advised about the latest scholarly research and educators who have designed FAIR Act-aligned lesson plans and want to share practical examples of how teachers across the nation can easily incorporate LGBTQ history into their social science curricula.
column2: Teaching Lgbt History To K12 Students:  A Roundtable

column1:
Lawrence Charap (College Board)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

Many students enter into the AP or U.S. History survey courses having never heard of the History of Medicine or Environmental history, both of which are fundamental to American history. This session focuses on the ways in which medical history and environmentalism are inseparable from understanding, for example, the Progressive Era, World Wars I and II, the New Deal, and the Civil Rights Movement. The session will also address how the latest research in these fields can be incorporated into the classroom.
column2: Teaching The Environment And Medicine In The U.S. History Survey

column1:
Mrs. Mary Anne Junqueira ()

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable considers the challenges and opportunities for teaching U.S. history abroad in the current political climate of America First, a slogan popularized by 1930s isolationists and recently revived by President Trump as the rallying cry for putting national interests above all other global concerns. This shift towards an inward looking American nationalism poses unique challenges for U.S. historians working abroad. Many students attending foreign universities have reacted negatively to Americas rising anti-immigrant sentiment, saber-rattling against longtime foes, and new conflicts with traditional allies. For some students this hostility manifests as disinterest in courses on United States history. For others, it has increased interest for more focused explanations of the current climate. Rather than ignoring these issues, historians abroad are grappling with ways to address them in their courses while still covering basics about U.S. history that are sometimes taken for granted in American classrooms. To consider these strategies, the roundtable brings together historians from four continents and four countries (Canada, Brazil, Germany, and Qatar) to consider these questions. The historians include both scholars teaching in English-language institutions and those teaching at non-English universities as well as a range of experience from early to late career scholars.
column2: Teaching U.S. History Overseas In A Time Of Only America First

column1:
Professor Susan Douglas (The University of Michigan)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

Historians always approach primary sources with some level of caution, questioning the maker of that source and interrogating the motives that led to its creation. This roundtable considers the use of television as a primary source, and the study of television as a form of history. Participants will discuss the ways they have utilized television in their own research, incorporating clips from television shows as part of the discussion. In what ways does television differ from other primary sources, and how is it best deployed in historical argument? What can television tell us that other sources cannot?
column2: Television As A Primary Source

column1:
Dr. Rhae Lynn Lynn Barnes (University of Southern California / Princeton)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel brings together scholars of African American history, womens history, performance history, religious history, and Southern history who regularly use sources written by and for white people to tell the stories of black historical actors. In this panel, the talks of which span the long 19th century, we will grapple with the challenges and opportunities these sources offer in our various attempts to uncover black lives from various archives. At the heart of this panel is a will to consider a simple but ever-pressing question: How do our sources shape and constrain the interpretive possibilities for telling black stories? In other words, how do our sources ultimately form the different ways we can represent the African American past? This session will run as a traditional paper presentation with a roundtable slant. Each participant will present abbreviated (1000-word) remarks on the topics presented below, and the commenter will provide a brief comment meant to provoke questions from the audience. The bulk of this presentation will run as a conversation between the scholars on the panel and the audience, and we encourage audience members to share the trials and triumphs they have experienced in their quest to read against the grain of white sources to tell the stories of African Americans.
column2: Telling Black Stories With White Sources

column1:
Dr. Megan J Elias (Boston University)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

Foodstuffs are a core element of personal and group identity and are integral to the political and economic history of North America. Thinking and teaching about food is not just a way to engage students quickly with the past but also to make them alert to topical intersections as well as to congruencies and continuities across time. This workshop will provide strategies and resources that demonstrate how putting food in the forefront when we teach history helps students identify and better understand connections across categories like race and class, and also across borders. Using three examples of topics common to US history survey courses -- European colonies, Progressive era reforms, and the Civil Rights Movement -- and digital archives, the leaders of the workshop will help workshop participants to develop their own assignments that use food history to enrich or deepen understanding of common subjects in US history. Edible items themselves may not be preserved, but their packaging, promotional materials and governing paperwork live on in archives and private collections. Using in-room computers, we will place educators into working groups to explore digital archives such as the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the National Agricultural Library, and some hidden gems such as the recipes printed in Nation of Islams The Daily Call. This workshop will provide teaching tools for educators to:1. Illustrate how food provides insight to social and cultural movements across history.2. Emphasize the critical role that food has played in creating geo-political boundaries and relationships between American regions and foreign countries.3. Explore the idea of food physically as well as metaphorically sustaining the people of the United States.
column2: The Edible Intersectional: A Teaching Guide

column1:
Professor Hasia R. Diner (New York University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This session aims to start a conversation between historians of migration and historians of emotion. As titles such as Oscar Handlins The Uprooted attest, emotions have often surfaced in histories of migration, but the subfield has yet to incorporate the insights of scholars who study emotion systematically. This oversight constitutes an opportunity missed since foregrounding emotion has the potential to provide fresh answers to enduring questions: How do migrants attachments to their old and new homelands change over time? To what extent do emotional—not economic—imperatives shape migration? What is the lived experience of migration? Ultimately, taking emotion seriously might also alter the forms that historians use to engage students and the public.In the past few decades, historians of emotions have conceptualized—and debated—how inner feelings relate to language, how personal emotions interact with communal norms, and how emotions change over time. Historians of the United States lag behind their Europeanist colleagues, but they are beginning to recognize that emotions have a history and emotions make history. A few trailblazers have suggested the potential benefits of careful attention to the emotions of migration in particular. Hasia Diner, a leading scholar of migration, first made the case in a programmatic essay in 1998. One response has come from an historian of emotions. Susan Matts Homesickness (2011) argued that homesickness, although widespread among migrants, was ultimately suppressed in the interests of fostering a mobile workforce. Historians who work on immigrant correspondence, such as David Gerber, Sonia Cancian, and Suzanne Sinke, discuss adaptation in terms of emotions. In related fields, literary scholars such as Jeffrey Santa Ana and Madelaine Hron have analyzed emotion in immigrant writing, and Paolo Boccagni and Loretta Baldassar recently called for more sociological research on emotions and migration. These forays have yet to ignite a sustained exchange, the goal of this session. The case studies in the first two papers bring emotion to established scholarly debates over community formation and information exchange. Alison Clark Efford (Marquette University) will use the documentation of German immigrant suicide to argue that even individual feelings of dislocation are best studied in the context of immigrant communities. Suzanne Sinke (Florida State University) will examine how and why the letters of Austrian refugees revealed or repressed certain emotions. In the third paper, Ana Elizabeth Rosas (University of California, Irvine) opens the conversation to questions of form by discussing a student-curated exhibition on the emotive underpinnings of the material culture of Mexican immigrants.Commentator Susan Matt (Weber State University) will ensure that we generate the sort of meaningful discussion that is not always achieved in the traditional conference session. As an established scholar of emotions, Dr. Matt will suggest how feelings might change histories of migration—in interpretation and form—and encourage audience contributions. As chair and second commentator, Hasia Diner (New York University), past president of the Immigration and Ethnic History Society and author of eleven books, adds weight and coherence to the session. Dr. Diners comments will be brief.
column2: The Emotions Of Migration

column1:
Dr. Monica L. Mercado (Colgate University)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 12:15 to 13:00

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Chat

As colleges and universities across the United States turn a critical eye to the histories of race and racism underlying their very foundations, the work of historians is increasingly harnessed to grapple with these complicated stories and their resonances on our 21st-century campuses. The purpose of this chat seminar is to grow a supportive community that is engaged with the work of campus history projects at public and private institutions of higher education, sites which we understand as important spaces in which Americans engage with the nations past.In the five years since Craig Steven Wilders foundational _Ebony and Ivy: Race, Slavery, and the Troubled History of Americas Universities_ (2013), faculty, students, and administrators have found themselves involved in a wide range of campus history projects that often engage with current campus conversations about diversity, inclusion, and access. In line with the OAH 2018 conference theme, The Forms of History, the chat seminar will move beyond the scholarly monograph and foster conversations about campus histories and the forms in which those histories are represented at our institutions, with particular attention to the value of shared authority between faculty, students, librarians and archivists, alumni, and other campus constituencies. From exhibitions, courses, and internships, to teach-ins, walking tours, and digital repositories, to oral history collecting and archives building, to performances and other creative projects, there is a growing network of resources and models for this work. What are the tools we need to propose or contribute to campus history efforts? How do we respond to critics, both inside of and outside our institutions? Who will document these modern-day struggles over the presence of the past and the power of place in the campus context? Looking at race and racism in elite higher education should also suggest other historical moments with which we still grapple: the radical transgression of suggesting women deserved an education equal to that of men; of suggesting that non-white students could share a classroom with white students; of suggesting that the economically disadvantaged college student or the first generation college student (or the differently abled college student) deserves a seat at the table. Chat moderator Monica L. Mercado has advised and coordinated campus history projects at the University of Chicago, Bryn Mawr College, and Colgate University. In 2015-2016 she was an organizer of the National Council of Public History working group Campus History as Public History. Participants in the chat seminar will think critically about the stories we tell about our campuses and the archives we use to tell them, and share strategies for creating or supporting projects that document contemporary and diverse histories of colleges and universities.
column2: The Forms Of Campus History

column1:
Dr. barbara gannon (University of Central Florida)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable seeks to illuminate the contemporary processes involved in shared historical re-imagining with descendant communities that recover experiences silenced by traditional narratives of history.Sites of trauma within enslaved peoples narratives, carnage during and after the Civil War as well as struggles within post-WWII social movements will be examined to culminate into a forum on community healing from the legacies of these cataclysmic events while incorporating discussions on tangible ways to connect scholars with the public and descendant communities as a whole.
column2: The Forms Of Recovery: A Roundtable On Historical Silences, Restoration, And Commemoration

column1:
Liz Clarke (Illustrator)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Doing History Workshop

What can the testimony of a young, enslaved woman from nineteenth century West Africa teachus about the human experience and the world in which we live? Anyone who teacheshistory knows that it is not so much a case of following a recipe as it is finding ways to givestudents vital content, plus the tools to understand it and finally the means to apply this contentto their everyday lives. At the heart of this process is the balancing of global stories with localexperiences, both to convey important stories and to help students hear the rarely heard voices ofeveryday people. Abina and the Important Men (Second Edition 2016) was written as one instructor"s attemptat this difficult balancing act, by giving students the tools to enter into a conversation with AbinaMansah, a woman who appeared before a court in West Africa to demand her freedom in 1876.The intended outcomes for students are a combination of critical skills, knowledge of historicalcontent and the methods to get at it, and an understanding of what it is historians do and why thestudy of the past is personally, intellectually, emotionally and socially valuable.
column2: The Graphic History:   Where Form And Function Come Together

column1:
Joel Christensen (Brandeis)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Workshop

Innovative uses of digital archives are the driving force behind a new wave of public history, and The HistoryMakers Digital Archive is leading that charge. In this workshop, participants will be given an overview of The HistoryMakers unique life oral history interview format by Founder & Executive Director Julieanna Richardson, as well as a look into the methods used in training The HistoryMakers interviewers. In addition, real world examples of the Digital Archives uses in teaching and scholarship will be provided by professors currently employing it in their classrooms. Workshop participants will be guided through an exploration of the Digital Archive, which combines traditional oral history and state of the art technology to present history in a more engaging form, and will be allowed to create their own VJ Mixtape – a curated playlist of interview segments from the Digital Archive around a chosen topic or theme. Mixtapes on policing in America, reflections on African American experiences with the Classics, the transformative power of reading as a learning tool, and intersectionality in the lives of black women have already been created by scholars and will be available for workshop participants to view.
column2: The Historymakers VJ Mixtape: Presenting Traditional Oral History In An Innovative Digital Form

column1:
Mr. Gregg Michael French (Saint Mary's University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel explores the ways in which Americans imagined the Global South during the Gilded Age and Progressive Era. Specifically, the papers examine how reformers and progressives called for US interventions in and commercial and cultural interactions with the Global South as solutions to matters of race, empire, and labor that they framed as questions or problems—i.e., the Negro Question, the African Question, the Philippine Question, the Race Question, and the Colonial Question, to name a few. Scholarship on the history of American foreign relations during the Gilded Age and Progressive Era has increasingly highlighted the actions of non-state actors, informal diplomats, and cultural diplomats who sought to influence international relations and US diplomacy during the period. As Michael Hogan argues in Paths to Power (2000) this new history focuses on traditional nonstate actors (i.e., corporations, labor unions, banks, and agricultural interests) and less traditional private actors (i.e., minorities) (7). In addition, it is attentive to the influence of race, racism, gender, class, ideology, popular culture, and rhetoric on American diplomacy. Each panelist situates his or her paper in this broader scholarship and turn in the history of American foreign relations. Moreover, they seek to contribute to ongoing discussions about the importance of Gilded Age and Progressive Era transnationalism.
column2: The Making Of The Global South In The U.S. Gilded Age And Progressive Era Imaginary

column1:
Professor M. Alison Kibler (Franklin and Marshall College)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 14:45 to 16:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This interdisciplinary panel examines a century of performance to better understand connections between the politics of gender, sexuality, race, class, and nation in an expanding and diversifying entertainment culture. Focusing on a wide range of performances by and of American women between 1850 and 1960, across genres from tragedy to sheet music, southern vaudeville to flamenco dance, this panel interrogates how gendered performances and imagery in a variety of contexts expanded notions of femininity and womanhood. These papers explore tensions and contradictions in images and narratives of women and chart the relationship between new genres of performance and shifting consumption practices of gendered and raced audiences.Starting in the 1850s, Sara Lampert examines the transformation of the tragedy Camille on the American stage, as touring actresses popularized new versions of the drama. Lampert argues that the Americanization of this play, as it shifted from sentimental morality tale to a raw portrayal of a prostitute, makes visible the shifting gender politics of entertainment in the mid-nineteenth century. Actresses popularized forms of French melodrama that involved new discussions of womens sexual agency and in the process connected with expanding female publics. Next, Gillian Rodger turns to sheet music images of burlesque and variety actresses active during the 1870s and 1880s in order to explore the ways that sexualized images considered solely for male audiences co-existed with images of the same actresses that were considered palatable for middle-class family settings. Rodger examines how these womens performances and skills complicate simple assumptions about the appeal they held for their male audiences.Focusing on the Jim Crow era and segregated black vaudeville and minstrelsy circuits in the South, Cookie Woolners paper looks at how representations of same-sex desire and gender transgression were depicted in this milieu. She argues that songs by blues women about mannish women and sissy men, along with performances by female impersonators hailed black queer audiences in a time before African Americans were welcome in gay bars, positioning black traveling shows as an important site through which to imagine queer life in the South. Rosanne Sia will then take up the Cold War era as the context for examining how Asian American and Tejana dancers used their performances to rework the racialized and sexualized tropes into which their audiences cast them at this time of U.S Empire. Sia uses oral history to open up readings of these womens performances, considering the multiple levels through which they used the live body to critique and reimagine American mythologies of racial democracy.
column2: The Many Imaginaries Of Female Performance, 1850-1960

column1:
Ms. Jacqueline Antonovich (University of Michigan)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This session is a lightning round panel on the emerging scholarship in the field of western history. In includes an overview of the works produced by advanced doctoral students in different Ph.D. programs around the country, and features exciting new research in the field. Topics include: Nineteenth-century gender and womens history; settler colonialism in the Great Plains; resistance of Native peoples, empires, and borderlands; migration stories of Mexican people in the Southern Plains and Midwest and Twentieth-century politics; Chicana/Latina voter rights and the international feminist movement; science, technology, and medicine in the North American West; environmental and labor histories of Native Americans; modern Indigenous identity; and African American women and politics in the Pacific Northwest.
column2: The Next Western History: Lightning Round On Emerging Scholarship In The Field

column1:
Professor William Francis Deverell (USC)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule
