Type: Roundtable Discussion

Between roughly 1800 and 1860, an expanding United States acquired or seized huge swaths of territory across North America, thrusting numerous borderland communities and residents into the midst of a contest over the future of slavery in the nation. Slavery advocates, for their part, deployed a number of strategies for pushing an agenda that would both ensure the spread of the institution into these new lands and guard against prohibitive national legislation. This panel explores those multifarious methods and tactics, which ranged from lobbying territorial legislatures to outright filibustering. Too often, however, the literature on slavery and southern interest in the Trans-Mississippi West focuses heavily on familiar debates in Congress and their consequences for eastern politics. In contrast, this panel will reorient the conversation to the western battlegrounds themselves to consider local conditions and discussions about the viability of slavery. In doing so, it will demonstrate how established communities in these far-flung lands confronted southern expansionism and shaped or molded it to their advantage. Southern dreams of empire ultimately hinged on the ability of advocates to navigate the whirlwind of competing nation-states, local elites, and various interest groups in the American borderlands. The southern impetus to see slavery proliferate arguably drove U.S. territorial growth during this period, but western interests determined whether those efforts succeeded or, more often than not, fizzled.In roundtable format, this panel brings together scholars at different stages in their careers to discuss particular cases of pro-slavery expansionism. Each presentation will move the view westward, beginning with Texas, shifting toward the continental interior, and concluding on the Pacific coast. Maria Angela Diaz argues that southerners in the Gulf South embraced Texas as a model and staging ground for expansionist ventures into Latin America, challenging typical geographic conceptualizations of the South, Southwest, and Gulf of Mexico as distinct regions. Similarly, the movement of Anglo-American cotton farmers into Coahuila y Tejas in the 1820s sparked heated debates over slavery in northeastern Mexico that, according to Andrew Torget, culminated in an independent Texas. Matthew Saionz, in turn, explores how the Republic of Texas worked to secure an empire of its own during the early 1840s when its leaders aimed to enforce territorial claims in New Mexico and gain control of the Santa Fe trade. Taking us further westward, Kevin Waite contextualizes the pro-slavery, separatist movements of Arizona and California during the 1850s to consider the numerous ways that antebellum partisans attempted to remake the North American map for slaveholding interests. Stacey Smith argues that southern migrants in California, hoping to contest free soil ideology in the gold mines, pursued other benefits from taking slaves to the Pacific Coast that did not rely on successfully establishing the institution there. To conclude, William Deverell will discuss how Civil War veterans looked upon the West as convalescent space, even as it reverberated with sectional tensions. Collectively, this roundtable offers new perspectives on the interplay of slavery and U.S. expansion and emphasizes the contingency of southern empire-building in the context of borderland politics.
column2: The Old South In The New West: Southern Expansionism And Empire-Building In The American Borderlands

column1:
Professor Michael Stewart Foley (Université Grenoble Alpes)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

We are grateful that the 2018 OAH Annual Meeting theme, the forms of history, offers us an opportunity to propose this panel on one of recent American historys most neglected forms: the history of punk. More specifically, we propose three papers that consider the punk experience of the 1970s and 1980s as vehicle for political expression and engagement. In the landslide of recent books on post-1960s American politics, punk is almost entirely absent. When historians have written about punk in their sweeping chronicles of American political realignment, it has been dismissively, finding that American punk lacked the political edge of British punk or served merely as a rebel pose (Bruce Schulman, for example, derided arch-political band Dead Kennedys as poseurs, seemingly devoted only to flouting established notions of good taste). This dismissal of punk results in a curious omission of youth politics even as cultural studies scholars have, for decades, shown so clearly that young peoples political experience in this period was increasingly tied to the arts, especially music and performance. The three papers in this panel take up this alternative form of political history, considering the question of punk politics vis-à-vis mainstream and radical politics by presenting a mix of less conventional historical sources. These include film and music clips, images and text from underground punk zines and recent oral history interviews. Each paper grows out of the presenters current research projects.We propose to consider punk as an historical phenomenon and process that broadens our understanding of the forms of American political experience. Céline Murillo (Université Sorbonne Paris Cité) will present some of her current research on New York City punk films, seeing the films themselves as political acts per se as well as transmitters of political criticism of failed social and economic urban policy. Michael Stewart Foley (Université Grenoble Alpes) will examine San Francisco punk politics as an early challenge to neoliberal urban policy, showing how punks made common cause with tenants rights, gay rights, and police reform groups while carving out and defending pockets of urban space for their own community. And Kevin Mattson (Ohio University) will take a national view of hardcore punk in the 1980s, highlighting the tension that existed at times between the politics within punk and the intervention of punks in national and local political issues. Taken together, the papers recover subsets of a national subculture engaged in serious political work, even as constraints from within and without became apparent. In keeping with the Program Committees call for proposals, and consistent with punks insistent call to break down the barrier between audience and artist/presenter, we will chair the panel ourselves and ask the audience to serve as commentator. This will allow for maximum interaction with the audience.
column2: The Politics Of Punk In The 1970s And 1980s

column1:
Mr. Daniel Elkin (University of Arkansas-Fayetteville)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Recent election cycles have resuscitated media characterizations of an urban/rural divide in American politics. Additionally, much of the scholarship focuses on a suburban and urban split. These dichotomies certainly exist, but by themselves often distort the role of the city in the development of conservative politics. However broadly we choose to define conservatism, some of its more lasting and effective means of mobilization were forged in the crucible of urban contexts. Questions surrounding poverty, housing, and especially crime animated conservative discourse throughout the 1960s and 1970s. Republicans and Democrats adopted conservative frameworks in addressing these urban issues and each advanced and negotiated the rise of neoliberal governance in their own way. Therefore, it was these urban political laboratories that incubated the conditions for a national rightward turn, with each unique strand coalescing into the Reagan Revolution of 1980.Timothy Lombardos paper concentrates on blue collar conservatism in 1960s and 1970s Philadelphia, moving the lens of scholarly emphasis away from suburbia and instead analyzing the ways in which urban and working-class whites engaged in the selective rejection of liberalism. In addition to redefining spatial assumptions regarding conservatism, Lombardo also challenges regional ones by demonstrating the influence of conservative politics in the liberal northeast. Benjamin Holtzmans paper examines the ways in which grassroots organizing in 1970s New York City manifested in response to the perceived failure of government to prevent crime. The resulting conservative neoliberal law-enforcement apparatus was therefore the result of populist mobilization and not simply the creation of powerful elites (as is often posited). Dan Elkins paper focuses on conservative politics in 1970s San Diego and the uneasy relationship between middle class populism and neoliberal urban development. As Americas Finest City became more reliant on immigrant labor, there also existed a rising tension with the perceived sieve-like border conditions and their supposed connection to crime. Navigating these competing currents, without rejecting either one, became an essential formula to conservative politics in the borderlands.Taken together, these papers hope to advance the discussion on conservative politics in two distinct ways: first by locating some of their more lasting legacies in urban contexts, and second by demonstrating that conservative interactions with neoliberal development did not adhere to predictable patterns or familiar categorizations.
column2: The Right And Cities: Postwar Conservatisms Urban Roots

column1:
Robert Atkins (Professor emeritus, The Union Institute)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable will delve into the history of the struggle of non-tenure track faculty in California, where mass faculty casualization began in the 1970s. The speakers were part of that struggle themselves and represent all three segments of the California public system of higher education: community colleges, California State University system, and University of California, which together make up the largest system of higher education in the United States. We will attempt to draw some lessons for the present and the future as well.
column2: The Roots And Resistance Of Contingent Faculty Labor In California

column1:
Professor Julie Gallagher (Penn State University, Brandywine)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 11:00 to 12:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

This roundtable brings together three of the contributors and the two editors of the soon-to-be/newly published book, Dismantling Historical Boundaries: Essays Centering Womens Nontraditional Lives (forthcoming, University of Illinois Press, 2018). Panel participants will discuss some of the key themes, vital lessons, and exceptional insights that the book illuminates in the course of its eighteen essays. These include: the daunting challenges but also the rewards that many women encounter as they pursue a life of the mind; the significance of mentorship in the field of history and academia more generally; the tangible and intangible importance of financial support to scholars without resources; the state of the historical profession and academia; the commitment to not only writing histories of women but also preserving their voices in archives. The panelists will also explore the sometimes unrecognized ways that historical subjects we write about have served as inspirations in our own lives. And finally, participants will reflect on the challenges and opportunities of writing and editing a collection of mini-biographies, an exercise most historians neither engage in nor are generally comfortable with. Briefly, the book is a collection of essays written by all the winners of the prestigious Catherine Prelinger Award, a $20,000 stipend. Given annually by the Coordinating Council for Women in History (CCWH) to a scholar of excellence who has not travelled an uninterrupted path from undergraduate study through to a tenure-track position in the academy, the Prelinger Award is among the most generous awards available to scholars studying womens history. The contributors include internationally recognized scholars of womens history as well as more recent scholars at the cutting edge of research. Taken together the eighteen essays demonstrate both the progress womens historians have made in advancing in the profession as well as the persistence of structural and cultural gender-based challenges and expectations that find a disproportionate number of women delaying the start of, or putting on pause for long periods, their goals of becoming professional historians. At the same time, the essays serve as a testament to the importance of supporting scholars who may not have access to institutional resources. Over the years, the books contributors have written field-shifting works that have broadened our understanding of U.S. history in many geographic areas, they have written about fantastically diverse topics, including: the history of migrant workers, refugees in the American South West, lesbian feminist print culture of the 1970s and 1980s, Indigenous women in settler-colonial interactions in North America, the challenges of unwelcome trailblazers, including African American women into government agencies. Finally, the contributors give readers a rare and inspiring insight into their tenacious pursuit for a life of the mind and for the determination to make a difference not only in the field of history but also in the lives of women far beyond the gates of the academy. We anticipate that this panel will generate a lively and important discussion about womens status in the profession and as historical subjects.
column2: They Broke Down Barriers: They Transformed History

column1:
Craig Staggs (Minnow Mountain)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Film Screening

On Aug. 1, 1966, a sniper rode the elevator to the top floor of the University of Texas Tower and opened fire, holding the campus hostage for 96 minutes. The toll included 16 dead, three dozen wounded in the first mass shooting in American history. Combining archival footage with rotoscopic animation, Tower offers a dynamic and dramatic narrative account unpacking the competing stories of the witnesses, heroes and survivors to understand what happened and what the shooting has come to mean.Release date: October 12, 2016 (USA)Director: Keith MaitlandAwards: Critics" Choice Documentary Award Most Innovative DocumentaryNominations: Gotham Independent Film Award for Best Documentary, MoreProducers: Keith Maitland, Megan Gilbride, Susan Thomson
column2: Tower

column1:
Dr. Christopher J Castaneda (CSU, Sacramento)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This session examines Spanish-speaking anarchists and how they struggled for social, political, and economic freedom in the United States. Employing the concept of liberty, Hispanic anarchists utilized a transnational print network to build community and promote labor organizing as well as social and economic justice. Despite popular notions that anarchists were simply focused on fomenting chaos and violent revolution, in reality most anarchists primarily desired freedom from traditional forms of political, social and economic oppression. Precisely to avoid the stereotypical misunderstandings of anarchism, many militants therefore embraced flexible, experimental, and even pluralistic approaches to the "anarchist ideal" including support of national values and states as a transitory way to achieve individual freedom and the anarchist society. As historian Kenyon Zimmer has stated, this respect for the individual and corresponding defense of diversity as a positive good in itself formed the core of anarchists cosmopolitan thought and practice. (Zimmer, Immigrants Against the State, 210). The underlying theme of this session is that the political, social and economic contexts in Spain and Latin America deeply influenced Hispanic anarchists in the U.S. These presentations therefore acknowledge and expand on the work of James Baer, Jesse Cohn, Montse Feu, Tom Goyens, Jennifer Guglielmo, Lily Litvak, Jorell Meléndez-Badillo, Kirwin Shaffer, Travis Tomchuk, David Turcato, and Kenyon Zimmer all of whom emphasize the various ways in which national boundaries became less meaningful to anarchists. The papers also build on the transnational theory put forth by Nicolás Kanellos on Latino culture in the United States: … from its origins in the early nineteenth century to the present, [it] has been a transnational phenomenon, one that crosses borders physically or symbolically or in both ways, constructs more than one national identity at a time or deconstructs and rejects them all (Kanellos, Hispanic Immigrant Literature, 34). To interrogate these themes and issues, this session examines four seminal episodes of the Hispanic anarchist experience in North America. Kirwin Shaffer explores the anarchist print network of the late 19th through early 20th century that connected Spanish-speaking libertarians in Puerto Rico, Cuba and Florida. Chris Castaneda then describes the ways in which Spanish-born anarchists based in New York began to dialogue with other U.S.-based anarchists including Ricardo Flores Magón on the West Coast. Sonia Hernandez examines the emergence of an anarchist community during the early 20th century in the Texas-Tamaulipas borderlands. Montse Feu concludes the session by exploring the ways in which Spanish anarchist writers and literary figures in the U.S. depicted the Spanish Civil War and its legacy. As a group, these presentations focus on the achievements of the often marginalized, yet influential, Hispanic anarchists who promoted libertarian ideals along with revolutionary social, political, and economic change in the United States.
column2: Transnational Hispanic Anarchists: The North American Experience

column1:
Dr. Eiichiro Azuma (University of Pennsylvania)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel explores the migrations of Japanese people and foods around the Pacific world, to highlight the emerging but still under-utilized form of evidence of food as a mode of transpacific connection. Food offers insight into intimate, everyday practices and ideas at the same time that they depend, as the panels papers show, on global exchanges of knowledge, resources, and people. This panel, by exploring the conjoined migrations of people and foods, illuminates an underexplored connection binding the Pacific world in the long-20th century. This adds to the burgeoning literature of the Pacific world, a world system as critical to U.S. history as the Atlantic one but still far less studied. Further, it underscores Japan and its links with the United States in that world. Japan has long been overshadowed by China, which is positioned along with the United States in both the scholarly and popular imaginations as a magnetic pole of the region. Yet, running below contemporaneous, near-mythical ideas about China was a far more consistent U.S.-Japanese trade and far more explosive imperial competition. Finally, this panel adds to the conceptualization of the Japanese diaspora, which has been undertheorized in the historical literature. However, as these papers make clear, Japanese migrants and their children continued to be linked in various ways to their home nation, while their actions further entangled Japan with the United States and contributed to Japanese imperialism as well as postwar Japanese and U.S. expansionisms. The first two papers explore the inter-imperial movements between Japan, Taiwan, and territorial Hawaii. Mariko Iijima follows Japanese migrants as agents of shared coffee-producing skills and materials between U.S. Hawaii and Japanese Taiwan; these migrants, Iijima argues, helped motor the coffee industry in these colonies and, perhaps, imperial control. Eiichiro Azuma examines the pineapple in a similar narrative of interwar, intercolonial transfers of knowledge and migrants; he argues that Japanese imperial ideologies of overseas racial development, U.S. frontier myths, as well as shifting local conditions help us understand Japanese migrants diasporic movements and the inter-imperial exchanges. The second two papers shift to the second generation, to continue the story of ethnics and their role in, rather than imperialisms, Japanese and U.S. expansionism. Robert Hegwood explores their place in the transformation of U.S. tastes; Hegwood examines the massive U.S. postwar popularity of sukiyaki to argue that a range of Japanese American entrepreneurs reshaped U.S. ideas about Japanese food and culture, paving the way for the explosive popularity of Japanese foods and products. Meredith Oda narrates the Cold War trajectory of imported Japanese soy sauce in the United States from a disparaged specialty item to a pantry staple; she argues this depended on not just taste, industry adaptations, and a persistent ethnic entrepreneur, but also the suburbanization of Asian Americans who provided a growing foundation for national markets. Together, these papers stake the particular, contingent, and localized roots of transpacific circulations of Japanese/American people and goods.
column2: Transpacific Circulations Of Japanese People And Foods

column1:
Professor Renato Barahona (University of Illinois at Chicago, Emeritus)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

In Sacramento in 1935 eighteen Communist union organizers went on trial on criminal syndicalism charges. A jury convicted eight--though their "crime" consisted of working to organize those at the bottom of the social ladder--and a judge sentenced them to prison. This shocking episode was not an isolated phenomenon, because the Golden State saw many fierce struggles to organize in the fields and food-processing plants during the Great Depression--and also intense anti-communism.I began studying these struggles when working on my Stanford dissertation about cannery workers in the Santa Clara Valley (now Silicon Valley) during the 1930s. That research became the germ of a book, SILICON VALLEY, WOMEN, AND THE CALIFORNIA DREAM. I subsequently held a Fulbright Chair in Moscow and had the opportunity to use the Comintern archives and examine the reports of CP organizers in the Valley in the early 30s--though this research has been shared only at a conference in Moscow. Still very interested in the role of the CP in California, I am currently awaiting the FBI file of a woman fired as a school principal in a small southern California town for being an unfriendly witness before HUAC.When I read that the OAH would be in Sacramento, it occurred to me that this would be an excellent venue for a roundtable on the subject of California Communism. I was aware of new work and of projected work on this topic, so I contacted various scholars, all of whom were enthusiastic. This roundtable will examine such topics as these: Does Carey McWilliams"s formulation of "California: the Great Exception" work for California Communism? How did CP women fare? How much interest did the CP show in organizing various groups of people of color? The world has heard a great deal about the Hollywood blacklist, but what about other victims of Cold War anxieties? Where in the state was the CP most successful? What other industries other besides entertainment, maritime commerce, and food saw CP organizing efforts? How did the CP contribute to the development of a Left-Labor culture in San Francisco after World War II and what happened to it? What was the impact of the Taft-Hartley Act in California during the late 1940s? What was the relationship between California"s Old Left and the New Left during the 1960s?Besides myself as chair, the other participants would be Robert Cherny, author of two journal articles on the California CP and a forthcoming book on a Communist artist in San Francisco; Renato Barahona, an Iberianist now working on Rose Isaak and her involvement with the San Francisco American Russian Institute, which appeared on the Attorney General"s list; Beth Slutsky, author of GENDERING RADICALISM: WOMEN AND COMMUNISM IN TWENTIETH-CENTURY CALIFORNIA; and Lisa Jackson, a graduate student working on putting California"s CP women into an international context.
column2: Twentieth-Century Communism In The Golden State:  A Roundtable

column1:
Ms. Kate Chilton (San Jose State University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

In 2013, the California State University"s Chancellors Office labeled U.S. history survey classes high-demand and low-success bottlenecks. This was because more than one-fifth of CSU students enrolled in the survey earned a failing grade or withdrew from the class. In the CSUs, such "bottlenecks" affect tens of thousands of students every year--20,000 freshmen earned one or more repeatable grades in the Fall 2015 term alone. Intense institutional scrutiny of "low success" bottlenecks has followed from detailed data "dashboards." At the moment, history survey courses are viewed as something of a foil to "student success," a political and educational imperative in public universities today. Evidence also suggests that when students fail or must pay to repeat an entry-level course such as US history, there are considerable psychic as well as economic consequences for California"s middle-class families. This scrutiny has left historians in the CSU system feeling somewhat vulnerable. Over the past three and 1/2 years, approximately 30 historians working across 23 separate campuses have worked together to substantially "redesign" both how we teach and what we teach in lower-division US history survey courses. We have also used technology more purposefully, with deeper integration with our course goals. Further, we have been compelled to see these classes as much more than entry-level history courses: They are gateways to college degrees and college "success." We have also delved deeply into what students bring to our classes, both in terms of disciplinary bias and financial insecurity. We are now launching what is perhaps the largest survey and and most rigorous assessment of its kind: A tool to better understand what helps first-year students do well in US history survey classes and what "success" looks like in a course that combines study of American institutions and government over time with close attention to historical thinking skills. We want to share this critical work because we have some concern that our institutional and political leaders might well find the study of US history at the lower-division level too expensive to sustain for all CSU students. In that worst-case scenario, History Departments at the California State University would be teaching thousands fewer students each year. Our department faculties would further shrink, and the impact on the job market for Ph.Ds and for the field generally would be potentially great. History and the liberal arts generally might not be able to regain that lost ground. We believe we are finding new ways to demonstrate both the value of such classes, as well as the value students place on them. These classes desperately need close attention now. At this time, more than 30 CSU historians have entirely overhauled the way they teach these classes. We are getting to a better understanding of the consequences of these changes for students and for our institutions. We would like to share that with the OAH in Sacramento, where so many critical decisions about public higher education in California are made.
column2: Undermining Student Success?:  How U.S. History Surveys Landed On The Chancellor's Shortlist For Low-Success Courses And What 30 Csu Historians Did About It

column1:
Dr. Fallon Samuels Aidoo (Northeastern University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Deepened engagement with urban planning and policy history has helped illuminate powerful currents of hidden resistance to the social justice movements that drive scholarly interpretations of post-WWII America. The influence of other disciplines, including American Studies, architectural design, and human geography, has also enhanced promising scholarship by urban historians that focuses upon social inequality within metropolitan communities. Building off recent literature that shows how historical actors continued to maintain a color-conscious praxis in putatively race-neutral aspects of urban planning, such as architecture, taxation, and transportation, this panel seeks to highlight discursive reassessments proposed by junior urbanists that explains how the devaluation of black residents in American metropolitan development has perpetuated the salience of racial inequality even as civic discourse surrounding race and racial inequality has shifted toward color-blindness.
column2: Valued Properties: Color-Consciousness In Mid-20th Century Urban Planning And Policy

column1:
Dr. Gabriela F Arredondo (University of California, Santa Cruz)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

Dr. Vicki L. Ruíz has been instrumental to the development of numerous generations of women of color in academia during four decades. Her mentoring and innovative research has inspired us to conduct research that builds on her methodological and analytical approaches. This roundtable is composed of five panelists, all Chicana/Latina historians, who will discuss the influence of Dr. Ruízs work and mentoring. Together, they demonstrate the immense influence she has on different generations of Chicana/Latina historians in and outside academia. The first panelist, Dr. Marla Ramírez, recalls reading Vicki Ruízs From Out of the Shadows book as an undergraduate and the impact of learning about first-person accounts through oral history. Eleven years later, she is now writing her first book which also employs oral history to center the voices of repatriated ethnic Mexicans during the Great Depression. Her paper examines the intergenerational gendered experiences and prolonged effects of removal at the turn of the twentieth century while reflecting on Vicki Ruízs research and mentoring. The second panelist, Dr. Mireya Loza, similarly explains that Vicki Ruízs scholarship broadens our understanding of oral history methodology that helps uncover understudied people and their experiences. Dr. Lozas deployment of oral history methods builds on Dr. Ruíz contributions by exploring the intersections of race and sexuality in bracero communities. Her paper focuses on Mexican guest workers narratives that highlight indigenous and sexual identities as lived in labor camps. The third panelist, Dr. Miroslava Chávez-García, highlights that Dr. Ruizs presence in the academy has been a vital component to her research, teaching, and service. Indeed, she credits Dr. Ruíz, with shaping all her research projects – books and articles – as well as her professional accomplishments. Her paper speaks to the ways Dr. Ruízs research on Mexican women in the twentieth century influenced her own research, including her latest book on the emotional and personal impact of migration on Mexican migrants in the 1960s and 1970s.The fourth panelists, Dr. Gabriela Arredondo, underlines that Dr. Ruízs research and mentoring have profoundly influenced her own research trajectory and intellectual development for over two decades. Her paper discusses her current research project on Chicana activists in San Jose, California. Specifically focusing on Wilma Martinez, a key participant in the nationalization of MALDEF in the 1970s. In doing so, she draws on key tenets of Ruízs work to demonstrate her intellectual and methodological contributions to the formulation of this kind of research.The fifth panelist, Dr. Natalia Molina, states that much of what she knows about Chicana/Latina, immigration, labor, and urban history, she learned from reading Dr. Ruízs oeuvre. Her paper discusses her book in-progress, Place-makers and Place-making: The Story of a Los Angeles Community, drawing on the key tenets of Ruízs work to demonstrate how she has shaped a generation. Place-makers examines, Echo Park, an overlooked Los Angeles neighborhood. At the heart of the book is an in-depth look at Mexican restaurants that served as urban institutions that developed the areas social capital in the absence of successful urban programs.
column2: Vicki L. Ruízs Legacy: Empowering Mujeres In Research, Scholarship, And Community Across Generations For Four Decades

column1:
Mr. Nick Cull (University of Southern California (Annenberg School for Communication))

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Cold War interventions in the countries of the Global South have proved historically transformative. As the United States and the Soviet Union attempted to manipulate the very shape of the postwar world in their own respective images, this new imperialism yielded both desired and unexpected outcomes. The superpowers drew into their orbit less powerful, emerging countries, many of which were wrestling with the processes of decolonization. This panel compares American public diplomacy efforts in four critical regions of the world during the rise and fall of the Cold War: South Asia, East Asia, the Middle East, and Latin America. By developing an expansive and complex public diplomacy apparatus, the U.S. applied cultural, economic, and political strategies to expand their influence and contain communism throughout the Global South.Papers focusing on Pakistan, India, and Taiwan in the postwar decades explore how U.S. state programs for technical and educational development emerged as ideological battlegrounds for support in developing nations but equally, the ways in which local actors leveraged American programming to their own advantage. In the case of South Asia, Uzma Quraishi finds that the promotion of American higher education in Indian and Pakistani universities inadvertently established permanent migratory linkages to the United States. Though the State Department in the postwar years never intended for large numbers of Asians to migrate to the U.S., their actions ultimately helped alter the demographic composition of the U.S. James Lins work shows that covert American funding of the Republic of China (Taiwan or ROC) development was intended to generate broad Third World support for the ROC in the UN. While the U.S. used Taiwanese success as a front to gain UN votes, the ROC applied the same rhetoric of successful modernization to validate its own legitimacy.Papers on Afghanistan and Nicaragua demonstrate the shifting meanings of freedom and human rights as wielded by public diplomacy campaigns, especially during the Reagan administration. Andrew Hammonds paper on the Soviet-Afghan War shows the ways in which freedom was pressed into service by the U.S. in its global struggle against the U.S.S.R. Freedom would become the key term through which the Afghan struggle against the Soviet Union would be understood within the U.S. By analyzing the U.S. Office of Public Diplomacys (OPD) role in subverting the power of Nicaraguas existing leftist government, Mike Schmidli unpacks the dark underbelly of covert action during the late Cold War period. The OPD actively sought to influence thought-leaders in the U.S. in order to mobilize support for American goals of regime change abroad by actively circulating policy-related information among American intellectuals and journalists.Collectively, the papers on this panel suggest that what the U.S. State Department once termed psychological warfare was surprisingly expansive in scope even as it was used to foster support among various publics for American foreign policy aims during the entire Cold War period. Public diplomacy programs were so extensive that they quite often altered the historical trajectories of the countries involved, while frequently undermining these countries claims to self-determination.
column2: Weaving Webs Of Power And Influence: U.S. Cold War Public Diplomacy Across The Global South

column1:
Tiffany Baker (Florida Historic Capitol Museum)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

The Joint AASLH-AHA-NCPH-OAH Task Force on Public History Education and Employment recently surveyed employers and public history alumni in an effort to illuminate the historical skills and training experiences most valued in the field. This roundtable will briefly present the surveys findings, and will assemble public history educators, alumni, employers, and students to react and respond to the task forces recommendations.
column2: What Do Public History Employers Want?: Reports And Reactions From The Field

column1:
Dr. Matthew Garcia (Dartmouth College)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 13:00 to 14:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

The JAHs Dec. 2016 Food Roundtable highlighted the success of popular writers in politicizing food issues for students and the public. As historians concerned with food politics, we add depth and further nuance to these conversations by bringing a historical perspective to bear on current issues. Indeed, the complex political and ethical problems that loom largest in public consciousness today -- such as poverty, immigration, environmental degradation, corporate responsibility (or lack thereof), and public health -- are made legible and addressable through the lens of food history. Arrangements of power are thrown into sharp relief; assumptions of inevitability and timelessness may be challenged and disrupted; and alternative solutions and frameworks are given a chance to emerge. In this paper panel, we are less concerned with the materiality of food than the material contexts that swirl around foods production, consumption, and distribution, and the activists, workers, businesspeople, and government officials whose legacies have shaped the political economy we must navigate today.Matt Garcia will explore the attempts of an American food conglomerate, the United Fruit Company, to mitigate conditions for workers in Honduras after years of devastating corporate exploitation. Garcias account previews the socially conscious capitalism of the twenty-first century and reveals the limits of ethical business in a context of free trade.Laurie Green turns to a time when public attention to obesity focused foremost on malnutrition among the nations poorest, particularly women suffering not from wrong-headed diets but their forced reliance on starchy and fatty foods instead of fresh and nutritious ones. Her paper shows that in the politics of hunger of the late 1960s and early 1970s, concerned antipoverty activists, medical experts, and liberal officials framed the cure for obesity as an expansion of federal food programs, focusing on structural change instead of personal responsibility. In his treatment of the California-based National Land for People Movement, Mario Sifuentez will broaden our understanding of the meaning of food security by looking at efforts to redistribute land to the people who labored upon it. By focusing on water reclamation as a way to alleviate poverty and develop farmworker power, the National Land for People Movement advanced a radical critique of corporate farming, one that begs consideration in light of Californias current water crisis.Using a meal delivery program for people with AIDS as a case study, Lana Dee Povitz will examine how volunteer ideology, mobilized during the conservative political climate of the 1980s, helped change what it meant to care about AIDS. In preparing gourmet meals for highly stigmatized, suffering people, ordinary New Yorkers found a satisfying and tangible way to make a difference. Simultaneously, the organization"s success minimized the importance of government intervention and elevated private charity as a solution to social ills."Ethical business," land use rights, obesity, and questions of responsibility for the public good all remain high-stakes issues. Each participant will conclude his or her paper by addressing the implications for collective problem-solving in the present moment.
column2: Whats This Really About?: Histories Of Food Politics In The Late-Twentieth Century

column1:
Professor Peter S Carmichael (Gettysburg College)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Letter writing offered perhaps the most important way for soldiers to stay connected to their loved ones at home. Yet the difficulties in maintaining these connections were palpable. The experience of war gave soldiers a different vocabulary, quite literally, from that of citizens on the homefront. Too, as active participants in a war of unprecedented carnage and destruction, soldiers experienced the enormity of human loss and suffering differently from their people at home. As these three papers suggest, soldiers often practiced a delicate balancing act between documenting their wartime experiences and assuring their loved ones that all was well. Peter S. Carmichaels paper, The Importance of Being Cheerful, looks at the letters written by poor and informally educated soldiers, unschooled in epistolary conventions of the mid-nineteenth century. Their lack of formal training, Carmichael asserts, freed their pens from […] formulaic narrative structures, thus allowing them to write unselfconsciously in their letters home. There was nothing unselfconscious in the letters written by the subjects of Timothy J. Williams paper, prisoners of war. As Williams notes, the constraints on subject and page length imposed by camp censors forced prisoners to compose their letters deliberately and consciously. Their prose, unlike Carmichaels soldiers, was most assuredly fettered. Williams argues that the unique epistolary culture created in prison camps ultimately gave rise to a new genre of postwar literature, the prison narrative. These narratives, he concludes, contributed to a vibrant print culture that circulated in the decades following the war. By rehashing old sectional divisions and wartime animosities prison narratives effectively forestalled reconciliationist efforts. Finally, Sarah E. Gardner turns to soldiers epistolary conversations about books, arguing that shared reading often served as a bridge across what seemed unbridgeable. She takes as a case study a wounded Confederate soldiers seemingly odd juxtaposed conversations with his fiancée about a popular British domestic novel, Dinah Craiks Mistress and Maid, and a series of suicides in camp. These discussions about books, she argues, allowed this soldier to discuss not only his profound misery and anxiety but also to reassert his common humanity. Taken together, then, the papers in this session explore connections between the act of soldiering and the composition of letters home by paying close attention to the manner in which soldiers wrote their stories. As the panel demonstrates, how men wrote (language, aesthetic, writing style) can sometimes be as important as what they told.
column2: When All That Is Left Is Words: The Writing Sensibilities Of Civil War Soldiers

column1:
Professor Van Gosse (Franklin & Marshall College)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

Many Americans know little to nothing about Puerto Rico. Popular perceptions are matched by a dearth of panels on Puerto Rico at U.S. history conferences and the lamentable reality that many historians of the United States know little about Puerto Rico. Puerto Ricos residents are full U.S. citizens, though they are denied the right to vote for president or congressional representatives. More Puerto Ricans currently live on the mainland than the island. Puerto Ricans constitute the second largest Latino population in the United States. The history of Puerto Rico, however, often falls between the cracks that separate the fields of United States and Latin American history, and is relegated to the margins of those fields. This roundtable addresses the OAHs 2018 conference theme of the forms of United States history by interrogating forms of United States history that place Puerto Rico at the margins; it reconfigures those narratives by placing Puerto Rico at their center. The roundtable brings together experts in the fields of United States, Latin American, and Puerto Rican history—Van Gosse (chair), Marisol LeBrón, Teresita Levy, Lisa Materson, and Margaret Power—to highlight new developments in the study of Puerto Rican history. Roundtable participants will discuss how these developments and the inclusion of Puerto Rican history shed light on key U.S. history forms and narratives, including the intersecting histories of political movements, state formation, labor systems, immigration, gender, race formation, and colonialism.
column2: Why Puerto Rico Matters To Historians Of The United States

column1:
Dr. Sarah Case (UC Santa Barbara)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

This panel will consider the opportunities, challenges, and impact of women working in the field of public history. How does gender operate in the field itself in terms of practice and professionalization? Is the field itself gendered?
column2: Women In Public History: Issues, Reflections, Trajectories

column1:
Dr. Kristin Bayer (Marist College)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

While political, military, and economic victors continue to shape policy and monopolize historical memory, exclusive consideration of winners can seem to foreclose other options. Analyses and narratives of alternatives to mainstream society help scholars construct more inclusively representative history and create a usable past. Such interpretations underscore which groups views have triumphed or actions have dominated but foreground the breadth of perceived options at historical moments. Intersectional womens and gender history, the foci of our panelists, are central to reevaluating which and whose stories have been ignored. Alternative narratives also delineate the parameters for social action and creative intervention in earlier eras. This form of historical inquiry, then, speaks directly to dissatisfied students and readers who are searching for models from the past to apply to contemporary proposals for change. Our panel creates a composite sketch of American women who, in claiming public cultural space, stood in radical distinction to the dominant culture. Making their marks between the 1920s and the end of the twentieth century, they stretched the boundaries of expectations—raising possibilities and breaking new terrain for future revolutionaries. Collectively, these papers promise to lend new insights into the role that women have played in forging cultural insurgency. The panel includes a diverse group of historians who highlight the exciting scholarship coming out of universities and liberal arts and community colleges.
column2: Women Inventing Alternatives

column1:
Professor Virginia Espino ()

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 11:30 to 13:00

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Luncheon

The 2018 Womens Committee Luncheon Speaker is Dr. Virginia Espino, an oral historian and documentary filmmaker affiliated with UCLAs Center for Oral History Research. Dr. Espino is an historian of Californias Latino/a community. In 2016, the OAH awarded her film No Más Bebés, an investigation of the systematic and involuntary sterilization of Latinas at the Los Angeles-USC Medical Center, the Erik Barnouw Award in recognition of outstanding programming on television, or in documentary film, concerned with American history, the study of American history, and/or the promotion of American History. Dr. Espino will speak about oral history, gender, and the role of a public intellectual.
column2: Women's Committee Luncheon: 'I Am The Author Of My Own Story: Collecting Gendered Narratives Of The Working Class Through The Art And Craft Of Oral History.

column1:
Dr. Laura D. Gutiérrez (University of the Pacific)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

"Working the Borderlands," will consider the intersections between labor, migration, and the production of North America"s national, trans- and multi-national borderlands. We will explore how resource extraction, labor economies, commodity flows, and capitalist ecologies have informed the movement of people across the borderlands and have shaped the conditions and settings in which they work. Additionally, our panel will examine the ways race, gender, and sexuality all shape and define border landscapes operating in a global economy. The roundtable features panelists with different perspectives (environmental, labor, cultural history), and regional emphases (U.S.-Mexico, U.S.-Canada) to the study of migration, labor, and borderlands.Each participant in the roundtable will bring their own expertise to the subject of labor circuits and the production of North American borderlands. Yale Postdoctoral Fellow Maria Quintana moves beyond bi-national frameworks to consider how provisions of the Bracero Program (1942-1964), which centered mainly on Mexican laborers, were extended to incorporate Caribbean labor and how the incarceration of Japanese Americans were framed within the same racial logics of labor importation. Assistant Professor Laura D. Gutiérrez details the consequences of labor migration for sending countries by tracing how the deportation and return migration off workers affected Mexico and the U.S.-Mexico border region in the 20th century. Assistant Professor Holly M. Karibo examines the cultural and social spaces that governed cross-border interactions in the Great Lakes border region despite state control and regulation of illicit economies. Exploring histories of labor importation, repatriation, and illicit economies, our roundtable seeks to continue a discussion and build on the forms of history that search for the symptomatic traces of the excluded. We will discuss innovative methodological practices that attempt to locate the histories of those who remained obscure to state structures/documentation as a means to survive. Conversely, we will consider the ways in which we read state archives against the grain, to find the traces of people impacted by resource extraction, labor economies, commodity flows in the borderlands (Stoler). Our roundtable will also highlight the ways in which labor history has impacted borderlands history and vice versa. The history of labor has been intimately tied to the legal, social, and cultural histories of the North American borderlands, and continues with the more recent scholarship of our panelists and that of Andrés Reséndez (The Other Slavery), Mario Sifuentez (Of Forests and Fields), Mireya Loza (Defiant Braceros), etc. Additionally, rather than focusing on one border region, we will examine the similarities and differences across both the U.S-Mexico and the U.S.-Canada borders. Labor migration flows are never as simple as crossing one boundary. They may require the movement across multiple boundaries within and outside nation-states. Furthermore, these borderlands have been co-constituted, with labor and immigration policies of one impacting the other. We will draw on the audience to add their knowledge of interior, urban, Pacific, Caribbean, and global borderlands to the discussion. And, finally as a group (panelists and audience), we would like to outline future directions (methodologies, research sites/topics, collaborations) for working the borderlands.
column2: Working The Borderlands

column1:
Dr. Jackie M. Blount (The Ohio State University)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

This panel explores how historians of education, race, and gender are sharing their work through digital books and video, which raises provocative questions about the future of scholarly communication. Jackie Blount will discuss her companion web site and short video that accompany her forthcoming biography on Ella Flagg Young. Jack Dougherty and his contributors are creating On The Line: How Schooling, Housing, and Civil Rights Shaped Hartford and its Suburbs, a digital-first, open-access book with interactive maps and oral history videos, under contract with Amherst College Press (http://OnTheLine.trincoll.edu). Esther Cyna and her colleagues are producing Educating Harlem, a digital history project in two interconnected parts that mix elements of traditional publishing with web-based open-access scholarship.
column2: Writing Race, Gender, And Education: Digital Book And Video Projects

column1:
Professor Catherine Ceniza Choy (UC Berkeley)

Date: 2018-04-12

Time: 12:45 to 14:15

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

For over seven decades, the history of the Philippines during WWII, where thousands of Filipino and American soldiers under the U.S. Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE) and a million civilians perished, is not taught in U.S. history for high schools. The Philippines, a colony of the United States since 1898, was invaded just a few hours after Pearl Harbor on December 8, 1941. On July 14, 2016, the California State Board of Education (SBE) approved its inclusion in the Grade 11 U.S. history curriculum framework (Chapter 16). Since 2014, Bataan Legacy Historical Society (BLHS) had been working with the California Department of Education"s Instructional Quality Commission (IQC) to include WWII in the Philippines in the history curriculum framework for high school and this is the culmination of its efforts. This will be the first time that these events will be taught in high schools in California and even in the United States. Among the topics that are now included in the curriculum framework are The Philippine Commonwealth; the creation of the United States Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE) comprised of Americans and a majority of Filipinos; the disruption of the timetable of the Imperial Japanese Army by the USAFFE Forces despite suffering from massive disease and starvation and fighting without any air support; the Bataan Death March and the thousands of casualties; the role of the Filipino and American guerrillas during the liberation; the American soldiers who were transported in hell ships to labor camps in Asia; the Battles of Leyte Gulf and the destruction of Manila. In California, each school district is responsible for the implementation of the curriculum framework in accordance with the local control and accountability plan (LCAP). BLHS is creating sample lesson plans that can be made available to high school districts to implement the revised history curriculum framework for Grade 11 in accordance with its recommendations that were fully approved by the IQC and the SBE. BLHS will base its sample lesson plans on its exhibition WWII in the Philippines – The Legacy of Two Nations with an inquiry-based approach that will engage the students to ask strategic questions that can lead them to a better understanding of the past and its relevance to the world that they live in. This can foster community engagement and conversations that can empower them to become responsible members and future leaders of the community.BLHS has a core of experts in its Educational Advisory Group which consists of members of the academia and the military.
column2: WWII In The Philippines-The Legacy Of Two Nations

column1:
Dr. Dawson Barrett (Del Mar College)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

The investigation of historys many forms, whether the growing wave of digital archives, Lin-Manuel Mirandas Hamilton, John Lewis March, or even Comedy Centrals Drunk History, requires equal consideration of historys audiences, both academic and popular.This interactive roundtable will specifically consider a youth audience. Presenters will examine how various media and pedagogical practices reach younger students in their classrooms, as well as how scholars can involve young people as historical researchers, documenters, interpreters, readers, contributors, and subjects. The panelists, whose research interests, ranks, and affiliations vary widely, will approach these inquiries with brief comments rooted in their own experiences and a collective goal of drawing audience members into the discussion.Dr. Robert Samuel Smith serves as Director of the Cultures & Communities Program and Associate Vice Chancellor for Global Inclusion & Engagement at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. In addition to acting as chair, his contribution to the round table will highlight the ways that reforms in the criminal justice system, especially the emergence of electronic monitoring, are re-shaping the lives of youth by expanding supervision and carceral experiences to homes and local communities. This research is informed by focus groups with youth under GPS surveillance/electronic monitoring, focus groups with youth service providing agencies, and detailed statistical analyses of Milwaukee County municipalities with regard to arrest, warrant and electronic monitoring data.Christina V Villarreal spent nearly a decade teaching and learning in East Oakland, California where she taught 7th & 8th Social Studies at a co-founded small school. She later served as an assistant principal in Oakland, where she successfully led the design and implementation of a University of California, A-G approved 9th grade Ethnic Studies course. Villarreal has previously taught ethnic studies courses at San Francisco State University, Teachers College, Columbia University, Hunter College, and Harvard University. She is a research fellow at the IUME at Teachers College, Columbia University, and serves as the Director of History & Social Studies Education at Brown University.Barry M. Goldenberg is a Graduate Research Fellow at the Institute for Urban and Minority Education (IUME), where he previously led the Youth Historians in Harlem program—an after-school program for high school students that sought to explore the implications of collaborative history-making with young people. His comments will focus on the last two years of the Youth Historians project, emphasizing what historians can learn through collaborations with high school students and how soliciting the assistance of youth can broaden our methods and improve scholarship.Dr. Dawson Barretts teaching duties at Del Mar College include dual enrollment courses at several rural high schools in South Texas. He is the author of Teenage Rebels: Successful High School Activists from the Little Rock Nine to the Class of Tomorrow, an illustrated trade history book for teenagers. Barretts comments will focus on the opportunities and limitations of Texas rapidly expanding early college/dual credit programs, as well as his efforts to use youth as a lens of study in college-level history courses for high school students.
column2: Youth Engagement And History

column1:
Ms. Jill Margaret Jensen (University of Redlands)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 15:00 to 16:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Panel Discussion

It has been nearly thirty years since a pioneer in the study of international political economy, Robert Cox, published his book, Production, Power and World Order. Within, he assessed the reciprocal relationship between these facets based upon the organization of world labor forces and the consequences of output. Cox and others took into consideration the push and pull between global periphery and hegemony. With this in mind—and including direction from liberal or socialist states—how do historical interpretations of production, power, and world order fit into our understanding of global development? This panel offers new insights on the history of globalization, via focus on dependency theory, rising consciousness about underdevelopment, and emerging international perspectives on neoliberalism. The 1970s, generally have garnered a declension narrative, yet panelists disagree with this approach and instead plot a new way forward by incorporating the global into the yet established historiographical discussion. Jensen reviews on-the-ground development through the lens of the Skills Program of Africa, created under the UN World Employment Program (WEP). It served as a pragmatic—if misdirected—formula for development. In the early 1970s, JASPA aimed at a mandate for employment at the crux of rural development, urban employment, and manpower/womanpower procurement. Part of a failed endeavor, the WEP non-the-less led to the formation of new knowledge on the differentiation in employment by gender and region and a greater understanding of the crossover between informal and formal work. Perhaps most importantly, the WEP provided solid evidence for the prolongation of what one author called boxes…of impoverishment, heterogeneity and an economic underworld within developing nations.Stevens focuses on a group of socialists and economists working within the interdisciplinary Centro de Estudios Socioeconomicos at the University of Chile, Santiago. With varying degrees of affiliation to the Chilean Movimiento Izquierda Revolucionaria (MIR) these academics used the university as an institutional vantage point from which to mobilize a social movement to the left of Allendes Chilean road to socialism, orienting their research around themes of dependency. This collaborative research, clearly articulated in a series of notebooks and bulletins in the late 1960s, represented the most ambitious effort to empirically operationalize key elements of dependency theory, either up to that moment or since. Williams offers a reinterpretation of the move to international neoliberalism with examples from the developing world. Reeling from hyperinflation and economic mismanagement, Indonesias economy was careening toward catastrophe in the mid-1960s. A fumbled coup by the Communist Party unwittingly marked what became an embrace of the market. Suhartos authoritarian government turned to a group of University of Indonesia economists who succeeded in restoring order by instituting market reforms. Meanwhile, the efforts of the Berkeley Mafia coincided with Brazils post-coup economic reforms to unleash the Brazilian Miracle. Indonesia and Brazil embraced a market path, and they were followed by leading regional and global actors. Williams disputes traditional narratives emphasizing Milton Friedman or the Chicago Boys as the progenitors for international neoliberalism. Instead, he considers other members of a global sea change in economic thinking.
column2: On The Capitalist Periphery In The 1970s: Dependency, Underdevelopment, And The New Economic Sense Of Neoliberalism

column1:
Dr. Douglas R. Egerton (Le Moyne College)

Date: 2018-04-14

Time: 10:00 to 11:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Paper Session

Scholars have increasingly challenged the triumphalist narrative of the American Civil War, more critically evaluating the lasting traumas and costs of the four-year conflict. In assessing societal expectations and lived experiences of soldiers in war, it is necessary to consider carefully long term repercussions of black military service. These three papers offer new and different ways of analyzing black troops. Holly Pinheiro looks closely at the martialistic rhetoric exhorting black men to join the military, noting the stark absence of appeals to black women. This differs markedly from calls to white men to enlist. Jonathan Lande explores the impact Frederick Douglass celebration of black mens sacrifice had on postwar African American intellectuals" conception of emancipation. Lesley J. Gordon probes the narrow and often contradictory definitions of courage and cowardice as applied to black and white troops in combat.
column2: The Double Edged Sword Of Freedom: Race, Gender, And Military Service During The American Civil War

column1:
Dr. Sarah Gordon (New-York Historical Society)

Date: 2018-04-13

Time: 08:00 to 09:30

Location: OAH Schedule

Type: Roundtable Discussion

In 2017, the New-York Historical Society opened the Center for Womens History, the first institution in the nation within the walls of a museum dedicated to enriching the public understanding of the American past through a focus on women. Anchoring the physical space of the Center is an interactive digital installation, Womens Voices, which showcases a network of famous and unsung women from New Yorks history, and aims to introduce visitors to womens history in an engaging and accessible way. The scholars who worked on this innovative media piece will discuss the creative process and its research challenges, chiefly the effort to resist the hall of fame treatment, which would merely replace a pantheon of Great Men with one of Great Women. Instead, Womens Voices highlights collective movements over individuals and respects the insights of feminists such as Audre Lorde, who insisted that Without community there is no liberation. Yet the tension remains, between the desire to enlighten visitors and the need to supply them with familiar faces (those fun girls--as an early tester demanded to see). A group of public and academic historians will use the project as a point of departure to address larger questions of womens history and public history.
column2: Where Are The Fun Girls? Womens History In The Public Realm
